A blend of 70% dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” processed coffee from the Halo Bariti Cooperative in Yirgacheffe and 30% wet or “washed” processed coffee from a micro-lot produced by Yirgacheffe farmer Birhanu Bali Jilo. Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious coffee and high-quality coffee. Visit redroostercoffee.com or call 540-745-7338 for more information.
Summary: An engaging and dramatically complex espresso: deeply floral, vibrantly zesty, roundly nut- and chocolate-toned.

Name: Cerro San Luis Costa Rica
BlindReview: Rich, sweetly pungent. Caramel, dried fig, cocoa, hops and lavender in aroma and cup. Mellow, round acidity; light though syrupy mouthfeel. The flavor consolidates around cocoa and dried fig in the clean, long finish.
Notes: Produced by Alexander and Sara Delgado at their farm in Costa Rica’s Central Valley from trees of the Catuai, Caturra and Villa Sarchi varieties. Chocolate Fish is a distinguished New-Zealand-inspired micro-roaster based in Sacramento California, focused on the best in both quality and integrity.Visit www.chocolatefishcoffee.com or call 916-451-5181 for more information.
Summary: A crisply pretty Costa Rica cup, sweet with dried fruit and rich cocoa notes throughout.

Name: Baloo Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly tart, richly spicy. Roasted cacao nib, cedar, apricot, orange zest, hazelnut in aroma and small cup. Light, syrupy mouthfeel. The rich, long finish consolidates around orange zest and cedar. Balanced and chocolaty in three parts milk.
Notes: Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria, Illinois committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees from roasting process to the cup. Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
Summary: A sweet but distinct tartness animates this rich, chocolaty espresso.

Name: Fazenda Santa Luzia Brasil
Origin: Campos Alto district, Minas Gerais State, southeastern Brazil
BlindReview: Rich, intricately sweet. Honey, rhododendron, tangerine zest and hazelnut in aroma and cup. Juicy, round acidity; buoyant, satiny mouthfeel. Nut and honey dominate in a crisp, quiet finish.
Notes: Produced by Jose Maria de Oliveira in the Cerrado growing region of Minas Gerais State in southeastern Brazil. This is a dry-processed or “natural” coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or “washed” versions. Chocolate Fish is a distinguished New-Zealand-inspired micro-roaster based in Sacramento California, focused on the best in both quality and integrity.Visit www.chocolatefishcoffee.com or call 916-451-5181 for more information.
Summary: A classic natural-process Brazil, with honey at the heart and nut-toned complication.

Name: Espresso Iza
Origin: Rwanda; Sidama/Sidamo growing region, southern Ethiopia
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly roast-toned and deep. Dark chocolate, tangerine zest, lightly scorched cedar, vanilla, lily-like flowers in aroma and small cup. Smooth, slightly leanish mouthfeel; dark chocolate and tangerine zest carry into a richly drying finish. Smoothes out in three parts milk with chocolate and lily at the center.
Notes: This blend is composed of wet processed or “washed” coffee from Rwanda and a dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” processed coffee from southern Ethiopia. The company name Amavida combines the Spanish words for love and life, reflecting Amavida’s multifaceted commitment to fairness and fine coffee.Visit www.amavida.com or call 850-213-1965 for more information.
Summary: Roasted in classic American, retro-darkish style, developing a dry but zesty, pleasingly nuanced chocolate.

Name: Fresh Perspective Ethiopian
BlindReview: Richly and ripely fruit-toned. Tartly juicy raspberry, sandalwood, roasted cacao nib, lavender in aroma and cup. Crisp, lively acidity; dry, satiny mouthfeel. Lavender and roasted cacao nib carry into a crisply floral-toned finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Most Yirgacheffe coffee is prepared by the conventional wet method, in which the skin and pulp are removed from the beans or seeds before they are dried, encouraging a cleanly high-toned, often intensely floral- and citrus-toned cup. This Yirgacheffe is a “natural” or dry-processed version, however, meaning the beans/seeds were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a deeper-toned profile, more pungent than bright, though still extravagant in its aromatics. Founded in 2015, the Greater Goods mission is to enrich the lives of coffee-drinkers through passion, creativity, innovation and commitment to the consistency of the specialty coffee the company roasts and to the local causes supported with its proceeds. Visit greatergoodsroasting.com or call 512-858-2680 for more information.
Summary: An unusual dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” profile: ripely juicy yet crisply dry and lavender-toned.

Name: Bean Brain Reserve Suke Quto Ethiopia Sidamo Espresso
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Sidamo growing region, south-central Ethiopia
BlindReview: Sweetly pungent, chocolate toned. Blood orange, sandalwood, jasmine, dark chocolate, almond paste in aroma and small cup. Silky mouthfeel; nut and fruit notes persist in the finish. Fills out three parts milk with a complex range of chocolate, fruit and nut suggestions.
Notes: One of Virtuoso’s “Bean Brain” limited edition coffees, this one is sold in an edition of 250 bags, numbered by hand. Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are produced from traditional Ethiopian varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. When processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) they typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on floral notes. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this one is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Notes: One of Virtuoso’s “Bean Brain” limited edition coffees, this one is sold in an edition of 250 bags, numbered by hand. Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are produced from traditional Ethiopian varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Most Yirgacheffe coffee is prepared by the conventional wet method, in which the skin and pulp are removed from the beans or seeds before they are dried, encouraging a cleanly high-toned, often intensely floral- and citrus-toned cup. Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade Certified, the latter meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a “fair” or economically sustainable price. Name: Kenya Othaya Peaberry
BlindReview: Deeply sweet, intricately rich. Lime zest, red currant, white sage, almond butter, magnolia-like flowers in aroma and cup. Zesty, juicy acidity; light, satiny-smooth mouthfeel. White sage and red currant are the throughline of the sweetly resonant, long finish. A coconut note surfaces in the very long.
Notes: Despite challenges ranging from unclear government coffee policy and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands to chronically unstable weather, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world’s most elegant and distinctive coffees. This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Name: Kopakaki Rwanda
BlindReview: Richly sweet, subtly floral. Butterscotch, hops, dark chocolate, honeydew melon in aroma and cup. Round, mellow acidity; full, buttery mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates to a savory hops note in the clean, lightly resonant finish.

Name: Bali Kintamani

Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Anyone who appreciates the lively paradox offered by a crisply dry, yet intricately sweet natural-processed Ethiopia.

Name: Rwanda Buremera
Origin: Buremera, Nyamagabe District, Southern Province, Rwanda
BlindReview: Delicate, sweetly spicy. Toffee, clove, sweet grapefruit, lavender in aroma and cup. Briskly tart, balanced acidity; crisp, delicate mouthfeel. Toffee and sweet grapefruit notes carry the rich, lightly sweet, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. Founded in 1995, Equator Coffees & Teas is a women-owned wholesale coffee roasting company that focuses on sustainability in coffee-sourcing and business practices. Visit www.equatorcoffees.com or call 800-809-7687 for more information.

Name: Colombia Supremo
BlindReview: Richly and deeply sweet. Baker’s chocolate, raisin, Brazil nut, magnolia, oak in aroma and cup. Roundly tart acidity; plump, syrupy mouthfeel. Richly drying, quietly nut-toned finish.
Notes: Supremo is the highest grade of Colombia coffee based on bean size and relative freedom from physical imperfections. Big Shoulders Coffee is a Chicago artisan roaster that emphasizes a fresh-roasted, no-nonsense approach to fine coffee. Visit www.bigshoulderscoffee.com or call 312-888-3042 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those looking for exceptional value in an accessible, impressively balanced, sweetly nut-toned Colombia.

Name: El Gaucho Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Deeply savory/sweet, floral-toned. Apricot, cedar, dark chocolate, a hint of lush narcissus in aroma and small cup. Creamy, light mouthfeel. Nut and rosemary notes surface, complicating the cedar in the savory, slightly tart finish. The herby cedar lingers in three parts milk, and apricot resurfaces.
Notes: Husband and wife team Samantha and Weston Nawrocki founded Manzanita Roasting on their family’s 127-year-old winery in San Diego. Committed to quality direct-trade sourcing and skillful roasting, they are happy to be a part of what they call San Diego’s new “coffee frontier.” Wholesale, retail and online sales. Visit www.manzanitaroasting.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a bold, sweet-savory espresso blend with an impressive price-to-quality ratio.

Name: Las Delicias Farms Colombia
BlindReview: Balanced, delicate and sweet. Peach, lemon zest, cedar, cacao nib, narcissus in aroma and cup. Juicy, lightly tart acidity; smooth, satiny mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates around lemon zest and peach in the clean, resonant finish.
Notes: Produced by farm manager Elias Hernandez at Las Delicias Farms from trees of five coffee varieties: Typica, Caturra, Castillo, Bourbon and Colombia. Processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). OQ Coffee is a New Jersey-based small-batch roasting company that emphasizes its commitment to coffee quality and community-building. Visit www.oqcoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a delicate, sweet Colombia with peach notes throughout and a pleasing floral character.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Dumerso Natural
BlindReview: Delicate and high-toned. Raspberry cider, dried hibiscus flower, liquorice root, roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup. Juicy, gently sweet acidity; light, satiny mouthfeel. The quietly sweet finish is redolent of cacao nib and dried hibiscus in the short, walnut in the long.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is rounder and lower-toned than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned Yirgacheffe profile. Big Creek Coffee Roasters is a small, quality-oriented batch roaster located in Montana’s Bitterroot Valley. Visit www.bigcreekcoffeeroasters.com or call 406-375-7508 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who appreciate an elegant natural-processed Ethiopia cup, with the cider and fruit complemented by crisp nut and cacao.

Name: Kenya AA Thageini
BlindReview: Delicately sweet-savory. Black currant, cocoa powder, gardenia, nutmeg, blackberry jam in aroma and cup. Soft but vibrant acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Black currant notes carry the richly drying, sweetly resonant finish.
Notes: Despite challenges ranging from unclear government coffee policy and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands to chronically unstable weather, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world’s most elegant and distinctive coffees. Big Creek Coffee Roasters is a small, quality-oriented batch roaster located in Montana’s Bitterroot Valley. Visit www.bigcreekcoffeeroasters.com or call 406-375-7508 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who appreciate a classic sweet-savory Kenya cup, gently pungent, quietly complex.

Name: Stubble Man Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply cocoa-toned, quietly complex. Baker’s chocolate, fresh-cut cedar, apricot jam, anise in aroma and small cup. Satiny mouthfeel. Chocolate and cedar carry into a resonant though drying finish. Surprisingly buttery and fat in three parts milk, with continued apricot and cedar notes.
Notes: Kevin Lin, the owner of HuZaZa Café, likes to relax and enjoy good coffees, and the coffees he serves at his Shanghai café are designed to provide that experience to customers. Located in a very competitive business area, HuZaZa Café offers an opportunity to slow down and enjoy life. Email [email protected] or call +86-1306-160-8697 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value an espresso both crisply dry and plumply fruit-toned.

Name: 100% Kona Bourbon Pointu Laurina
Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, “Big Island” of Hawaii
BlindReview: Deeply rich, subtly complex. Honey, prickly pear fruit, clove, cocoa nib and jasmine in aroma and cup. Delicate, dynamically composed acidity; buttery-smooth mouthfeel. The resonant, spice-toned finish leads with cocoa butter in the short and clove notes in the long.
Notes: Bourbon Pointu, botanical name var. Laurina, is a rare variety of arabica that is a  natural mutation of the famous Bourbon variety from Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean. The Bourbon Pointu is famous for its natural low levels of caffeine, bean shape (small and tending to be pointed at the ends, hence “pointu”), and pungently fruit-toned, Bourbon-like cup. This version was produced in Kona, Hawaii. Hula Daddy is a boutique coffee producer with farms at the 1,400 and 2,500 foot levels of the Mount Hualalai volcano near the northern end of the Kona growing district, five minutes above the town of Kailua-Kona. Visit www.huladaddy.com or call 888-553-2339 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those interested in the thrill of experiencing a rare and distinctive coffee variety, tactfully roasted by a highly regarded Kona producer.

Name: Ethiopia Halo Bariti
BlindReview: Deeply sweet and fruit-toned. Dried blueberry, sandalwood, cocoa powder, sweet-toned bourbon whisky in aroma and cup. Juicy, round acidity; silky, buoyant mouthfeel. The whisky suggestion on the nose and in the cup carries through the crisp, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is rounder and lower-toned than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned Yirgacheffe profile. Produced by the Halo Bariti Cooperative, founded in 2012. This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from one or more small-holding farmers at a “fair” or economically sustainable price. Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious coffee and high-quality coffee. Visit redroostercoffee.com or call 540-745-7338 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a powerhouse natural-processed Ethiopia coffee with an elegantly and complexly stated whisky-toned fruit character.

Name: Congo Sopacdi
Origin: Kalehe, South Kivu Province, Democratic Republic of the Congo
BlindReview: Delicately sweet and spicy. Crisp apple, dark caramel, toasted nori and rosemary flower in aroma and cup. Juicy, quietly tart acidity; satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Dark caramel notes run through the richly drying, resonant finish.
Notes: Last year, this exceptional coffee was selected as the #30 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 coffees of the year. The Democratic Republic of the Congo has very recently established itself as a source of specialty coffee with the development of cooperatives like Sopacdi. Located overlooking Lake Kivu, on the opposite side of the lake from Rwanda, this rapidly growing cooperative now has 5,600 members and apparently is succeeding its goal to help heal wounds left by the latest in eastern Congo’s seemingly endless string of horrific rebellions and civil wars. This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a “fair” or economically sustainable price.Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious coffee and high-quality coffee. Visit redroostercoffee.com or call 540-745-7338 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who appreciate a balanced, sweet and spicy coffee with compelling savory depth and impressive socio-economic and environmental credentials.

Name: Bernachon B945 Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Cocoa-toned, pungently roasty. Blackberry, cocoa, cedar, ripe (almost overripe) plum in aroma and small cup. Very lightly syrupy mouthfeel; cocoa and cedar persist in a richly drying finish. Muscular in three parts milk: dark chocolate, cedar, ripe plum, blackberry.
Notes: Wei Chuan Foods Corporation is an international food-science corporation. This coffee is a production of its specialty beverages research and development program. Visit www.weichuan.com.tw or call +866-0800-021-007 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value cocoa-toned, bracingly dark-roasted espressos. Big and assertive in milk.

Name: Bernachon N345 Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Subtly rich and balanced. Cedar, cocoa-powder, plum, star-anise, vanilla in aroma and small-cup. Lightly satiny mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates around quiet cocoa and cedar in a sweet finish. Fills out three parts milk nicely with continued cocoa and cedar notes.
Notes: Wei Chuan Foods Corporation is an international food-science corporation. This coffee is a production of its specialty beverages research and development program. Visit www.weichuan.com.tw/ or call +866-0800-021-007 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Subtle balance and comfortable sweetness make this an accessible espresso, perhaps best enjoyed as a cappuccino.

Name: Costa Rica Alberto Guardia Venecia Natural
BlindReview: Elegantly fruit-toned and rich. Blueberry, complex flowers (sweet lilac, pungent dried hibiscus), frankincense, fudgy chocolate in aroma and cup. Sweet, juicy acidity; buoyant, silky-smooth mouthfeel. Hibiscus and lilac carry the short finish, while blueberry and chocolate resurface in the long.
Notes: Produced by the father-son team of Alberto and Diego Guardia from trees of the Venecia variety, a mutant selection of the sturdy, compact-growing Caturra that withstands heavy rains, among other agronomic virtues. An unusually refined example of a dry-processed or “natural” coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or “washed” coffees. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value a dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” coffee with the fruit and complexity of type vividly yet elegantly embodied.

Name: Nicaragua Francisco Olivera
BlindReview: Sweetly spicy and complex. Nutmeg, baker’s chocolate, Asian pear and a hints of lavender and peppermint in aroma and cup. Gentle, round acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. Pear, mint, lavender and baker’s chocolate all carry into a savory, richly drying finish.
Notes: Produced from the Maracaturra coffee variety, a cross between the compact-growing Caturra (itself a mutant of the heirloom Bourbon) and the rare, huge-beaned Maragogipe, making it a parallel variety to the better-known Pacamara, a cross between Maragogipe and Pacas (also a mutant selection of Bourbon). Processed by the honey method, which means that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet or “washed” process, but at least some of the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value the deep, savory-sweet complexity of a fine Maracaturra/Pacamara-style cup.

Name: Adame Gorbota Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Lushly but resonantly bright; juicy. Complex fruit (mango, guava, tangerine), dark chocolate, sandalwood, jasmine in aroma and small cup. Silky mouthfeel; crisp, deeply flavor-saturated finish. Maintains its complexity into three parts milk, untamed and fruit-forward.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. This coffee is certified organically grown. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: An all-around spectacular single-origin espresso, immense in dimension and aromatic range in the straight shot, capable of maintaining its distinction even in tall milk.

Name: El Aguila Pacamara Espresso
Location: Santa Ana growing region, El Salvador
Origin: Santa Ana growing region, El Salvador
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Lush yet deeply savory; original. Honey, dark chocolate, roasted pine nut, horned melon, wisteria in aroma and small-cup. Full, syrupy mouthfeel. Fruit and flowers carry into a resonant short finish that turns richly drying in the long. Fills out milk with a complexly savory-sweet chocolate and peach- and melon-toned fruit.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the No. 12 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2016. This lot is comprised entirely of the much admired, bold-bean Pacamara variety of Arabica, a cross between the giant-beaned Maragogipe variety and Pacas, a selection of the heirloom Bourbon. This is a wet-processed or “washed” version, meaning the fruit skin and pulp were removed from the beans immediately after harvesting and before drying. Produced on El Aguila Farm by grower Ricardo Ariz. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Exceptional coffees of the Pacamara variety, with their juxtaposition of savory depth and floral sweetness, often require a reframing of our coffee expectations. This espresso is neither classically Italian nor brightly contemporary, but rather a sophisticated espresso framing of the savory-sweet sensory style of the Pacamara type.

Name: Lift Off Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly nuanced, crisp, balanced. Tangerine, pomegranate, honeysuckle, sandalwood in aroma and small cup. Light, satiny mouthfeel; layered fruit notes ring on in a gently tart finish. Three parts milk rounds the fruit, turning it delicately chocolaty.
Notes: Flight Coffee (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value finesse and delicate complexity. Its refinement shows best in a straight shot or in short milk drinks.

Name: Ethiopia Kossa Geshe
Origin: Limmu Kossa District, Jimma Zone, western Ethiopia
BlindReview: Crisp, soft, complexly layered. Violets, roasted cacao nib, cinnamon bark, tamarind in aroma and cup. Roundly gentle acidity; plush, enveloping mouthfeel. Cinnamon and cacao nib in particular carry into a long, resonant finish.
Notes: An unusually refined example of a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria, Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees from the roasting process to the cup. Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value simultaneous delicacy and richness in a crisp, cinnamon- and cocoa-toned cup.

Name: Single Origin Malabar Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Syrupy, savory-sweet, roasty. Dark chocolate, scorched mesquite, orange zest, very ripe peach in aroma and small cup. Fat, syrupy mouthfeel; heavy, savory-sweet finish. Fruit-toned chocolate and mesquite dominate in three parts milk.
Notes: This is an India monsooned Malabar. Monsooned Malabars are dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” coffees that, after fruit removal and drying, are exposed to wet, salty winds inside special open-sided warehouses on the southwest coast of India during the monsoon season. After several months of such exposure the beans swell to about twice their normal size, lose acidity, and develop a rustic, syrupy weight. Visit www.kapicoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy richly rustic, heavy-bodied, darker-roasted espressos.

Name: Jamaica Blue Mountain
Origin: Blue Mountain growing region, eastern Jamaica.
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso produced as a ristretto 25ml (.85-ounce) shot using a Nespresso capsule espresso brewer with whole milk heated using a conventional steam wand. Delicate, gently bright, lightly fruit-toned. Pineapple, molasses, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Very light, silky mouthfeel. Crisply sweet finish. Very delicate in three parts milk; the fir and molasses notes resolve to an elegant if faint chocolate.
Notes: Blue Mountain, grown in the lush, lovely mountains to the northeast of Kingston, Jamaica, is one of the world’s best-known coffees and also one of the most expensive. Hayman offers elite coffees in Nespresso compatible capsules and pods, including this Jamaica Blue Mountain. Hayman was founded in London, United Kingdom, in 2014. To ensure maximum freshness, Hayman coffee is roasted and shipped worldwide within 24 hours of receiving an order. The Hayman capsule is compatible with all Nespresso machines except Nespresso VertuoLine machines. For more information, visit www.haymancoffee.com. Nespresso is a brand owned by a third party unrelated to Hayman.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Nespresso capsule machine owners who enjoy a very delicate, sweetly bright espresso with a pleasing fruit note. Best at the short, ristretto setting.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Banko Gutiti Coop
Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia
BlindReview: Lush and fruit-forward. Jasmine, blood orange, frankincense and almond butter in aroma and cup. Rich, vibrant acidity; syrupy-smooth mouthfeel. The juicy finish is redolent of jasmine and almond.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Like virtually all southern Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. This is a dry-processed or “natural” Yirgacheffe, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or “washed” coffees. Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who appreciate the deeply aromatic and exotic character of an exceptional dried-in-the-fruit Yirgacheffe.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Sidamo Guji Shakisso
Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia
BlindReview: Immense, intricate, sweet. Lychee, caramelized pear, lush rose, rye whiskey and hazelnut in aroma and cup. Rich, juicy acidity; buoyant, silky mouthfeel. Lychee, cacao nib and a hint of fine musk carry the long, crisp, nuanced finish.
Notes: Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are produced from distinctive traditional Ethiopian varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Like virtually all southern Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. This is a dry-processed or “natural” coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or “washed” coffees. Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located in the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who love powerhouse, fruit-forward natural Ethiopia coffees with elegant but explicit notes of sweet ferment.

Name: Colombia Granja La Esperanza Las Margaritas Sudan Rume
Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia
BlindReview: Complex, delicate, richly sweet. Mango, blood orange, nougat, violet, myrrh in aroma and cup. Vibrant, juicy acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. All of the fruit, flower, nut and exotic spice notes carry through a deep, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Comprised entirely of beans from the rare Sudan Rume, a presumably very old variety of arabica originally selected from wild trees growing on the Boma Plateau of Sudan, close to the border with Ethiopia. This is a wet-processed or “washed” version, meaning that the fruit skin and pulp were removed from the seeds or beans before they were dried. Produced by farmer Rigoberto Herrera at Granja La Esperanza in Colombia, an innovative producer that specializes in impressive and innovative work with unusual cultivars of Arabica. Roasted at PT’s Coffee, where the motto is “without the love, it’s just coffee.” Visit www.ptscoffee.com or call 888-678-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those interested in experiencing a rare coffee variety, expertly roasted, that lives up to is rare billing in the cup.

Name: Adame Gorbota Ethiopia
BlindReview: Delicate, rich, sweetly floral. Tangerine blossom, cinnamon, passion fruit and dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Plump, balanced acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Cocoa and cinnamon, in particular, carry into a long, resonant finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a “fair” or economically sustainable price. JBC Coffee Roasters was founded in 1994 as Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters and is a family-owned specialty coffee roastery located in Madison, Wisconsin. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value a classic washed Ethiopia cup with profound aromatic intrigue.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Adado
BlindReview: Elaborately rich and sweet. Candied lemon zest, cacao nib, jasmine, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Gentle, slightly bitter acidity; lightly silky mouthfeel. Resonant finish dominated by lemon zest in the short finish and cacao nib and frankincense in the long.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on floral notes. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Flight Coffee (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire. Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: hose who enjoy a fine, classic wet-processed Yirgacheffe with the intricately lush yet crisply intense character of the type.

Name: Rock the House Blend
BlindReview: Delicate and sweetly spicy. Hibiscus, hazelnut, peach, grapefruit zest, sweet lavender in aroma and cup. Juicy, plump acidity; satiny mouthfeel. Grapefruit zest and hazelnut predominate in the crisp, richly sweet finish.
Notes: The name of this blend resulted from a contest held some years ago on the JBC Facebook page. Coffees composing this blend are certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, the latter meaning the green beans were purchased from small-holding farmers at a “fair” or economically sustainable price. JBC Coffee Roasters was founded in 1994 as Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters and is a family-owned specialty coffee roastery located in Madison, Wisconsin. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those seeking excellent value in a high-quality Fair-Trade/organic blend both elegant yet powerfully aromatic in the cup.

Name: Rwanda Hingakawa
BlindReview: Delicate, sweetly rich. Mulberry, tea rose, cacao nib, cedar in aroma and cup. Lightly juicy acidity; velvety mouthfeel. Cacao nib and cedar carry into the crisp, richly drying finish.
Notes: Produced by the Hingakawa Women’s Association Cooperative, processed on single-disc pulpers with an initial dry fermentation, followed by washing and soaking, a Central African variation on conventional wet-processing. Ghost Town is a small-batch roaster, wholesaler, equipment supplier and training resource located in Bozeman, Montana that takes great care in responsibly sourcing top-quality specialty coffees. Visit www.ghosttowncoffee.com call 406-586-0777 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value a juicy, zesty Central Africa cup animated by an appealing sweet-tart mulberry note.

Name: Burundi Kiryama
BlindReview: Rich and deeply sweet. Caramel, gardenia, apricot, malt in aroma and cup. Gentle, richly rounded acidity; richly creamy mouthfeel. Caramel and malt carry into the clean, gently drying finish.
Notes: Burundi is a small, landlocked country in Central Africa. Most coffee is grown in the mountains of the north, bordering Rwanda. Benefiting from ideal growing conditions and large plantings of Bourbon and related heirloom varieties of Arabica, Burundi coffee has an excellent reputation and a growing following among North American specialty roasters. This is a wet-processed or “washed” coffee, meaning that the fruit skin and pulp were removed from the seeds or beans before they were dried. Ghost Town is a small-batch roaster, wholesaler, equipment supplier and training resource located in Bozeman, Montana that takes great care in responsibly sourcing top-quality specialty coffees. Visit www.ghosttowncoffee.com call 406-586-0777 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy complex fruit and floral notes in a coffee with an unusual malt character throughout.

Name: Panama Ratibor Hartmann Natural
Origin: Santa Clara, Piedra Candela, Volcan growing region, western Panama
BlindReview: Elegantly powerful, exquisitely floral-toned. Apricot marmalade, brandy, white pepper, myrrh and molasses in aroma and cup. Crisp, round, deeply sweet acidity; liltingly plush mouthfeel. All flavor notes carry into a quietly resonant, long finish.
Notes: Finca Hartmann was founded in 1940 by Ratibor Hartmann and continues to be operated by members of the Hartmann family, having maintained its distinction for nearly eighty years. This is an unusually refined example of a dry-processed or “natural” coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or “washed” coffees. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those seeking the sensory hedonism of a beautifully made natural coffee: flavor-saturated, subtly complex and juicy throughout.

Name: Costa Rica Alberto Guardia Bourbon Honey
BlindReview: Deeply sweet and resonant. Honey, cedar, ripe blackberry, tangerine, lavender in aroma and cup. Round, sweet-toned acidity; buoyant, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Honey, lavender and tangerine saturate the long, rich finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety by farmers Alberto and Diego Guardia of Sonora Estate in Costa Rica. Processed by the honey method, which means that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet or “washed” process, but at least some of the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin.Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy an attractively assertive, fruit-forward Costa Rica cup with a honey throughline.

Name: Peru Cafe Femenino
BlindReview: Roast-toned and chocolaty. Roasted almond, dark chocolate, narcissus, molasses in aroma and cup. Crisply dry acidity; velvety mouthfeel. Chocolate and nut suggestions consolidate in a gently drying finish.
Notes: This coffee is organic and Fair Trade certified, the latter meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a “fair” or economically sustainable price. Cafe Femenino is an organization that supports women farmers and their families in coffee growing communities. This is a wet-processed or “washed” coffee, meaning the fruit skin and pulp were removed from the beans immediately after harvesting and before drying. Grounds for Change is a certified organic coffee roaster specializing in sustainable coffee and supporting a wide range of progressive ecological and social programs. The complete carbon footprint (from crop to cup) for this coffee has been offset with tree planting (carbonfund.org).Visit www.groundsforchange.com or call 800-796-6820 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy moderately dark-roasted coffees that pleasingly emphasize chocolate and nut notes.

Name: Kenya Karatina AA Espresso
BlindReview: Crisply and subtly sweet. Black currant, almond, gardenia-like flowers, dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Rounded, rich acidity; light but syrupy mouthfeel. Black currant and chocolate notes resonate in the quietly rich-toned, gently drying finish.
Notes: Produced from the SL-28 variety of Arabica, the tree variety that produces the finest coffees of Kenya. Despite challenges ranging from unclear government coffee policy and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands to chronically unstable weather, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world’s most elegant and distinctive coffees. Purchased as whole bean in a 12-ounce foil bag with one-way degassing valve at a Whole Foods location in northern California. This sample was roasted, roast-dated, and packaged at Ritual’s San Francisco, California facility. Ritual is a frequently celebrated (NY Times, etc.), obsessively quality-oriented roastery based in San Francisco, California. Visit www.ritualroasters.com or call 415-641-1024 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy an invigorating balance between sweet and tart notes in a delicate but subtly powerful Kenya cup.

Name: Organic Guatemala Asuvim Micro Lot
BlindReview: Spicy, crisply sweet. Green apple and grape, sandalwood, roasted cacao nib, a hint of myrrh in aroma and cup. Round, brisk but juicy acidity; silky mouthfeel. Citrus and sandalwood, in particular, carry into a dry, zesty finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of four different varieties of arabica: Bourbon, Caturra, Catuai and Pache. Certified organically grown and Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning this coffee was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Purchased as whole bean in a 12-ounce foil bag with one-way degassing valve at a Whole Foods location in northern California. This sample was roasted, roast-dated and packaged at Allegro’s Berkeley, California small-batch roasting facility. Visit www.allegrocoffee.com or call 800-227-1107 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value an invigorating, zesty-sweet cup with lively, distinctive aromatic intrigue.

Name: Kenya AA Medium Roast
BlindReview: Those who value a roundly assertive Kenya with rich, complexly stated sweetness enveloping tart fruit notes. An almost shockingly low price for a Kenya this distinctive and pleasing.
Notes: AA is the highest grade of Kenya coffee based on bean size and freedom from physical imperfections. Purchased as whole bean in a 13-ounce metal can with soft, peel-off foil top with inset one-way degassing valve at a Trader’s Joe’s location in northern California. Trader Joe’s is an innovative discount gourmet and natural foods supermarket chain with 457 stores in more than twenty states. Visit www.traderjoes.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value a roundly assertive Kenya with rich, complexly stated sweetness enveloping tart fruit notes. An almost shockingly low price for a Kenya this distinctive and pleasing.

Name: Colombia Nariño Medium Roast
BlindReview: Delicately and richly sweet. Orange marmalade, tea rose, fresh-cut fir, cashew in aroma and cup. Round, bittersweet acidity; full, lightly velvety mouthfeel. Fir and plum predominate in the quietly sweet, slightly drying finish.
Notes: Purchased as whole bean in a 12-ounce foil bag with one-way degassing valve at a Safeway supermarket in northern California. This sample was roasted and packaged at Mr. Espresso’s Oakland, California facility. Mr. Espresso is a San Francisco Bay Area wholesale roaster and espresso parts distributer that slow-roasts its coffees using traditional wood-fired roasting machines. Visit www.mrespresso.com or call 510-287-5200 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a pleasingly accessible, fruit-and-nut-toned Colombia.

Name: Colombian 100% Arabica Medium-Dark Roast
BlindReview: Sweetly and gently pungent, quietly complex. Dark chocolate, cedar, hazelnut, plum in aroma and cup. Round, backgrounded but softly resonant acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Hints of dark chocolate, cedar and plum all linger faintly but persistently in a sweet-toned finish.
Notes: Purchased pre-ground in a 12-ounce foil bag with one-way degassing valve at a Safeway supermarket in northern California. McCafé is a brand of McDonald’s. Visit www.mcdonalds.com/us/en/promotions/mccafe_at_home.html for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those looking for quiet but surprising intrigue at a value price in a supermarket Colombia.

Name: Rwanda Butare
BlindReview: Quiet, sweet-savory. Green apple, brown sugar, cedar, white peppercorn in aroma and cup. Brisk, juicy acidity; plump mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a crisp, dry finish.
Notes: Rwanda’s impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past two decades, owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. Purchased as whole bean in a 12-ounce foil bag with one-way degassing valve at a Whole Foods location in northern California. This sample was roasted and packaged at Toms’ Los Angeles, California facility. The company’s business model includes a donation to charity with every purchase. Visit www.toms.com/coffee for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value a brisk rendition of tart fruit and pungent, peppery cedar notes, as well as coffee drinkers interested in supporting this company’s philanthropic efforts directed toward delivering clean water to those who have none or little.

Name: Tanzania Kikafu Estate Direct Trade Light Roast
BlindReview: Rich, roast-rounded. Baker’s chocolate, hazelnut, fir, brown sugar in aroma and cup. Gentle, balanced acidity; crisp, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavors consolidate in a dry, spicy finish, with chocolate lingering into the long.
Notes: Purchased pre-ground in a 12-ounce foil bag with one-way degassing valve at a Target location in northern California. Offering everything from baked goods to frozen foods, Archer Farms (“Tasty Food Tasty Price”) is a premium foods house brand of the Target Corporation. This coffee is available exclusively at Target stores. Visit www.target.com or call 800-440-0680 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those looking for value and the convenience of a pre-ground coffee that still manages to deliver a quietly distinctive cup.

Name: Colombia Luminosa Light Roast
BlindReview: Mild, sweetly pungent. Apricot, brown sugar, hints of dark chocolate and lily in aroma and cup. Round, backgrounded acidity; plump mouthfeel. Flavor makes a rather faint last stand in a quiet finish.
Notes: Purchased pre-ground in a 12-ounce foil bag with one-way degassing valve at a Safeway supermarket in northern California. This sample was roasted, roast-dated, and packaged at Peet’s Alameda, California facility. Peet’s, now a privately owned corporation under the John A. Benckiser Investment group, has arguably managed to maintain its essential identity during a slow, careful expansion from its original, intensely loyalist base in the San Francisco Bay area. Visit www.peets.com or call 800-999-2132 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: This coffee is considerably lighter roasted than a typical Peet’s coffee. Its gentle pungency and apricot fruit is pleasing, though rather muted.

Name: Big Trouble
BlindReview: Quiet; brisk but sweet. Black tea, almond, elm, bergamot, carob in aroma and cup. Round, backgrounded acidity; full, plush mouthfeel. Citrusy finish in the short, carob and elm in the long.
Notes: Purchased as whole bean in a 12-ounce bag with one-way degassing valve at a Whole Foods location in northern California. This sample was roasted, roast-dated, and packaged at Counter Culture’s Emeryville, California facility. Counter Culture is a specialty roaster with an informative and lively website, a commitment to fine coffee, direct relationships with growers, transparency, and youthful, enthusiastic leadership. Visit www.counterculturecoffee.com or call 888-238-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy an understated balance of sweetness and citrus-and-nut briskness.

Name: 100% Colombian Ground Coffee
BlindReview: Crisply sweet, delicate, balanced but simple. Molasses, raisin, freshly cut fir, a hint of hazelnut in aroma and cup. Crisp, though rather muted, acidity; silky, but very light, mouthfeel. Sweet in the finish, though drying and rather woody.
Notes: Purchased pre-ground in a 12-ounce foil bag with one-way degassing valve at a Safeway supermarket in northern California. Safeway Kitchens is a brand of Safeway. Safeway is the second-largest supermarket chain in the United States, with nearly 2,200 stores in western and central United States and western Canada. Visit www.safeway.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Great price, but not much other reason to buy this sweet-toned but rather listless pre-ground Colombia.

Name: 100% Colombian Medium Roast
BlindReview: Cloying raw nut and vaguely spicy wood dominate in both aroma and cup, with some suggestions of roasted cacao nib and raisin. Simple, bittersweet acidity; syrupy, though rather inert, mouthfeel. Flavor smooths out a bit in the finish, with a little more cacao and raisin and a little less raw nut and wood.
Notes: Purchased pre-ground in a 28-ounce plastic canister with soft, peel-off foil top with inset one-way degassing valve at a Safeway supermarket in northern California. Maxwell House is a brand of Kraft Foods. Visit www.maxwellhousecoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Avoid it.

Name: Kenya Kii
BlindReview: Crisply sweet and spicy. Blackberry, sandalwood, ripe tomato and cocoa in aroma and cup. Juicy, balanced acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor saturates the sweet, long, resonant finish.
Notes: Despite challenges ranging from unclear government coffee policy and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands to chronically unstable weather, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world’s most elegant and distinctive coffees. With two locations in Southern California’s Orange County, Kéan Coffee is an in-house coffee roaster and retailer established by Martin Diedrich of the distinguished Diedrich coffee family. The Kéan slogan, “Martin knows his beans,” should be true, considering Martin grew up in Guatemala where his family owned a coffee farm.Visit www.keancoffee.com or call 949-933-9164 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a classic Kenya cup with pleasingly balanced chocolate and fruit notes.

Name: Congo Sopacdi
Origin: Kalehe, South Kivu region, Democratic Republic of the Congo
BlindReview: Richly and deeply sweet. Molasses, baker’s chocolate, passion fruit, oak and gardenia in aroma and cup. Crisply sweet, lively acidity; light, silky mouthfeel. Passion fruit notes carry into the resonantly sweet and quietly tart finish.
Notes: The Kivu region of the Democratic Republic of the Congo has very recently established itself as a source of specialty coffee with the development of cooperatives like Sopacdi. Overlooking Lake Kivu, on the opposite side of the lake from Rwanda, this rapidly growing cooperative now has 5,600 members and apparently is succeeding its goal to help heal the wounds left by the latest in eastern Congo’s seemingly endless string of horrific rebellions and civil wars. With two locations in Southern California’s Orange County, Kéan Coffee is an in-house coffee roaster and retailer established by Martin Diedrich of the distinguished Diedrich coffee family. The Kéan slogan, “Martin knows his beans,” should be true, considering Martin grew up in Guatemala where his family owned a coffee farm. Visit www.keancoffee.com or call 949-933-9164 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who are interested in experiencing a sweet and zesty coffee from a newly revived and hopeful growing region.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Dry Process
BlindReview: Sweet, deep, complexly fruit-toned. Tangerine, plum, fresh tobacco, hints of brandy and lily in aroma and cup. Round, resonant acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a sweet, cleanly brandy-toned finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or “washed” coffees. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. GreenAlives is a small-batch roasting company located in the Taishan District of New Taipei City, Taiwan that pursues quality in every act of coffee production from green coffee selection through storage, roasting and educating customers in optimum brewing practice. Visit www.greenalives.com or call +886-0921-884-579 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value the older style of big, fruit- and brandy-toned dry-processed or “natural” coffees: juicy but clean.

Name: Mi’s Blend
BlindReview: Sweetly and gently bright, quietly intricate. Orange, cedar, roasted cacao nib, jasmine in aroma and cup. Delicate, graceful acidity; light, silky mouthfeel. Orange and jasmine in particular carry into a sweet-toned, surprisingly resonant finish.
Notes: A blend of natural Ethiopia, washed Panama and honey-processed Costa Rica coffee beans. Mi’s Cafe is an in-store roaster and coffee shop in Kaohsiung City, Taiwan. For more information, call 886-7-2010188, email [email protected] or visit www.facebook.com/MISCOFFEE.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value purity and delicately exhilarating complexity in an aptly named blend.

Name: DanCeing Blend
BlindReview: Softly crisp, round, resonant. Honey, rose, blackberry, hazelnut in aroma and cup. Sweetly brisk, berry-toned acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Berry notes carry into a sweet, quietly rich finish.
Notes: A blend of coffee beans from Tanzania and Honduras. DanCeing Coffee was named after two Chinese words, “??” ("Dan-Ceing”), after a former prison factory in Ping-Tung County, located in southern Taiwan, in which the roastery is housed. For more information, call 886-8-7785635, [email protected] or visit www.shop.moj.gov.tw.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A comfortable coffee, brisk but sweet and honey-toned.

Name: Kenya AA Nyeri Tambaya
BlindReview: Delicately sweet and savory. Meyer lemon, blackcurrant, geranium, cedar and black tea in aroma and cup. Sweetly crisp, resonant acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Dark chocolate and raisin consolidate in a deep, long finish.
Notes: Despite challenges ranging from unclear government coffee policy and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands to chronically unstable weather, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world’s most elegant and distinctive coffees. This Kenya was produced by the Tambaya wet mill, a member of the Rumukia Farmer’s Co-op Society, from trees of the admired SL28 and SL34 varieties. AA is the highest grade of Kenya coffee based on bean size and fewest physical imperfections. Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious coffee and high-quality coffee. Visit redroostercoffee.com or call 540-745-7338 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who appreciate a sweet, but also deeply savory, classic Kenya cup.

Name: Costa Rica Las Lajas Red Honey
Origin: Sabanilla de Alajuela growing region, Costa Rica
BlindReview: Delicate and sweet. Caramel, tangerine, lavender and sandalwood in aroma and cup. Crisply sweet acidity; buoyant, silky-smooth mouthfeel. Balanced and elegantly dry, flavor-saturated finish dominated by tangerine in the short and sandalwood in the long.
Notes: Produced from trees of the respected Catuai and Caturra varieties of Arabica at Calle Liles Farm and processed by the red honey method, meaning the beans were dried with 100% of the fruit flesh still adhering to the beans. Certified organic. Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious coffee and high-quality coffee. Visit redroostercoffee.com or call 540-745-7338 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy deeply sweet, citrus-toned coffees with exotic wood and floral aromas.

Name: Rwanda Kabirizi Organic
Origin: Lake Kivu, Nyamyumba growing region, Rwanda
BlindReview: Delicately sweet, deeply savory. Tea rose, honey, violet, almond in aroma and cup. Round, fruit-toned acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Honey and tea rose carry into the rich, deeply resonant finish.
Notes: Rwanda’s impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. Processed at the Kabirizi washing station, part of the COOPAC co-op. Certified organic. Established in 2010, Red Rooster is an organic-certified micro-roaster focusing on socially conscious coffee and high-quality coffee. Visit redroostercoffee.com or call 540-745-7338 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value a balance of sweet and savory tones in a lush, complex central Africa coffee.

Name: Ethiopia Adado Natural
BlindReview: Richly and sweetly pungent. Apricot, hazelnut, roasted cacao nib and freesia-like flowers in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; smooth, satiny mouthfeel. The gently drying finish is redolent of hazelnut with a hint of cacao nib.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. This is a dry-processed or “natural” Yirgacheffe, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or “washed” coffees. Lone Oak Coffee Company’s seven values — relationships, family, community, integrity, quality, education, and responsibility — inform its decisions about coffee from bean to cup. For more information, call 540-905-8991 or visit www.loneoakcoffee.com.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who like a classic dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia that is fruit-forward on the nose and palate and moves toward nutty chocolate tones in the finish.

Name: Six-Shooter Kenya AA
BlindReview: Sweet and savory. Raisin, fir, pecan and ripe tomato in aroma and cup. Lively, tart acidity; plump, round mouthfeel. Hints of roasted cacao nib in the richly drying finish, with ripe tomato resurfacing in the long.
Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world’s most elegant and distinctive coffees. AA is the highest grade of Kenya coffee based on bean size and fewest physical imperfections. Montana Cowboy Coffee was founded by Bob Arnot, MD, as a tribute to his father and grandparents who were early pioneers in the state. Using liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry analysis, the company strives to produce coffees with the highest possible health benefits by sourcing and roasting coffees with high levels of anti-inflammatory compounds. For more information, visit www.montanacowboycoffee.com or Amazon.com.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who appreciate an accessible Kenya that is equal parts sweet and savory.

Name: S.O. Espresso Guatemala Concepcion Buena Vista
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Bold, chocolaty and citrus-toned. Tangerine, sandalwood, lily and savory chocolate in aroma and cup. Plump, creamy mouthfeel; chocolate and tangerine persist in a pleasingly tart finish.
Notes: This coffee is a blend of beans from trees of the Caturra and Bourbon varieties, produced by Bernardo Solano, a third-generation farmer of the Concepcion Buena Vista family farm. It is a wet-processed or “washed” coffee, meaning that the fruit skin and pulp were removed before drying. Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those interested in breaking out of the classic espresso mode and into a compelling “New American” rendition animated by a complex play of savory chocolate, floral and citrus.

Name: Panama Geisha
BlindReview: Roast-toned and floral. Singed oak, pomegranate, lavender, baker’s chocolate in aroma and cup. Quiet, juicy acidity; plump, syrupy mouthfeel. Hints of lavender and cocoa in the gently drying finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also spelled Geisha). With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s most unique coffees. This is a wet-processed or “washed” version, meaning the fruit skin and pulp were removed from the beans immediately after harvesting and before drying. San Francisco Bay is one of five coffee brands produced by the family-owned Rogers Family Company. Visit www.sfbaycoffee.com or call 800-829-1300 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Anyone interested in the rare opportunity to sample a very successful dark-roasted Gesha at an excellent value.

Name: Special Reserve Hard Core
Origin: Hambela District, Oromia growing region, southern Ethiopia
BlindReview: Subtly sweet, rich, enlivened by tart fruit notes. Pie cherry, lavender, dried basil, hazelnut butter in aroma and cup. Juicy, tart acidity; full, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Baker’s chocolate surfaces in a richly drying finish.
Notes: Oromia is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This lot was processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying). Southern Ethiopia coffees processed with this method typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity, with a particular emphasis on floral notes. Dr. Danger Coffee was founded by Bob Arnot, MD, a veteran of relief work in Africa and a long-time health correspondent for NBC and CBS. Using liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry analysis, the company strives to produce coffees with the highest possible health benefits by sourcing and roasting coffees with high levels of anti-inflammatory compounds. Visit drdangercoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value wet-processed Ethiopia coffees with a pleasing balance of sweet and tart tones animated by hints of herb and lavender.

Name: Special Reserve Surgical Strike
BlindReview: Delicately sweet, nutty. Caramel, honeysuckle, walnut, fir in aroma and cup. Juicy, rounded acidity; satiny-smooth mouthfeel. Graceful, sweet finish redolent of cacao nib in the short and walnut in the long.
Notes: This is a blend of coffee beans sourced from East Africa and Brazil. Dr. Danger Coffee was founded by Bob Arnot, MD, a veteran of relief work in Africa and a long-time health correspondent for NBC and CBS. Using liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry analysis, the company strives to produce coffees with the highest possible health benefits by sourcing and roasting coffees with high levels of anti-inflammatory compounds. Visit www.drdangercoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who appreciate a sweet, nut-toned coffee with caramel and quietly intricate floral complication.

Name: Ethiopia Hambela Natural
Origin: Hambela District, Oromia growing region, southern Ethiopia
BlindReview: Delicate and immaculately sweet. Dried blueberry, almond, white tea, lilac in aroma and cup. Balanced, juicy acidity; velvety-smooth mouthfeel. Quietly resonant finish, fruity throughout and sweetly nutty in the long.
Notes: Oromia is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or “washed” coffees. Mojo Coffee is a New Orleans-based roaster specializing in ethically sourced, hand-sorted and small-batch-roasted coffees. It strives to highlight the innate sweetness and unique flavor characteristics of each coffee and focuses on ensuring consistency from seed to cup.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a beautifully structured, fruit-forward and floral natural-processed Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Harrar Mesela
BlindReview: Richly and deeply sweet. Molasses, dark chocolate, Asian pear and narcissus in aroma and cup. Bittersweet acidity; silky mouthfeel. Nut leads at the front of the short, richly drying finish.
Notes: The semi-arid highlands near the ancient east-Ethiopian walled city of Harrar has long produced traditional dried-in-the fruit or “natural” coffees like this one. Caffè Luxxe is an Italian-inflected artisan roaster and retailer that emphasizes both its coffee knowledge and precision and its straightforward lack of pretension. Visit www.caffeluxxe.com or call 310-394-2222 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who appreciate crisp fruit in a chocolaty and subtly floral cup representing an ancient but rarely imported Ethiopian regional coffee type.

Name: Nicaragua Santa Lucila Maracaturra
BlindReview: Complete; delicately sweet and intricately structured. Tart, juicy acidity; buoyant, syrupy mouthfeel. Lemon zest, almond, butterscotch, rosemary flower in aroma and cup. Zesty, bittersweet finish in the short with a subtle flourish of spicy flowers in the long.
Notes: Maracaturra is a cross between the workhorse compact-growing variety Caturra (itself a mutant of the heirloom Bourbon) and the rare, huge-beaned Maragogipe, making it a parallel variety to the better-known Pacamara, a cross between Maragogipe and Pacas (also a mutant selection of Bourbon). This is a wet-processed or “washed” coffee, meaning the fruit skin and pulp were removed from the beans immediately after harvesting and before drying. Beneficio de Cafe Santa Lucila was the first wet/dry mill in the Nueva Segovia region, established in 1960. It is owned and operated by the three generations of the Paguaga family. Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy an invigoratingly tart cup complicated by a sweet zing of lemon zest and herby floral notes.

Name: Ethiopia Adado Sulula Natural
BlindReview: Elaborately rich and fruit-forward. Ripe strawberry, sandalwood, violet-like flowers and a hint of rye whisky in aroma and cup. Richly and roundly tart acidity; velvety mouthfeel. Long, clean finish is saturated with strawberry and sandalwood.
Notes: Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are produced from traditional Ethiopian varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is less predictable and deeper than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned southern Ethiopia profile. Like virtually all Yirgacheffe coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. ChacolaTAY is a Taiwanese small-batch roaster aiming to maximize cup character of elite green coffees through flexible, precise artisan roasting. Visit http://chacolatay.com or call 886-935-730422 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy equal parts fruit and spicy pungency in a fine dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia coffee.

Name: Bernachon Panama Geisha
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Bright, juicy, tropical. Pineapple, passion fruit, rose-like flowers, musk, a backgrounded dark chocolate in aroma and small cup. Satiny mouthfeel. Chocolate and tart fruit carry into a richly drying finish. Crisp, still juicy, and deeply and subtly nuanced in three parts milk.
Notes: From trees of the Geisha (also spelled Gesha) variety planted on the slopes of Volcan Baru in the Boquete growing region of Panama at elevations between 5,000 and 5,700 feet, where trees of this celebrated variety are said to have first been established in Panama, brought from Costa Rica in 1898 by Don Enrique Vasquez. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty, cup, the Geisha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world’s unique coffees. Wei Chuan Foods Corporation is an international food-science corporation. This coffee is a production of its specialty beverages research and development program. Visit www.weichuan.com.tw/ or call +866-0800-021-007 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Crisply dry yet sweetly lush, deep, intricate, a splendid and remarkably versatile espresso in the newer style.

Name: Bernachon B123 Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly crisp, but round. Vanilla, spicy-rich cedar, lily-like flowers, brisk cranberry in aroma and small cup. Full, creamy mouthfeel; sweet-toned cedar and chocolate notes carry into a rich finish. Crisply savory-sweet and redolent of cedar and sage in three parts milk.
Notes: Wei Chuan Foods Corporation is an international food-science corporation. This coffee is a production of its specialty beverages research and development program. Visit www.weichuan.com.tw/ or call +866-0800-021-007 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a spicy Central America espresso with appealing aromatic wood notes.

Name: Bernachon M425 Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Rich and deep with floral top notes. Caramel, carob, cedar, lily in aroma and small cup. Full, syrupy, though rather dry mouthfeel; lily and cedar, in particular, carry into a crisp, balanced finish. Carob, cedar and a hint of flowers in three parts milk.
Notes: Wei Chuan Foods Corporation is an international food-science corporation. This coffee is a production of its specialty beverages research and development program. Visit www.weichuan.com.tw/ or call +866-0800-021-007 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value a crisply focused espresso blend with subtly persistent floral top-notes carrying from aroma through milk.

Name: Bernachon Arabica Mangkuraja Grade 1 Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Deep, cedary and chocolaty. Dark chocolate, fresh-cut cedar, moist tobacco, a hint of lily-like flowers in aroma and small cup. Lean but smooth mouthfeel. Cedar dominates in a dry finish. Crisply dry chocolate nuanced by lily and fresh tobacco in three parts milk.
Notes: Wei Chuan Foods Corporation is an international food-science corporation. This coffee is a production of its specialty beverages research and development program. Visit www.weichuan.com.tw/ or call +866-0800-021-007 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: An unusual espresso from southern Sumatra for coffee adventurers. Dry, a little salty, but rich with cedar, chocolate and lily notes.

Name: Ecuador Nestor Nino
BlindReview: Sweet and delicately rich. Strawberry, almond, honeysuckle, cedar in aroma and cup. Crisp, balanced acidity; buoyant, velvety mouthfeel. Berry and nut flavors resonate in a richly drying finish.
Notes: Produced by Nestor Nino at his farm, San Alejo and comprised entirely of beans from trees of the unusual and impressive Sidra variety of arabica, a cultivar specific to Ecuador. It is a washed coffee, meaning that the skin and fruit pulp were removed or “washed” from the beans before they were dried. Ghost Town is a small-batch roaster, wholesaler, equipment supplier and training resource located in Bozeman, Montana that takes great care in responsibly sourcing top-quality specialty coffees. Visit www.ghosttowncoffee.com call 406-586-0777 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who appreciate rich coffees that strike a graceful, even lyric, balance between sweet and savory.

Name: Ethiopia Ayele Dula
BlindReview: Delicately sweet yet resonantly deep. Honey, peach, almond, gardenia-like flowers in aroma and cup. Crisp, juicy acidity; silky-smooth mouthfeel. Balanced and richly drying finish, with peach notes in the short and roasted cacao nib in the long.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. From Dhudhufa farm, a member of the Yirgacheffe Coffee Farmers Cooperative Union (YCFCU). Bloom Coffee Roasters is a hands-on, community-focused micro-roaster in Lansing, Michigan. Visit .com or call 886-935-730422 for more information. Visit www.bloomroasters.com for further information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value an aromatically compelling wet-processed Ethiopia, peachy and floral in front, with crisp nut undertones.

Name: Finca San Luis Colombia
BlindReview: Complex and deeply sweet. Apricot, dark chocolate, hazelnut, narcissus, an Oolong tea suggestion in aroma and cup. Juicy, gently tart acidity; plush, syrupy mouthfeel. Cocoa-toned and savory in the short finish, richly drying in the long.
Notes: Farmer Omar Arango is a member of the Cafinorte Orgánico Coop and processes his coffees at his own mill located on the grounds of Finca San Luis. This is a washed coffee, meaning that the skin and fruit pulp were removed or “washed” from the beans before they were dried. Chocolate Fish is a distinguished New-Zealand-inspired micro-roaster based in Sacramento California, focused on the best in both quality and integrity.Visit www.chocolatefishcoffee.com or call 916-451-5181 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a crisp, juicy Colombia with chocolate throughout and a pleasing and surprising Oolong tea note.

Name: Finca Merced Guatemala
BlindReview: Crisply sweet, cocoa-toned. Cocoa, baked apple, vanilla bean, elm in aroma and slightly savory cup. Gently rounded acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Baked apple and elm carry into a sweet-savory finish.
Notes: Produced by the Ortega family entirely from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. This is a wet-processed or “washed” coffee, meaning the fruit skin and pulp were removed from the beans immediately after harvesting and before drying. Chocolate Fish is a distinguished New-Zealand-inspired micro-roaster based in Sacramento California, focused on the best in both quality and integrity.Visit www.chocolatefishcoffee.com or call 916-451-5181 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: The slightly savory, baked apple edge makes an argument for a place on the holiday table for this resonant Guatemala Bourbon.

Name: Ethiopia Suke Quto Pulped Natural Lot
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Sidamo growing region, south-central Ethiopia
BlindReview: Spicy, sweet, subtly intricate. Dark chocolate, lavender, sandalwood, pink peppercorn in aroma and cup. Tart but profoundly sweet acidity; satiny mouthfeel. Chocolate and lavender carry far into a richly sweet finish.
Notes: Certified organically grown. Southern Ethiopia coffees like this one are produced from traditional Ethiopian varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This version is processed by the pulped natural or “honey” method, in which the skin is removed from the coffee fruit immediately after picking, but the seeds or beans are dried with all or part of the sweet pulp, or fruit flesh, still adhering to them. Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Unusual honey processing promotes remarkable delicacy and crisply sweet balance in this complex, silky Ethiopia.

Name: Panama La Esmeralda Geisha Bosque Natural
