BlindReview: Complex, deep, pungent. Black currant and blackberry; opulent flowers; dark chocolate; hints of fresh herb – black sage, cilantro – in aroma and cup. Powerful, richly tart acidity; plush mouthfeel. Sweet, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Despite grower discontent and sporadic social disorder, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy big, intense coffees expressing great range in structure and aromatics, from sweet flowers through complex fruit to savory hints of herb.

Name: Lift Off Espresso
Origin: Minas Gerais State, Brazil; West Valley growing region, Costa Rica.
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Richly fruit-toned, roundly bright. Cantaloupe, apricot, buttery dark chocolate, fresh-cut cedar, a hint of honeysuckle in aroma and small cup. Lightly syrupy mouthfeel; flowers carry into a crisp finish. Rather bright and dry in three parts milk but impressively nuanced: chocolate, apricot, cedar, all lingering in an impressively long, sweet finish.
Notes: This blend consists of a honey-processed Daterra Estate Brazil peaberry and a wet-processed or “washed” coffee from the Helsar de Zarcero Mill in Costa Rica. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A classic espresso in the newer American style: bright but deep, sweet, complex.

Name: Costa Rica Helsar Manuel Macho Arce
Origin: West Valley growing region, Costa Rica.
BlindReview: Sweet-toned, quietly lyric. Brown sugar, carob, rose-like flowers, almond, hints of tangerine and cumin in aroma and cup. Round, gentle acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Quietly flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Named after the micro-mill Helsar de Zarcero in the West Valley of Costa Rica, this coffee is made up entirely of the Caturra variety of Arabica and comes from a segregated lot of farmer Manuel “Macho” Arce’s production. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy grace and subtle originality in a gentle, syrupy cup.

Name: El Guamal Colombia
BlindReview: Very sweet, delicately rich. Cane sugar, lilac, hazelnut, fresh-cut oak, a hint of honeydew-melon-like fruit in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Floral and fruit hints in particular carry into a quiet, balanced finish.
Notes: This coffee was produced by farmer Tomas Maria Vargas, and was auctioned as part of “Antioquia’s Best Cup 2014” program. JBC Coffee Roasters was founded in 1994 as Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters and is a family-owned specialty coffee roastery located in Madison, Wisconsin. JBC Coffee Roasters’ vision is simple: “let the coffee lead the way” through sourcing and roasting the best and most unique coffees available and rewarding the farmers who grow those coffees with substantial premiums. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a delicate but sweet and brightly lively breakfast cup.

Name: Sumatra Ulos Batak
BlindReview: Extraordinarily intense and complexly aromatic coffee. Pungent fruit (grapefruit, black currant); moist pipe tobacco and sweet, freshly turned clay; molasses and chocolate fudge. Round, quietly vibrant acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Richly sweet, powerfully flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #2 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2014.  Coffees from the northern part of the Indonesian island of Sumatra are admired for their complex earth and fruit notes that appear to result largely from unorthodox fruit removal and drying practices called “wet hulling.” This is a particularly refined example of the type. Based in the San Diego area, Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler focused on organic and socially responsible coffees; it was awarded the “2012 Roaster of the Year” title from Roast Magazine. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A Sumatra both refined and intense; those many lovers of the Sumatra type should not miss this one; purists who still remain suspicious of the type should find this example both familiar (the pungent fruit is almost Kenya-like) yet original: pipe tobacco, clay, richly fudgy chocolate.

Name: Washed Yirgacheffe
Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Delicately intense; layered complexity. Candied lemon, peach, kiwi, roasted cacao nib, a hint of spice (cardamom, saffron) in aroma and cup. Soft but crisply lively acidity; very silky mouthfeel. Sweet, deeply flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: This is Lot #21 of this year’s production from the Alemu Washing station in Kochere. Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity, often with a particular emphasis on floral and citrus notes. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Based in the San Diego area, Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler focused on organic and socially responsible coffees; it was awarded the “2012 Roaster of the Year” title from Roast Magazine. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A superb Yirgacheffe with emphasis on sweetly tart, complexly expressed fruit notes given depth and crispness by suggestions of cacao nib and spice.

Name: Espresso Blend
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Well-structured, complete, balanced. Dark chocolate, richly aromatic cedar, apricot, tangerine, a hint of honeysuckle in aroma and small cup. Very smooth, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate carries into a drying but richly sweet finish. Flavor predictably softens but carries with delicate complexity into three parts milk.
Notes: Revel Coffee is a quality focused micro-roaster located in Billings, Montana. Its motto: “Quality is paramount – a difference you can revel in." Visit www.revelcoffee.com or call 406-534-9621 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: No grand gestures here, but a remarkably consistent and balanced espresso: delicately chocolaty, a hint of fruit and flowers, full and satiny in mouthfeel, all carrying persuasively into cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Aricha
BlindReview: Very sweet, brandy-toned. Black cherry, brandy, rose-like flowers, ripe orangy citrus in aroma and cup. Juicy, vivacious acidity; syrupy but lively mouthfeel. Cherry and floral notes carry into a sweet-toned though rather short, drying finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is less predictable and deeper than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned Yirgacheffe profile. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Revel Coffee is a quality focused micro-roaster located in Billings, Montana. Its motto: “Quality is paramount – a difference you can revel in.” Visit www.revelcoffee.com or call 406-534-9621 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Classically big, juicy, brandy-toned dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia for those many coffee drinkers who love the style.

Name: Kenya Kikai
BlindReview: Sweetly and deeply pungent; intense but balanced. Peach, plum, black currant, narcissus-like flowers, fresh-cut elm in aroma and cup. Crisply sweet, nuanced acidity; silky, buoyant mouthfeel. Flowers in particular saturate a rich, resonant finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #9 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2014. From the slopes of Mt. Elgon in far western Kenya rather than from the more familiar growing regions of central Kenya. Produced by the nearly 2,000 very small-holding members of the Kikai cooperative. Founded in 1990, Lexington Coffee is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Virginia. Lexington’s focus on fresh, flavorful and sustainable coffee is reflected in its motto, “Fresh, Flavorful & Fair.” Visit www.lexingtoncoffee.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Classic Kenya; almost perfectly structured and finely nuanced around sweetly tart fruit and fragrant floral suggestions.

Name: Guatemala ASDECAFE
BlindReview: Quiet but vibrant. Caramel, roasted cacao nib, fresh-cut oak, orangy citrus, musk in aroma and cup. Gentle but crisply lively acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Round, quietly flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: ASDECAFE is the Spanish acronym for the Sustainable Coffee Association of Guatemala, an organization with a membership including several cooperatives and other organizations in western Guatemala. Founded in 1990, Lexington Coffee is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Virginia. Lexington’s focus on fresh, flavorful and sustainable coffee is reflected in its motto, “Fresh, Flavorful & Fair.”  Visit www.lexingtoncoffee.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer a gentle but lively and engaging breakfast cup.

Name: Ethiopia Kochere
Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Balanced; delicate but rich. Honey, lilac, fresh-cut cedar, roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup. Brisk acidity; light but silky mouthfeel. Flowers in particular carry into a sweet though drying finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on floral notes. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Founded in 1990, Lexington Coffee is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Virginia. Lexington’s focus on fresh, flavorful and sustainable coffee is reflected in its motto, “Fresh, Flavorful & Fair.” Visit www.lexingtoncoffee.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a delicately lively, briskly floral- and honey-toned cup.

Name: Rwanda Hinga Kawa
BlindReview: Soft, rich, deep. Complex floral-related notes (honeysuckle, rose, vanilla, peach) lead, particularly in the cup, with complicating hints of earthy, strawberry-like fruit and walnut. Pronounced but gentle acidity; plush, silky mouthfeel. Floral notes profoundly saturate a sweet-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by the Hinga Kawa Women’s Association of the Abakundakawa Cooperative from trees of the heirloom Red Bourbon variety of Arabica. Victrola is a small-batch, hands-on roaster with a passionate commitment to quality and distinctiveness. Visit www.victrolacoffee.com or call 206-624-1725 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: This sweet, deep, floral-toned cup, particularly characteristic of the best Rwandas, should please those who enjoy a pure but exotically complex coffee.

Name: Mexico CESMACH FTO
BlindReview: A slightly rough, but profoundly sweet and quite chocolaty cup. Brown sugar, dark chocolate, hints of lily, green grape and peach in aroma and cup. Round, backgrounded acidity; lightly but distinctly syrupy mouthfeel. Sweet, long, chocolate-toned finish.
Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Produced by Campesinos Ecológicos de la Sierra Madre de Chiapas (CESMACH), a coop located within the buffer zone of El Triunfo Biosphere Reserve, one of the world’s most diverse forest reserves, the integrity of which CESMACH supports through shade-growing and other sustainable practices. Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer richness, resonance and chocolate to purity and brightness in a lighter roasted coffee. Good environmental and socio-economic credentials.

Name: Burundi Mpanga
BlindReview: Rich, deep, sweet-savory. Caramel, fresh-cut fir, pineapple, pear, a hint of honeysuckle in aroma and cup. Crisp, pleasantly bittersweet acidity; plush mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists in a very rich finish.
Notes: Produced at the high-elevation Mpanga washing station or wet mill from trees of the heirloom Red Bourbon variety of Arabica. Victrola is a small-batch, hands-on roaster with a passionate commitment to quality and distinctiveness. Visit www.victrolacoffee.com or call 206-624-1725 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a very sweet cup deepened by a savory edge.

Name: Mexican Vera Cruz Finca Kassandra
BlindReview: Sweet but crisply dry throughout the profile. Sweet plum and night-blooming flowers complemented by pine and caraway seed in aroma and cup. Backgrounded acidity; very lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but lasts in a sweet but gently drying finish.
Notes: This lot is comprised entirely of the much admired, bold-bean Pacamara variety of Arabica, a cross between the giant-beaned Maragogipe variety and Pacas, a selection of the heirloom Bourbon. Finca Kassandra, established in 1996 by the Rivas family, is located in the central region of the Mexican State of Veracruz near Totutla and Huatusco. Of the finca's 600 hectares, about 320 are dedicated to coffee production, and of the coffee production, 8% is Pacamara, which is separated and milled carefully. Just Love Coffee Roasters is a small-batch roaster located in Murfreesboro Tennessee; its mission is to develop the unique qualities inherent in each coffee bean and to be equally passionate about helping those in need.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy sweetly dry, slightly savory beverages, in this case complicated by some unusual aromatic intrigue.

Name: Las Margaritas Colombia Gesha
BlindReview: Quietly rich, distinctive. Brisk notes of fine black tea and fresh-cut cedar balanced by considerable sweetness: honeysuckle, ripe apricot, vanilla. Crisp, pleasantly bittersweet acidity; light, silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but lasts in a gently drying finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare (and expensive) Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also spelled Geisha). Las Margaritas Gesha was produced without the use of pesticides, herbicides or synthetic fertilizers. Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast. Visit www.barringtoncoffee.com or call 800-528-0998 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: The unusual juxtaposition of brisk, cedary black tea notes with lush ripe fruit and floral sweetness is original and attractive.

Name: El Diamante Huehuetenango Guatemala
Origin: Agua Dulce, Huehuetenango growing region, Guatemala.
BlindReview: Sweetly pungent, very deep, quietly complex. Sweet dark chocolate, clove, prune, hints of grapefruit and musky night flowers in aroma and cup. Soft but vibrant acidity; plush mouthfeel. Chocolate in particular carries into a very long, resonant finish.
Notes: El Diamante is produced by Patricia Perez Diaz and her mother on their family farm. Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast. Visit www.barringtoncoffee.com or call 800-528-0998 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy resonant depth and spicy, musky chocolate.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kore Kochore
BlindReview: Pungent, deeply flavor-saturated. Honey, blood orange, black currant, rhododendron-like flowers in aroma and cup. Richly tart acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but carries far into a pungent, sweet-toned finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on floral notes. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A deep, resonant version of the great floral and citrus Yirgacheffe cup.

Name: Sombra del Poro Costa Rica
BlindReview: Crisp, soft, sweet-toned. Dark chocolate, fresh-cut fir, plum, a hint of musk in aroma and cup. Gentle, balanced acidity; plush, satiny mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a sweet-toned though simple finish.
Notes: This coffee (Sombra del Poro or Shade of the Poro) takes its name from the Poro trees under which it is largely grown. It is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee. Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A relaxed, balanced, straightforward breakfast cup.

Name: SO Espresso Brazil Fazenda Rainha Natural
Origin: Mogiana Region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Opulent, sweet, carnal. Brown sugar, fresh-cut cedar, rich chocolate, apricot, cinnamon, a hint of narcissus-like flowers in aroma and small cup. Full, syrupy mouthfeel. Flowers, chocolate and cinnamon in particular saturate a crisp finish. Flavor softens but carries relatively intact into three parts milk.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #22 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2014. The term natural means this coffee was dried inside the entire fruit rather than after the fruit was removed. Most Brazil coffee is dried inside the fruit, but this natural Brazil shows a particularly ripe fruit character not typical for Brazil versions of the type. Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: The intriguingly lush, complex flavor profile should appeal to enthusiasts and casual espresso drinkers alike. This is a forgiving espresso that produces a successful shot at a variety of parameters, making it an attractive choice for beginners.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe Reko
Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Intense yet delicate. Chocolate, tangerine, papaya, honeysuckle, a hint of bourbon-style whisky in aroma and cup. Sweetly brisk, buoyant acidity; silky, lively mouthfeel. Floral notes in particular carry into a gently rich finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is rounder and lower-toned than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned Yirgacheffe profile. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Reko is a small wet mill or washing station located in the Kochere region. Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A fine example of the latest style of Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit cup: the fruit delicately lush and clean, the flowers sweet and exhilarating, the whisky-like hint enlivening but discreet.

Name: Summit Premium Espresso Blend
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Deep, syrupy. Buttery dark chocolate, lush night-blooming flowers, tangerine, fresh-cut cedar in aroma and small cup. Full, syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor, particularly flowers, saturates a sweet finish. In three parts milk, flavor consolidates around a crisp, flower-and-fruit-nuanced chocolate.
Notes: This espresso blend consists of 80% Arabica and 20% Robusta. Fieldheads Coffee is a small-batch wholesale and Internet retail roaster that roasts specialty grade coffee only on order.  Visit www.fieldheadscoffee.com or call 406-261-8206 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Neither a bright, crisp espresso in the new American style nor a fruit-and-chocolate Italian-style blend; rather, nicely situated between. The persistent floral and ripe citrus notes energize a cedarish chocolate.

Name: Regular Coffee
Origin: Inza Municipality, Cauca Province, southwestern Colombia.
BlindReview: Soft, crisp, quietly complete. Caramel, hazelnut, raspberry-like fruit, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Gentle but lively acidity; lightly though distinctly syrupy mouthfeel. Raspberry in particular carries into a quietly flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Regular Coffee is a specialty coffee company based in Grand Rapids, Michigan that specializes in bringing consumers a good cup of coffee at a good price without fuss, hyperbole or fancy packaging. The tall 24-ounce can wrapped in a kraft paper label with plain black lettering drives the point home. Regular sells its coffees on a no-commitment subscription basis. The purchase price includes shipping.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A balanced, versatile, satisfying cup. And given that shipping is included, a good value.

Name: Organic Colombia El Roble
BlindReview: Sweet-toned, round, resonant. Peach, almond, fresh-cut cedar, rhododendron-like flowers in aroma and cup. Roundly brisk acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but gently persists in a sweet-toned though drying finish.
Notes: El Roble (Oak Tree) Estate is owned and operated in exemplary fashion by Oswaldo Acevedo. Coffee is grown under full shade and processed by the traditional ferment-and-wash method. Certified organically grown. Weed control is manual and all agricultural inputs are generated on the farm or neighboring farms. Produced from a mix of traditional varieties of Arabica. Allegro Coffee, a subsidiary of Whole Foods Market, offers one of the country's largest selections of single-origin coffees. Visit www.allegrocoffee.com or call 800-227-1107 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer depth and resonance to brightness and drama in a balanced breakfast cup.

Name: Papua New Guinea
Origin: Wahgi Valley, Western Highlands, Papua New Guinea.
BlindReview: Delicate, quiet, exotic. Grapefruit, dark chocolate, molasses, vanilla, a hint of pink peppercorn in aroma and cup. Quiet, backgrounded acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Grapefruit and molasses in particular carry into a sweet-toned, balanced finish.
Notes: The high mountain valleys of central Papua New Guinea offer some of the world's most favorable terroirs for production of fine coffee, although the rugged terrain presents daunting transportation and infrastructure challenges. This Papua New Guinea is grown by small holders and processed at a central mill in the heart of the western highlands. Revel Coffee is a micro-roaster located in Billings, Montana. Its motto: “Quality is paramount – a difference you can revel in.” Visit www.revelcoffee.com or call 406-534-9621 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A quiet cup with pleasing aromatics built around grapefruity citrus and a molasses-inflected chocolate. A good choice for those who enjoy a relaxed, accessible, but still original and engaging cup.

Name: Sulawesi Toarco Jaya
Origin: Toraja growing region, south-central Sulawesi, Indonesia.
BlindReview: Tartly sweet, pungent, complex. Halvah-like honey and nut, plum, suggestions of pine and honeysuckle in aroma and cup. Round but vibrant acidity; satiny mouthfeel. Hints of honey, nut and flowers carry into a sweet-toned, balanced finish.
Notes: Toarco (TOraja ARabica COffee) is a coffee project in the famous Sulawesi coffee growing region of Toraja developed and financed by Japan's Key Coffee Company and its Indonesian partners. Toarco coffees are processed by variants of the orthodox wet or washed method, giving them a brighter and cleaner profile than Sulawesi coffees processed by the locally traditional wet-hulling method. Until recently Toarco sold its entire production to the Japanese market, making this coffee rare in the United States. Topéca Coffee is an artisan roaster with three café locations and a roastery in Tulsa, Oklahoma.Visit www.topecacoffee.com or call 918-398-8022 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy pungently sweet beverages.

Name: Papua New Guinea Baroida
Origin: Eastern Highlands Province, Papua New Guinea
BlindReview: Delicate, pungent, subtly original. Dark honey, ripe grapefruit, orchid-like flowers, a hint of cinnamon in aroma and cup. Brisk, juicy acidity; light but silky mouthfeel. The grapefruit notes carries into a crisp, continued juicy finish.
Notes: Established in the 1960’s by Ben Colbran and now in its third generation of family ownership, Baroida is one of the few genuine single-estate coffees still produced in Papua New Guinea. Despite spectacularly rugged terrain that presents daunting transportation and infrastructure challenges, the high mountain valleys of central Papua New Guinea offer some of the world's most favorable terroirs for production of fine coffee. Allegro Coffee, a subsidiary of Whole Foods Market, offers one of the country's largest selections of single-origin coffees. Visit www.allegrocoffee.com or call 800-227-1107 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a balanced, quietly complex breakfast cup animated by brisk but juicily sweet suggestions of ripe grapefruit.

Name: Sulawesi Toraja Mamasa
Origin: Mamasa growing region, south-central Sulawesi, Indonesia
BlindReview: Crisp, earthy chocolate (or chocolaty earth) dominates aroma and flavor, complicated by tart passion fruit and hints of vanilla and musk. Rounded, gently vibrant acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Rich though drying finish.
Notes: This is a traditional wet-hulled Sulawesi coffee from small holding producers in the tribal Mamasa sub district, just west of the more celebrated Toraja region. Ghost Town is a small-batch roaster, wholesaler, equipment supplier and training resource located in Bozeman, Montana that takes great care in responsibly sourcing top-quality specialty coffees. Visit www.ghosttowncoffee.com call 406-586-0777 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A classic wet-hulled profile of the kind traditionally associated with Sumatra and Sulawesi. Here the famous Indonesia earth notes are crisp and almost graham-cracker-like, rather than lush and humus-like as in some versions of this type. At any rate, a good choice for those who enjoy exploring some of the engaging variations on the Indonesia earth-toned wet-hulled cup.

Name: Papua New Guinea Sihereni
Origin: Upper Asaro Valley, Eastern Papua New Guinea.
BlindReview: Pungently sweet, balanced, elegant. Black currant, dark chocolate, molasses, rose-like flowers in aroma and cup. Tartly sweet, lively acidity; plush, silky mouthfeel. Crisp though sweet, molasses-inflected finish.
Notes: This coffee is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Sihereni Estate was acquired by farmer David Oromari in 2002, and has consistently made strides in quality since then with the support of Monpi Coffee Exports. Roasted at PT’s Coffee, where the motto is “without the love, it’s just coffee.” Visit www.ptscoffee.com or call 888-678-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Almost Kenya-like in its sweet, exhilarating acidity and pungent berry suggestions, though approached in any context a fine coffee.

Name: Sulawesi Tana Toraja
Origin: Toraja growing region, South Sulawesi, Indonesia
BlindReview: Sweetly and deeply pungent. Honey, grapefruit, cacao nib, Brazil nut, a hint of fine leaf tobacco in aroma and cup. Briskly but pleasantly bittersweet acidity; silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates and simplifies in an otherwise impressive finish: rich, deep, long.
Notes: This coffee originates from the Toarco (TOraja ARabica COffee) project in the famous Sulawesi coffee growing region of Toraja, a project developed and financed by Japan's Key Coffee Company and its Indonesian partners. Until recently Toarco sold its entire production to the Japanese market, making this coffee rare in the United States. Blueprint Coffee is a one-location roastery-café in St. Louis, Missouri that aims at producing a small number of flawless and distinctive coffees. Visit www.blueprintcoffee.com or call 888-863-8053 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A gently bittersweet bite (honey on grapefruit) deepens and grounds the subtle complexities of this silky, quietly original profile.

Name: Sulawesi PT Toarco
Origin: Toraja growing region, southwestern Sulawesi, Indonesia
BlindReview: Quietly distinctive; resonant. Honey, dark chocolate, hazelnut, sweetly pungent fruit (cherimoya?) in aroma and cup. Round but juicy acidity; lively, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate sweetness dominates in a long, gently persistent finish.
Notes: Toarco (TOraja ARabica COffee) is a coffee project in the famous Sulawesi coffee growing region of Toraja developed and financed by Japan's Key Coffee Company and its Indonesian partners. Toarco coffees are processed by variants of the orthodox wet or washed method, giving them a brighter and cleaner profile than Sulawesi coffees processed by the locally traditional wet-hulling method. Until recently Toarco sold its entire production to the Japanese market, making this coffee rare in the United States. Propeller is a relatively new Toronto-based micro-roaster with a dedication to careful selection and exceptional craft roasting of high-end coffees, the outgrowth of five years of successful business as the three-location Crema Coffee café chain. Visit www.propellercoffee.com or call 416-479-3771 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a nicely structured, resonantly balanced cup with quiet, understated aromatic drama.

Name: Papua New Guinea Kunjin
Origin: Wahgi Valley, Western Highlands, Papua New Guinea.
BlindReview: Plush, deep, resonant. Apricot and orange, roasted cacao nib, vanilla, a hint of fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Round, soft, though deeply vibrant acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Very sweet finishing, with continued hints of orange and vanilla.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #14 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2014.  This coffee is produced by small-holder farmers. The high mountain valleys of central Papua New Guinea offer some of the world's most favorable terroirs for production of fine coffee, although the rugged terrain presents daunting transportation and infrastructure challenges. When these coffees are carefully prepared by the traditional wet or washed method, as is the case with this coffee, they can compete with the world’s finest. Chromatic prides itself in doing everything in-house and meticulously, from printing its attractive bags to modifying equipment to sourcing and roasting its exceptionally fine coffees. Visit www.chromaticcoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer depth and resonance to assertion and brightness in a complex, well-structured cup.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Ardi
Origin: Guji Zone, Sidama Province, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Immense and lavish. Blueberry, guava, dark chocolate, a hint of cognac, musky, carnal flowers in aroma and cup. Richly pungent acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Guava and chocolate in particular carry into a mildly drying but deeply flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: A spectacularly fruit-toned but unusually refined example of a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Caffe Luxxe is an Italian-inflected artisan roaster and retailer that emphasizes both its coffee knowledge and precision and its straightforward lack of pretension. Visit www.caffeluxxe.com or call 310-394-2222 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Straightforward structure is lifted by extraordinary aromatic depth and complexity from nose to finish.

Name: Ace Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Rich, deep, sweet. Dark chocolate, apricot, tangerine, juniper berry and musk in aroma and small cup. Lightly syrupy, rich-toned mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates around cocoa and juniper hints in a crisp finish. Lightly tart and rounded in three parts milk, with excellent flavor continuity and saturation.
Notes: Propeller is a relatively new Toronto-based micro-roaster with a dedication to careful selection and exceptional craft roasting of high-end coffees, the outgrowth of five years of successful business as the three-location Crema Coffee café chain. Visit www.propellercoffee.com or call 416-479-3771 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A satisfying espresso with sufficient distinction to excite enthusiasts but round and deep enough to avoid polarizing espresso classicists.

Name: Colombia Piendamo Regional Select
BlindReview: Sweetly pungent, complex, original. Cherry-like fruit, brown sugar, roasted cacao nib, hints of clove and vanilla in aroma and cup. Crisp, lightly juicy acidity; light, silky mouthfeel. The cacao nib and spice in particular carry into a gently drying but sweet-toned finish.
Notes: Bean Fruit is a quality-oriented small-batch roaster based in Jackson, Mississippi, whose motto is a Biblical quotation from Galatians 5:22-23: “But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, long suffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, meekness, temperance: against such there is no law.” Visit www.beanfruit.com or call 601-624-2605 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those to whom an unusual flavor complex, sweet but pungent, deep-toned, slightly spicy, appeals.

Name: Costa Rica Dota
Origin: Santa Maria de Dota valley, Tarrazu growing region, Costa Rica.
BlindReview: Sweet, delicately crisp. Walnut, fresh-cut fir, carob, raisin, a spicy floral hint in aroma and in the cup, where the carob sweetens and rounds toward chocolate. Quiet, backgrounded acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Drying though sweet-toned finish.
Notes: From the Dota Cooperative, with which Allegro has a long-standing relationship dating back to the 1990’s. Funds from the sale of this coffee go to support Earth University, a private non-profit university in Costa Rica devoted to sustainability and agricultural sciences. This coffee is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Allegro Coffee, a subsidiary of Whole Foods Market, offers one of the country's largest selections of single-origin coffees. Visit www.allegrocoffee.com or call 800-227-1107 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A quiet, sweetly crisp cup with delicate savory hints, the sale of which supports an admirable cause.

Name: Organic Peru Cecovasa
BlindReview: Deep, quiet, gently chocolaty. Hazelnut, dark chocolate, fresh-cut oak, a hint of orangy citrus in aroma and cup. Simple, functional acidity; very lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate in particular carries into a dry but sweet-toned finish.
Notes: Produced by farmer members of CECOVASA, an association of cooperatives comprising more than 5,000 individual small-holding indigenous producers in a mountain valley in southern Peru. Certified organically grown. Allegro Coffee, a subsidiary of Whole Foods Market, offers one of the country's largest selections of single-origin coffees. Visit www.allegrocoffee.com or call 800-227-1107 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy low acidity and chocolate and nut notes in a certified organically-grown coffee.

Name: Sumatra Lintong
Origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.
BlindReview: Deep, pungent, complex. Spicy scorched cedar, dark chocolate, brown sugar, faint but distinct hints of grapefruity citrus and sweet herb. Roast-muted acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. A sweet roasty chocolate dominates in the finish.
Notes: Coffees from the northern part of the Indonesian island of Sumatra like this one are admired for their complex fruit, herb and aromatic wood notes that result largely from unorthodox fruit removal and drying practices collectively called wet hulling or giling basah. This coffee is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Allegro Coffee, a subsidiary of Whole Foods Market, offers one of the country's largest selections of single-origin coffees. Visit www.allegrocoffee.com or call 800-227-1107 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A darker roast develops the chocolate and pungent grapefruit tendencies of this classic wet-hulled Sumatra.

Name: Colombia Agustino Forest
Origin: San Agustín growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia
BlindReview: Pungently sweet, nut-toned. Carob, roasted chestnut, taffy, hints of mango and musk. Crisp, resonant acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Some flavor carries into a richly balanced finish.
Notes: Produced by 104 mostly indigenous members of the ASOGUAR (La Argentina Forest Ranger Association) in the celebrated Colombian coffee growing region of San Agustin. Allegro Coffee, a subsidiary of Whole Foods Market, offers one of the country's largest selections of single-origin coffees. Visit www.allegrocoffee.com or call 800-227-1107 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy sweet yet pungently deep and nut-toned profiles.

Name: Kenya Grand Cru
BlindReview: Tartly sweet, berry-toned, complex. Blackberry, black currant, dark chocolate and complex flowers, from bitterish lavender to sweet honeysuckle. Delicately lush, buoyant acidity; silky, lively mouthfeel. Berries and chocolate saturate a deep finish.
Notes: Allegro’s Kenya Grand Cru represents a selection of top lots produced in the heart of Kenya’s famed traditional coffee belt, mainly from the celebrated SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica. Allegro Coffee, a subsidiary of Whole Foods Market, offers one of the country's largest selections of single-origin coffees. Visit www.allegrocoffee.com or call 800-227-1107 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Balance and elegance in a superb classic Kenya.

Name: Celinga Ethiopia Espresso
Origin: Celinga Village, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Intense, brightly sweet, deep. Honey, lilac, complex fruit (blood orange, mango, passion fruit), roasted cacao nib in aroma and small cup. Very smooth, silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a tartly drying but very sweet finish. Three parts milk rounds the cacao-nib and fruit to a rich, fruit-saturated chocolate.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this impressive example processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying on raised beds) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on floral notes. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Definitely not a traditionally rounded, chocolate-and-cedar Italian style espresso, yet deeper, sweeter and considerably more complex than most espressos in the brighter contemporary style.

Name: Celinga Ethiopia
Origin: Celinga Village, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Intense, sweetly complex, dramatic. Honey, jasmine, peach, mango, a crisp hint of roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup. Buoyant, lyric acidity; silky, lively mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but rings on and on in a very long finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this impressive example processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying on raised beds) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on floral notes. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Simply a superb coffee in the washed southern Ethiopia style, lyric and exhilarating.

Name: Kochere Yirgacheffe Ethiopia
BlindReview: Crisply sweet, subtle, engaging. Tangerine, plum, lush, lily-like flowers, a hint of nut-toned chocolate in aroma and cup. Brisk, delicate acidity; light but silky mouthfeel. Flowers and chocolate carry into in a richly drying finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on floral notes. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. An integral part of New York’s coffee renaissance, Brooklyn-based Café Grumpy opened its first café in 2005 and has since expanded to six locations, including a roasting facility and bakery. Visit www.cafegrumpy.com or call 718-383-0748 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a delicately exotic, crisp yet sweet breakfast cup.

Name: Las Flores Honduras
BlindReview: Deep, sweetly pungent. Molasses, pecan, raisin, a hint of dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Roundly tart acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate and raisin carry into a crisply drying finish.
Notes: Produced in Santa Bárbara Department near the town of Peña Blanca by César Fernandez on his four-hectare farm from trees of the heirloom Bourbon and respected Pacas varieties of Arabica. An integral part of New York’s coffee renaissance, Brooklyn-based Café Grumpy opened its first café in 2005 and has since expanded to six locations, including a roasting facility and bakery. Visit www.cafegrumpy.com or call 718-383-0748 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A strong-structured coffee with a syrupy but dry mouthfeel and pronounced but rounded acidity.

Name: Brazil Serra Do Bone
Origin: Matas de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.
BlindReview: Complex, deep, original. Halvah-like honey and nut, coconut, narcissus-like flowers, a hint of rye whisky in aroma and cup. Rich, rounded acidity; light but syrupy mouthfeel. Deeply flavor-saturated finish coasts on and on.
Notes: Processed by the pulped natural method, in which the coffee is dried (in this case on raised beds) with the skin removed but the fruit pulp still adhering to the beans. Produced by farmer Carlos Sergio Sanglard from trees of the respected Catuai variety of Arabica. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer forests to meadows, poetic dusk to bright mornings.

Name: Brazil Araponga Temple Select
BlindReview: Balanced, subtle, layered. Hazelnut, honeydew melon, tamarind, fresh-cut oak in aroma and cup. Crisp, gently lively acidity; light, buoyant mouthfeel. Resonant, gently flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: A blend of Brazil coffees selected by Temple from five different farms, including coffees processed both by the dried-in-the-fruit or natural method and the pulped natural method, in which the coffee is dried with the skin removed but all or some of the fruit pulp remaining on the beans. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A good candidate for those who avoid brightly acidy coffees and prefer balance and subtle layered complexity to assertion and intensity.

Name: Rwanda Gashonga
BlindReview: Richly and sweetly pungent. Rose-like floral notes, mulberry, fresh-cut cedar, musk in aroma and cup. Gently bright, balanced acidity; light but lively mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but saturates a very sweet-toned finish.
Notes: Exclusively from trees of the heirloom Red Bourbon variety of Arabica. Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. The Gashonga wet mill draw coffees from nearly 1,600 small-holding farmer cooperative members. North Star Micro Roasters roasts on a five kilogram machine and is “dedicated to sourcing, roasting and supplying the best coffees we can get our hands on.” Visit www.northstarroast.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a sweetly pungent cup with just a hint of savory depth.

Name: Kiawamururu Kenya
BlindReview: Delicate, gently tart. Honey, red currant, hints rose hip, fresh-cut cedar, sweet prairie flowers. Sweetly bright, juicy acidity; lightly syrupy, lively mouthfeel. Rich, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Produced by some of the 561 small-holding members of the Kiawamururu Cooperative. Despite grower discontent, unclear government coffee policy and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Worldwide shipping of this and other fine UK coffees is available through The Coffee Roasters at thecoffeeroasters.co.uk. Visit www.climpsonandsons.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Pure, delicate, gently bright; a meadow in a cup.

Name: Doyo Coop Ethiopia
Origin: Jimma Zone, Oromia Region, southwestern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Very sweet, soft, delicate. Distinct honey and almond notes, roasted cacao nib, hints of narcissus and tangerine-like fruit in aroma and cup. Gentle, lively acidity; light but silky mouthfeel. Almond and flowers carry into a sweet, quiet, slightly drying finish.
Notes: Produced by a cooperative of 430 small-holding farmers from traditional local heirloom varieties of Arabica. Worldwide shipping of this and other fine UK coffees is available through The Coffee Roasters at thecoffeeroasters.co.uk. Visit www.climpsonandsons.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A tactful light roast allows the honey-toned sweetness to dominate in this very pure, delicate coffee.

Name: Ethiopia Levelup Coffee Natural
BlindReview: Richly and lavishly pungent. Blackberry, black currant, dark chocolate, musky flowers in aroma and cup. Low-toned but vibrant acidity; lightly syrupy, lively mouthfeel. Distinct dark chocolate and berry notes carry into a long, clean, sweet-toned finish.
Notes: Levelup Coffee is a relatively new international coffee production company that produces mid-sized lots of green coffees with consistent and distinctive cup profiles. It is the creation of the team that developed Ninety Plus, the admired Panama- and Ethiopia-based producer of small-lot, high-end coffees. This particular Levelup Coffee is a dry-processed or "natural" Ethiopia coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Horsham Coffee Roaster is dedicated to supplying premium, ethically traded, freshly roasted coffee. Worldwide shipping of this and other fine UK coffees is available through The Coffee Roasters at thecoffeeroasters.co.uk. Visit www.horshamcoffeeroaster.com or call +44 7828 786443 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A fine example of the latest style of dried-in-the-fruit or natural coffees, in which the fruit notes are pungently crisp rather than lushly fermenty.

Name: Ethiopia Guji Shakiso
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Sidama Province, Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Sweet, juicy, complex. Orange- and guava-like fruit, dark chocolate, pistachio, lush honeysuckle in aroma and cup. Brisk but juicy acidity; silky mouthfeel. Flavor gently saturates a deep, lively finish.
Notes: Produced by small-holding farmers from traditional local heirloom varieties of Arabica. Clifton Coffee supplies specialty coffee, barista training and commercial espresso machines to coffee shops around the United Kingdom. Worldwide shipping of this and other fine UK coffees is available through The Coffee Roasters at thecoffeeroasters.co.uk. Visit www.cliftoncoffee.co.uk or call +44 845 260 6706 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a refreshing, brisk yet juicy coffee with a gently exotic fruit and floral character.

Name: Gatomboya Bourbon SL28 Kenya
BlindReview: Crisp, sweetly and elegantly tart. Black currant, dark chocolate, night-blooming flowers, pungent sandalwood in aroma and cup. Richly and deeply tart acidity; lightly syrupy, lively mouthfeel. Flowers, black currant, sandalwood all saturate a resonant though drying finish.
Notes: From small-holding producers associated with the Gatomboya wet mill or washing station and produced from trees of the celebrated, Bourbon-related SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica. Despite grower discontent, unclear government coffee policy and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Edinburgh-based Artisan Roast is an award-winning gourmet coffee roastery with two proprietary cafés in Edinburgh and wholesale distribution to top cafés and restaurants throughout Scotland. Worldwide shipping of this and other fine UK coffees is available through The Coffee Roasters at thecoffeeroasters.co.uk. Visit www.artisanroast.co.uk or call +44 7526 236615 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy the sweetly tart, dry berry and lush floral character of a fine Kenya.

Name: Colombia Santiago Joven
Origin: Timana growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia
BlindReview: Pungent and savory-sweet. Roasted cacoa nib and nut, lily, complex fruit (apricot, plum, blood orange), a hint of sweet licorice bark in aroma and cup. Rich, juicy acidity; lightly plush mouthfeel. Floral and cacao notes in particular carrying into a crisp finish.
Notes: Farmer Santiago Joven of Finca La Montanita is a member of the ASPROTIMANA cooperative. Founded in 2001 by thirty-two producers, ASPROTIMANA is now comprised of nearly ninety. Spyhouse Coffee Roasting emphasizes building relationships within and around the coffee community through passion and knowledge. Visit www.spyhousecoffee.com or call 612-345-4348 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A distinctive variation on the classic Colombia profile, juicy with a crisp, engaging savory edge.

Name: Ethiopia Ardi
Origin: Guji Zone, Sidama Province, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Crisply pungent, balanced, sweet-toned. Roasted cacao nib, almond, tangerine, a hint of sweetly fermented fruit cider in aroma and cup. Gently brisk acidity; lively, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. A hint of savory depth in the cup carries with the cacao nib and tangerine into a resonant finish.
Notes: From the Kercha Cooperative. This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. It is an unusually refined example of a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Topéca Coffee is an artisan roaster with three café locations and a roastery in Tulsa, Oklahoma.Visit www.topecacoffee.com or call 918-398-8022 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy gentle complexity and balance and a bit of savory/cidery intrigue.

Name: Tanzania Shiwanda Estate Peaberry
BlindReview: Sweet, balanced, gently deep. Caramel, walnut, raisin, flowers, coriander in aroma and cup. Juicy, gently lush acidity; light, silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a crisp, resonant finish.
Notes: Unlike the cooperative coffees that dominate East and Central Africa production, this is an estate-grown coffee. This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. For reasons that are not entirely clear, Tanzania is particularly associated with its peaberry grades. Pebble Coffee is a specialty micro-roaster located Taipei, Taiwan that focuses on high-end coffees. Email [email protected] or call +886-2-2760-8616 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Quietly complete cup with a slight spice hint to the flowers. Expresses the combination of delicacy and sensory depth traditionally associated with the Tanzania peaberry, a classic coffee type particularly prominent in the early decades of the North American specialty coffee movement.

Name: Congo Muungano
Origin: Kalehe, Southern Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo.
BlindReview: Pungent, sweetly tart. Tangerine, agave syrup, roasted cacao nib, plum in aroma and cup. Impressively lush, sweetly bright acidity; plush mouthfeel. The tart tangerine carries into a deeply resonant, sweet-toned finish.
Notes: The Democratic Republic of the Congo has very recently established itself as a source of specialty coffee with the founding of the Muungano Cooperative in an area overlooking Lake Kivu, on the opposite side of the lake from Rwanda. The rapidly growing cooperative now has 2,300 members, and apparently is succeeding its goal to help heal the wounds left by the latest in eastern Congo’s seemingly endless string of horrific rebellions and civil wars. Wonderstate Coffee, formerly Kickapoo Coffee, is an award-winning roaster based in rural Wisconsin known for their commitment to guaranteeing higher pay for farmers and being the country’s first 100% solar powered roastery. Visit https://wonderstate.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: The agave- and tangerine-like notes in particular animate this sweetly tart, complex cup.

Name: Burundi Kayanza Gitika
BlindReview: Sweet, lively, juicy. Cane sugar, honeysuckle, white grape, hazelnut, a hint of tapioca in aroma and cup. Bright, resonant acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a long, sweet-toned finish.
Notes: Burundi is a small, landlocked country in the Great Lakes region of Central Africa. Most coffee is grown in the mountains of the north, bordering Rwanda. Benefiting from ideal growing conditions and large plantings of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica, Burundi coffee has an excellent reputation, though it is better known in Europe than in the United States. This particular Burundi was processed by the Gitika washing station. Revel Coffee is a micro-roaster located in Billings, Montana. Its motto: “Quality is paramount – a difference you can revel in.” Visit www.revelcoffee.com or call 406-534-9621 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy coffees sweet and pure enough to achieve completeness in a very light roasting style.

Name: Flor Del Huila
Origin: Garzon growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia.
BlindReview: Gently and sweetly tart, quietly complex. Brown sugar, roasted cacao nib, peach, orange, hazelnut in aroma and cup. Crisp, backgrounded acidity; light but silky mouthfeel. Flavor rounds but carries into a sweet-toned finish.
Notes: This coffee is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee. Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Understated but bright, a subtle Colombia for subtle classicists.

Name: Tanzania Nyoni
Origin: Matengo Highlands, Ruvuma Region, southwestern Tanzania.
BlindReview: A rich, lightly roast-toned dark chocolate enveloped in lush floral sweetness dominates in aroma and cup. Hints of banana and honey. Rich, round, gently tart acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The finish is mildly drying, but a resonant chocolate sweetness prevails in the long.
Notes: From the Nyoni Cooperative Union of small holding producers in Tanzania in the highlands above Lake Nyasa. This coffee is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee. Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Chocolate and flowers – sounds right for spring.

Name: Copan Honduras
BlindReview: Round, quiet, deep. Raisin, dark chocolate, roasted pistachio, oak in aroma and cup. Rich, low-toned acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a sweet-toned, balanced, lightly drying finish.
Notes: This coffee is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee.  Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A calm though resonant coffee for calm though resonant mornings.

Name: Ethiopia Danch Meng
BlindReview: Intricate, distinctive, complete. Dark chocolate, a rich array of fruit suggestions – pear, pineapple, plum – and rose, sandalwood and vanilla notes in aroma and cup. Plumply tart and rich acidity; lightly syrupy, lively mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but saturates a long, rich finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is less predictable and deeper than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned Yirgacheffe profile. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Cambria Coffee is a small, quality-focused artisan roasting company located in the town of Cambria on California’s Central Coast. Visit www.cambriacoffeeroasting.com or call 805-927-0670 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A fine example of the new style of Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit coffee, with the lush fruit and chocolate notes characteristic of the processing method, yet still pure, classic, complete.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Bokasso Coop
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Balanced, sweetly crisp. Caramel, hazelnut, strawberry, roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup, where a giddy lilac-like floral note emerges. Delicately lush acidity; light though silky mouthfeel. The cacao note in particular carries into a rich, drying finish.
Notes: Sidamo (also Sidama) is a coffee-growing region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Sidamo coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) typically express considerable aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on floral notes. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Compelling & Rich is uncompromisingly dedicated to offering only small lots of selectively sourced fine single-origin coffees freshly roasted. Visit www.compellingrich.com or call 818-835-5135 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A quietly crisp version of the southern Ethiopia cup, with the floral, citrus and cacao notes expressed with classic subtlety.

Name: Bali Kintamani
BlindReview: Deep, sweet, richly fermenty. Blueberry and blackberry, dark chocolate, Bourbon whisky and carnal, sweetly heavy floral notes in aroma and cup. Round, backgrounded acidity; heavy mouthfeel. The finish is richly resonant with an edgy overripe fruit.
Notes: Produced in the central highlands of the colorful island of Bali, this is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Magnolia Coffee is a Charlotte, North Carolina based boutique roaster whose motto is “Artisan roasted, truly delicious, socially conscious.” Magnolia particularly emphasizes community engagement through its Local Beans for Local Good programs.Visit www.magnoliacoffeeco.com or call 704-651-7726 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Lovers of the flamboyantly fruit-and-spirits style of dried-in-the-fruit coffee, intoxicating and complex, dusk in a tropical forest. Not for coffee purists.

Name: Rwanda Bufcafe
BlindReview: Deep, pungent, complexly chocolate-toned. Dark chocolate, hazelnut, apricot, hints of night-blooming flowers and black currant in aroma and cup. Tart, richly brisk acidity; syrupy, lively mouthfeel. Chocolate and flowers in particular carry into a richly drying finish.
Notes: Rwanda's tremendous potential as fine coffee producer has only come to fruition over the past four to five years owing to generous support from international aid agencies, the specialty coffee community and the industry of its growers. This coffee is produced entirely from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. Epiphanie Mukashyaka established the now famous Bufcafe washing station or wet mill following the Rwandan genocide and the loss of most of her family. She and her son now operate two wet mills and a dry mill in the area. Highwire Coffee Roasters is a small-batch coffee roaster located in Emeryville, California. Established in 2011, Highwire pursues the straightforward goal of sharing the coffees it loves with the community. Visit www.highwirecoffee.com or call 510-420-0473 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A hint of the elegant dry berry character animating Kenya coffee complicates this deeper, more chocolaty version of the Kenya coffee idea.

Name: Rwanda Karongi Gitesi
BlindReview: Subtle, deep, complex. Honey, honeysuckle-like flowers, crisp red currant, hints of pistachio and clove in aroma and cup. Lush, round acidity; lively, syrupy mouthfeel. Honey and flowers saturate a mildly drying finish.
Notes: From trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety and processed at prize-winning Gitesi mill. Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. Papa Lin's Coffee Roasting is a “nano” roaster located in Yorktown Heights, New York, that focuses on carefully sourced, extremely high-quality specialty coffees that are custom-roasted to the preference of every customer. Visit www.papalins.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Complete in structure and exotic in detail: honey and spice in a lush, syrupy-bodied cup.

Name: Rwanda Gitesi
BlindReview: Brisk but juicy. Grapefruit, lush flowers, honey, sweet squash in aroma and cup. Richly tart acidity; light but plush mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists in a long, crisp finish.
Notes: From trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety and processed at prize-winning Gitesi mill. Orazure (The Blue Hour) is a personalized, quality-focused artisanal coffee roaster near Houston, Texas.  Visit www.orazure.com or call 281-961-2766 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Unusual and attractive profile, with a bracing grapefruity brightness enveloped in honey and flowers.

Name: Rwanda Lake Kivu Kabirizi FTO
BlindReview: Rich, syrupy, lush. Honey, gardenia-like flowers, Concord grape, carob in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Grape and carob carry into a simplifying but long, ringing finish.
Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from the small-holding farmers of the COOPAC Cooperative at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Produced from trees of the Central African Mayaguez strain of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. Namusairo is a boutique café and artisan roaster founded in Seoul, South Korea in 2002. Visit www.namusairo.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Rounded power in a juicy, big-bodied cup with subtly original aromatics.

Name: Rwanda Karongi Gitesi
BlindReview: Deeply sweet and chocolaty with a savory edge. Honey, chocolate, lilac, mulberry in aroma and cup. Delicately brisk acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate and honey in particular saturate a crisp, rich finish.
Notes: From trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety and processed at prize-winning Gitesi mill. Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. GivCOFFEE is dedicated to three goals: to provide quality coffee, to provide a fair price to farmers, and to give back to those in need. GivCOFFEE donates two dollars of every retail bag sold. Visit www.givcoffee.com or call 860-874-5301 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy their chocolate with complications, both savory and floral.

Name: Rwanda Cotecaga Bourbon
BlindReview: Big, roundly pungent, complete. Honey, grape, complex flowers (honeysuckle, lavender), candied orange in aroma and cup. Richly intense acidity; syrupy, lively mouthfeel. Grape and lavender notes in particular resonate in a very deep, long finish.
Notes: From trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety and processed at the distinguished Cotecaga mill, which serves over 1,700 members. Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. Four Barrel is a café located in San Francisco's Mission District with an in-house roasting facility. It is owned by Ritual Coffee Roasters co-founder Jeremy Tooker. Visit www.fourbarrelcoffee.com or call 415-252-0800 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy big-bodied, richly acidy coffees with resonantly original aromatics, grapey and complexly floral.

Name: Rwanda Kirezi
BlindReview: Savory nut and sweet honey notes together suggest an almost halvah-like richness, with complications of fresh-cut cedar and roasted cacao nib. Sweetly brisk, buoyant acidity; lively, silky mouthfeel. Drying though deeply flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: The Kirezi cooperative was founded in 2009 with six members. It has now grown to over four hundred members with a full washing station and improved equipment. Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. Blue Bottle Coffee started as the quintessential boutique coffee business: a micro-roasting operation in Oakland housed inside a space about as large as a suburban walk-in closet and a single retail location in San Francisco. Since its founding Blue Bottle has attracted a strong following in the San Francisco Bay Area and beyond, and now operates two roasting locations: one in Oakland, California and another in Brooklyn, New York. Visit www.bluebottlecoffee.com or call 510-653-3394 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Lovers of originality, in this case driven by paradox: crisply savory nut enveloped in honey-and-floral sweetness.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Tambaya AA
BlindReview: Deep, sweetly and richly bright. Honeysuckle, mulberry, black sage, a crisp hint of roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup. Brisk, delicately lively acidity; silky/syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists in a rich, resonant finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #26 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2014.Produced by the Tambaya wet mill member of the Rumukia Farmer’s Co-op Society, from trees of the admired SL28 and SL34 varieties. ChacolaTAY is a Taiwanese small-batch roaster aiming to maximize cup character of elite green coffees through flexible, precise artisan roasting. Visit http://chacolatay.com or call 886-935-730422 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Deep, ringing version of the celebrated Kenya profile, distinguished in particular by intense dry berry and savory-sweet floral notes.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Ardi Natural
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Sweet, complex, rich. Dark chocolate, honey, blueberry, hints of brandy and night-blooming flowers in aroma and cup. Plush, lively acidity; silky mouthfeel. Chocolate and flowers in particular carry into a resonant finish.
Notes: A fine example of a “natural” or dry-processed coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is sweeter and deeper-toned than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned southern Ethiopia profile. Parisi Artisan Coffee is the specialty coffee division of Paris Brothers Specialty Foods, a family-owned business involved in many aspects of the food and beverage industry, including manufacturing, importing and distributing of a wide variety of specialty foods. Visit www.parisicoffee.com or call 816-842-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy the lush blueberry-and-brandy style of southern Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit coffees. A fine, complexly expressed version of the type.

Name: Ethiopia Yirga Natural Bedhatu
Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Crisply exotic. Complex flowers running from honeysuckle to lavender, roasted cacao nib, orange, moist pipe tobacco in aroma and cup. Richly tart, floral-toned acidity; light but very silky mouthfeel. Deep, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. It is an unusually refined example of a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Worka is one of twenty-two primary cooperatives located in the Gedeo Zone of Southern Ethiopia organized as the Yirgacheffe Farmers Union; Bedhatu Jibicho is one of the farmers within the cooperative. Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Brisk but lush profile for those who enjoy both balance and excitement.

Name: Ethiopia Moplaco Yirgacheffe
BlindReview: Juicy, vivacious, with a bracing bittersweet edge. Almond, violets, kumquat, moist pipe tobacco in aroma and cup. Ripe, lively acidity; lightly but smoothly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor saturates a very sweet-toned finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. ChacolaTAY is a Taiwanese small-batch roaster aiming to maximize cup character of elite green coffees through flexible, precise artisan roasting.  Visit http://chacolatay.com or call 886-935-730422 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Bittersweet citrus and delicate florals make this juicy, lively profile a distinctive variation on the great washed Yirgacheffe cup.

Name: Rwanda Kabirizi Washing Station
BlindReview: Sweet-toned, soft, quietly distinctive. Brown sugar, vanilla, jasmine, a hint of blood orange in aroma and cup. Quietly juicy acidity; plush mouthfeel. Vanilla and brown sugar in particular carry into a rich finish.
Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from the small-holding farmers of the COOPAC Cooperative at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Produced from trees of the Central African Mayaguez strain of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. Parisi Artisan Coffee is the specialty coffee division of Paris Brothers Specialty Foods, a family-owned business involved in many aspects of the food and beverage industry, including manufacturing, importing and distributing of a wide variety of specialty foods. Visit www.parisicoffee.com or call 877-345-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer resonant sweetness and gentle complexity in a versatile, all-day cup.

Name: Guji Zone Ethiopia
Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Sidama Province, Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Crisply lush, extravagant. Dark chocolate, jasmine-like flowers, brandy, honey, layered fruit notes: kiwi, mango, banana. Sweetly tart, vivacious acidity; syrupy but lively mouthfeel. Long, resonant, flavor-saturated finish.
