Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #10 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2014.  A fine example of a “natural” or dry-processed coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is sweeter and deeper-toned than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned southern Ethiopia profile. Based in the San Diego area, Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler focused on organic and socially responsible coffees; it was awarded the “2012 Roaster of the Year” title from Roast Magazine. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Lovers of grand sensory gestures; Cirque du Soleil in a cup.

Name: Keynote Perennial Brew
Origin: Sul de Minas growing region, southern Minas Gerais State, Brazil.
BlindReview: Sweetly pungent, gentle, balanced. Caramel, cedar, chocolate, plum, a hint of citrus in aroma and cup. Plushly soft acidity; smooth, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a crisp, sweet-toned finish.
Notes: Keynote Perennial Brew is a rotating single-origin coffee. The version reviewed here is a Brazil coffee processed by the pulped natural or “honey” method, in which the skin of the coffee fruit is removed but the beans are dried with all or some of the fruit pulp still adhering to the beans. Produced entirely from trees of the respected Yellow Catuai variety of Arabica. Chromatic prides itself in doing everything in-house and meticulously, from printing its attractive bags to modifying equipment to sourcing and roasting its exceptionally fine coffees. Visit www.chromaticcoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Comfort without compromise: a round, drinkable coffee with soft but lively acidity and impressive complexity.

Name: Colombia El Bado
BlindReview: Crisply sweet, complete. Roasted cacao nib, orangy citrus, almond butter, honeysuckle, apricot in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart, juicy acidity; lightly but distinctly syrupy mouthfeel. Cacao and flowers in particular persist in a sweet finish.
Notes: El Bado is a Cup of Excellence record holder of sorts with four consecutive top-twenty placements, a tribute to the efforts of farmer Maria Diaz, who took over operations with the help of her son after her husband passed away. Mr. Espresso is a San Francisco Bay Area wholesale roaster and espresso parts distributer that slow-roasts its coffees using traditional wood-fired roasting machines. Visit www.mrespresso.com or call 510-287-5200 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Fine balance in a roundly tart but very sweet profile.

Name: Colombian Monserrate B
BlindReview: Richly pungent, deeply floral. Molasses, vanilla, ripe plum, night-blooming flowers, a hint of savory-sweet spice in aroma and cup. Soft, gently crisp acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Crisply dry in the short finish; a floral sweetness blooms in the long.
Notes: Produced by Yaneth Gil in the admired high-elevation coffee growing community of Monserrate, this segregated lot B is a particularly refined example of the Monserrate production. Cod? Coffee is a small-batch coffee roaster located in Denver, Colorado, begun by two brothers with a passion for quality coffee and exemplary sustainable practices. Visit www.codacoffee.com or call 877-234-2632 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: The deep, resonant sweetness of night-blooming flowers in particular permeates this soft, melodic coffee.

Name: Colombia Tolima La Aldea
BlindReview: Delicate, soft, silky. Honey, night-blooming flowers, cocoa butter, vanilla in aroma and cup. Gentle but lively, floral-toned acidity; buoyant, silky mouthfeel. Vanilla in particular carries into a quietly flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: This coffee has benefited from the “million-pesos” program, which guarantees farmers a significant premium for coffees rated 90 points and above. Papa Lin's Coffee Roasting is a “nano” roaster located in Yorktown Heights, New York, that focuses on carefully sourced, extremely high-quality specialty coffees that are custom-roasted to the preference of every customer. Visit www.papalins.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value poise and balance in a delicately structured, sweetly fragrant cup.

Name: Colombia Finca Santa Maria Caturra
BlindReview: Big, sweetly pungent. Fudgy chocolate, strawberry, lily-like flowers, fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Rich, round, juicy acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a deep, chocolate-toned finish.
Notes: Produced at around 6,000 feet from trees of the Caturra variety of Arabica. In 2013 the farm was attacked by bandits, who stole much of the harvest and destroyed essential equipment. Owing to a fundraising effort by PT’s, coffee farmer Armando and his family were able to secure the essentials to complete their production. Roasted at PT’s Coffee, where the motto is “without the love, it’s just coffee.” Visit www.ptscoffee.com or call 888-678-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy the big, rich style of Colombia cup, with the chocolaty sweetness balanced by a crisp cedary edge.

Name: Organic Colombia Fondo Paez Cooperative
Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.
BlindReview: Roundly and richly tart; lively. Orangy citrus, honeysuckle, honey, vanilla, a spicy hint of sandalwood in aroma and cup. Delicately juicy, bright acidity; very silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a resonant, sweet-toned finish.
Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown. Although the words "Fair Trade" appear as well on the label of the attractive 12-ounce valve-topped can, the trade-marked seal of Fair Trade USA does not. Fondo Paez is a cooperative of 550 farmers from the indigenous Paez people of central Colombia. Wonderstate Coffee, formerly Kickapoo Coffee, is an award-winning roaster based in rural Wisconsin known for their commitment to guaranteeing higher pay for farmers and being the country’s first 100% solar powered roastery. Visit https://wonderstate.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Classic Colombia breakfast cup with bonus nuance and depth and a fine social and environmental story.

Name: Colombia Huila Million Pesos Natural
BlindReview: Deep, pungent, juicy. Immense, sweet night-blooming flowers, molasses, dark chocolate, guava-like fruit, a hint of thyme. Rich, deeply nuanced acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but rings on in a resonant finish.
Notes: This is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. This is the first natural-processed Colombian coffee ever to reach us at Coffee Review. The “million-pesos” program guarantees farmers a significant premium for coffees rated 90 points and above. Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Fine and original variant on the dried-in-the-fruit cup, preserving the pungent, complex sweetness of the type with little of the usual fermenty fruit.

Name: Colombia San Agustin
Origin: San Agustín growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia
BlindReview: Deep, pungent, layered. Dark chocolate, molasses, narcissus-like flowers, peach, honeydew melon in aroma and cup. Round, gently rich acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flowers and chocolate in particular carry into a long, sweet-toned, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: San Agustín is one of the most admired of Colombia coffee-growing regions. Chromatic prides itself in doing everything in-house and meticulously, from printing its attractive bags to modifying equipment to sourcing and roasting its exceptionally fine coffees. Visit www.chromaticcoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy quiet distinction, depth and resonance in a versatile, all-day cup.

Name: Colombia Finca Monte Verde, Gildardo Gutierrez
BlindReview: This deeply nuanced coffee requires patience to fully engage its originality and distinction. Sweet-savory in structure with honey, lilac, roasted cacao nib and ripe peach in aroma and cup. Plump, juicy acidity; an almost honeyish viscosity in the mouthfeel. Lilac, honey and cacao nib in particular carry into a long, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee is only available in-store at Sightglass Coffee in San Francisco. Produced by farmer Gildardo Gutierrez, who was gifted the farm by his father as a wedding present. Sightglass Coffee is a small-batch sibling-owned coffee company with two roasteries located in San Francisco. Sightglass works tirelessly at its craft to perfect and deliver excellence in coffee. Visit www.sightglass.com or call 415-861-1313 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A contemplative coffee with a savory-sweet complexity that rewards attentiveness.

Name: Colombia Cerro Azul Enano
Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.
BlindReview: Intensely floral, deeply complex. Rose- and lavender-like flowers, honey, cacao nib, apricot, a delicate hint of cashew in aroma and cup. Gently buoyant, lively acidity, light but very silky mouthfeel. Lavender and cashew in particular persist in a sweet-toned, balanced finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #28 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2014.  The unpredictability of coffee is confirmed once again with this striking sample, produced from trees that are apparently a spontaneous hybrid involving the famous Gesha (also Geisha) variety of Arabica. The producers Granja la Esperanza brought Gesha plant material from Panama, where this celebrated variety was first rediscovered, to Colombia, where they established it on their farm Cerro Azul. Some of the trees proved not to resemble the trees of the classic Gesha, however; they grew smaller and denser. The producers have given the name “Enano” or dwarf to this apparent hybrid of Gesha. Based on the slim evidence of this single sample of the Enano, the result in the cup is a profile similar to the finest examples of bonafide Gesha, though perhaps a bit less intense in its Geshaness. Founded in 1995, Equator Coffees & Teas is a women-owned wholesale coffee roasting company with web-based retail and two recently-established cafés plus more on the way. Equator focuses on sustainability in coffee sourcing and business practices. Visit www.equatorcoffees.com or call 800-809-7687 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: An extraordinary bargain: offers a persuasive version of the sensory fireworks of a great Gesha at about one-fifth the price.

Name: Colombia Cerro Azul Geisha
Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.
BlindReview: Intense yet delicate; crisp, graceful. A tightly layered, utterly pleasing fusion of lavender-like flowers, roasted cacao nib and a hint of blood orange carries with clarity and consistency from aroma through finish. Lyrical, animated acidity; light but silky, lively mouthfeel. The finish never seems to stop; the floral-cacao-citrus notes ring on and on.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #25 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2014.  Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also spelled Geisha). Gesha was planted on the Granja La Esperanza farms as part of a ten-year project to improve coffee quality and to introduce new botanical varietals to Colombia; Cerro Azul is one of those farms. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and chocolate cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world's most unique coffees. Tony’s Coffee has been roasting in Bellingham, Washington since 1971. Visit www.tonyscoffee.com or call 800-448-8804 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: If a coffee ever merited the term elegant, this one does. Delicately but perfectly structured, with an amazingly consistent and original aroma-flavor complex.

Name: Rwanda Kabirizi FTO
BlindReview: Crisply sweet, quietly distinctive. Caramel, orange, vanilla, hazelnut in aroma and cup. Gently bright acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a clean, sweet finish.
Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from the small-holding farmers of the COOPAC Cooperative at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. From trees of the Central African Mayaguez strain of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria, Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees from the roasting process to the cup. Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A gentle but distinctively engaging breakfast cup with Fair Trade and organic credentials.

Name: Twisted 3.0 Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply sweet and versatile, with a wide-ranging complexity. Pineapple-like fruit, dusk-blooming flowers, buttery chocolate, musk in aroma and cup. Lightly but distinctly syrupy mouthfeel. Crisp and chocolaty in the finish. Turns very sweet in three parts milk: buttery chocolate and pineapple.
Notes: Twisted’s name was inspired by the way espresso “twists” as it streams from the spout of a portafilter. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: As a straight shot complex and satisfying; sweet and flavor-nuanced in cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Bufcafe Rwanda Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Deep, round, quietly complex. Banana, crisp dark chocolate, blood orange, flowers in aroma and small cup. Lightly but distinctly syrupy mouthfeel; citrus and chocolate carry into a gently rich finish. Flavor notes round but persist with some nuance in three parts milk.
Notes: Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Balanced, versatile espresso with a low-toned, resonant complexity in both straight shot and cappuccino-scaled milk.

Name: Rock the House Blend FTO
BlindReview: Delicately and sweetly pungent. Cane sugar, chocolate, flowers, peach, a hint of fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Crisp, quiet acidity; light, very silky mouthfeel. Rather drying in the short finish, though sweetness and flavor carry into the long.
Notes: The name of this blend resulted from a contest held some years ago on the Johnson Brothers' Facebook page. Coffees composing this blend are certified organically grown and Fair Trade, the latter meaning the green beans were purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Delicate but sweetly and crisply engaging breakfast cup with impressive social and environmental credentials.

Name: Ethiopia Amaro Gayo Dry Process
BlindReview: Crisp, sweetly pungent, juicy. Roasted cacao nib, honeysuckle-like flowers, amaretto, cactus fruit, black cherry in aroma and cup. Lively, almost effervescent acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The cacao nib in particular carries into a sweet-toned, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: A “natural” or dry-processed coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is lower-toned and more richly pungent than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned southern Ethiopia profile. Organically grown and meticulously prepared by Asnakech Thomas, Ethiopia’s only female miller/exporter. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Cacao-nib crisp but amaretto-like sweet, resonantly complex, a superb version of the dried-in-the-fruit southern Ethiopia type.

Name: El Salvador Las Delicias Natural
BlindReview: Crisp, aromatic, whisky-toned. Raspberry and blueberry, honeysuckle and lavender, rye whisky, roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup. Gentle, rounded acidity; delicately syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but lasts in a rich finish.
Notes: This is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A hint of clean ferment contributes a whisky-like shimmer to the complex fruit and floral notes of this impressive dried-in-the-fruit coffee.

Name: Kenya Kikai
BlindReview: Crisply pungent, complex in structure and aromatics. Fine balance of sweet, tartly dry and savory: dark chocolate, brown sugar, black currant, blackberry, a hint of white sage in aroma and cup. Brisk but juicy acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Balanced, gently rich short finish with some chocolate and molasses notes surviving in the long.
Notes: Despite grower discontent, confusing government coffee policy and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Mystic Monk Coffee is a small-batch roaster associated with a Carmelite monastery located in the Rocky Mountains of northern Wyoming. The monks emphasize an artisan approach to roasting and a commitment to quality. Visit www.mysticmonkcoffee.com or call 877-751-6377 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A fine variation on the sweet and berryish yet crisply dry-boned Kenya profile.

Name: Easter Sunrise Blend
BlindReview: Delicately bright and vanilla-toned. Roasted cacao nib, vanilla, lavender, mulberry in aroma and cup. Gently tart, berry-toned acidity; light, silky mouthfeel. Cacao nib and mulberry in particular carry into a crisply sweet finish.
Notes: Mystic Monk Coffee is a small-batch roaster associated with a Carmelite monastery located in the Rocky Mountains of northern Wyoming. The monks emphasize an artisan approach to roasting and a commitment to quality. Visit www.mysticmonkcoffee.com or call 877-751-6377 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Crisp delicacy and vanilla and floral tones that could add up to lily may make this breakfast blend particularly suitable for Easter-time spring mornings.

Name: Monk-Shot Kenya Kikai (K-Cup compatible)
BlindReview: (As brewed in a Keurig B70 Platinum single-serve brewing device using a Keurig-compatible capsule to produce a 6-ounce serving): Sweet, silky, juicy. Caramel, blackberry, night-blooming flowers, a hint of fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Delicately crisp acidity; the mouthfeel is light in weight but syrupy in texture. Flavor consolidates but gently persists in a sweet-toned, balanced finish.
Notes: This coffee is sold pre-ground in capsules that are compatible with the Keurig brewing system, but which use a different design from Keurig K-Cups. Despite grower discontent, confusing government coffee policy and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Mystic Monk Coffee is a small-batch roaster associated with a Carmelite monastery located in the Rocky Mountains of northern Wyoming. The monks emphasize an artisan approach to roasting and a commitment to quality. Visit www.mysticmonkcoffee.com or call 877-751-6377 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Manages to carry some of the crisply berry-toned distinction of a fine Kenya into the generally muting K-cup format, but Kenya aside, any Keurig owner looking for a sweet, berry-and-floral-toned breakfast cup should enjoy this one.

Name: Monk-Shot Easter Sunrise Blend (K-Cup compatible)
BlindReview: (As brewed in a Keurig B70 Platinum single-serve brewing device using a Keurig-compatible capsule to produce a 6-ounce serving): Crisply sweet, quietly complex. Fresh-cut fir, caramel, orange, golden raisin in aroma and cup. Gently brisk acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Orange and raisin persist in a sweet-toned though mildly drying finish.
Notes: This coffee is sold pre-ground in capsules that are compatible with the Keurig brewing system, but which use a different design from Keurig K-Cups. Mystic Monk Coffee is a small-batch roaster associated with a Carmelite monastery located in the Rocky Mountains of northern Wyoming. The monks emphasize an artisan approach to roasting and a commitment to quality. Visit www.mysticmonkcoffee.com or call 877-751-6377 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Low-toned but complex, gently brisk all-day cup for Keurig owners.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo
BlindReview: Deep, shifting complexity in aroma and cup: lavender, musk, bergamot, cinnamon, roasted cacao nib. Buoyant, melodic acidity; silky mouthfeel. Flowers in particular saturate a delicately rich, gently drying finish.
Notes: Wild Goose is an artisan roaster in the southern California town of Redlands striving for “World class coffee with a worldwide conscience.” Wild Goose emphasizes its relationship-driven green coffee sourcing, and for every pound of coffee sold it purchases ten pounds of food for a local food bank, with over four-hundred thousand pounds donated to date. Visit www.wildgoosecoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Solid structure and deep, exotic aromatics should both reassure and surprise at breakfast.

Name: Ethiopia Gedeo Yirgacheffe
BlindReview: Fruit notes are layered and shifting: tangerine, guava, strawberry, more, complicated by honeyish floral notes and a crisp, nutty roasted cacao nib. Juicy, lively acidity; silky mouthfeel. Flowers in particular saturate a long, resonant finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. Revel Coffee is a micro-roaster located in Billings, Montana. Its motto: “Quality is paramount – a difference you can revel in.” Visit www.revelcoffee.com or call 406-534-9621 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: An extravagant yet crisply focused coffee; a fine morning surprise.

Name: Java Taman Dadar
BlindReview: Pungently rich, complex. Dark chocolate, lightly scorched oak, molasses, hints of night-blooming flowers and coriander in aroma and cup. Dry, low-toned acidity; light but silky mouthfeel. Dry and oaky in the short finish but a chocolaty sweetness prevails in the long.
Notes: An unusual small-producer coffee from Java, prepared using the uniquely Indonesian fruit removal and drying practices collectively called wet hulling. This coffee is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee.  Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who know and enjoy Sumatra coffees should particularly enjoy this moderately dark-roasted, briskly complex variation on the Indonesian wet-hulled cup.

Name: Blue Sky Breakfast Blend
BlindReview: Balanced, suave, lightly pungent. Honeyish chocolate, lily-like flowers, pineapple, fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Richly and roundly tart acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Crisp, gently chocolate-toned finish.
Notes: Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Sweet chocolate and floral notes are deepened by pungent pineapple and aromatic wood in this gently complex, balanced breakfast cup.

Name: Whidbey Blend
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Richly pungent, intense. In the small cup dark chocolate, fresh-cut cedar, raisin, a hint of vanilla-like flowers. Lightly creamy mouthfeel. Chocolate carries into a rich though rather drying finish. In three parts milk displays a crisp, balanced chocolate nuanced with vanilla and a raisiny fruit.
Notes: Established in 1989, Whidbey Coffee continues to offer fine, affordable coffee to areas north of Seattle, including sprawling, colorful Whidbey Island. Visit www.whidbeycoffee.com or call 800-575-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a pungently intense, nicely nuanced bittersweet chocolate character in small cup and short milk.

Name: Brazil Yellow Catuai Esperança Joao “Zinho” Souza
Origin: Cerrado growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.
BlindReview: Delicate, soft, lively. Distinct honeysuckle-like flowers, apple, caramel, walnut, a hint of roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup. Gently crisp acidity; lightly plush mouthfeel. Sweet-toned, quietly flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Processed by the pulped natural method, in which the skin is removed from the coffee fruit immediately after picking, but the seeds or beans are dried with the sweet pulp, or fruit flesh, still adhering to them. João “Ziñho” Souza and his family produced this micro-lot from trees of the Yellow Catuai variety of Arabica at their farm Fazenda Esperança. Ritual is a frequently celebrated (NY Times, etc.), obsessively quality-oriented roastery based in San Francisco, California. Visit www.ritualroasters.com or call 415-641-1024 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value delicacy without loss of complexity.

Name: Brazil Fazenda Furnas Natural
Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil
BlindReview: Sweet, rich, slightly fermenty. Blueberry, chocolate, fresh-cut cedar, sweet narcissus-like flowers in aroma and cup. Round, gently rich acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor carries persuasively into a sweet-toned though slightly dry finish.
Notes: The term natural means this coffee was dried inside the entire fruit rather than after the fruit was removed. Most Brazil coffee is dried inside the fruit, but this natural Brazil shows a particularly ripe fruit character that is not generally typical for the Brazil versions of the type. Papa Lin's Coffee Roasting is a small, “nano” roaster located in Yorktown Heights, New York, focusing on carefully sourced, extremely high quality specialty coffees, which are custom roasted to the preference of every customer.  Visit www.papalins.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Definitely not purists; rather those who enjoy the lush, edgily overripe fruit and floral sweetness of an old-fashioned dried-in-the-fruit coffee.

Name: Brazil Fazenda Sertaozinho
Origin: Sao Sebastiao da Grama, Sao Paulo state, south-central Brazil.
BlindReview: Sweetly and tartly pungent. Crisp roasted cacao nib, hazelnut, apricot, hints of honeysuckle and musk in aroma and cup. Roundly tart acidity; light, satiny mouthfeel. Sweet and chocolate-toned in the short finish; mildly drying in the long.
Notes: Composed entirely of beans from the yellow-fruited strain of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. Processed by the pulped natural method, in which the skin is removed from the coffee fruit immediately after picking, but the seeds or beans are dried with the sweet pulp, or fruit flesh, still adhering to them. Fazenda Sertãozinho has consistently placed high in Brazil Cup of Excellence international juried green coffee competitions. Based in the heart of San Francisco, Linea Caffe brings together the coffee knowledge of Andrew Barnett, founder of Ecco Café and widely traveled competition judge, and the food savvy of respected restaurateur Anthony Myint.  Visit www.lineacaffe.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a measure of tart authority in a crisp, cacao-toned Brazil.

Name: Brazil Pedra Redonda
Origin: Matas de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.
BlindReview: Rich, deep, exotically pungent. Spicy, tea-rose-like flowers, roasted cacao nib, vanilla, tamarind, myrrh in aroma and cup. Round, quietly resonant acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The cacao-nib in particular carries into a sweet, richly drying finish.
Notes: Produced entirely from trees of the Catuai variety of Arabica and processed by the pulped natural method, in which the skin is removed from the coffee fruit immediately after picking, but the seeds or beans are dried with the sweet pulp, or fruit flesh, still adhering to them. The Pedra Redonda farm is run by farmer José Santana with his two brothers, and selectively hand-harvests its coffee, an unusual practice in Brazil. Roast Co. is a small-batch roasting company based in Oakland, California founded by Alex Roberts and Andrew Green with the vision of roasting high-quality coffees sourced through conscious connections.  Visit www.roastco.com or call 510-658-2799 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy spicy flowers and near-incense-like pungency, softened by a more familiar chocolaty cacao-nib note.

Name: Brasil Carmo De Minas Fazenda Monte Verde Bourbon
Origin: Mantiqeiras de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.
BlindReview: Resonant and complex from aroma through finish: roasted cacao nib, vanilla, apricot, hazelnut. Crisply bittersweet acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The long, deep, flavor-saturated finish is particularly impressive.
Notes: Composed entirely of beans from the yellow-fruited strain of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. Processed by the pulped natural method, in which the skin is removed from the coffee fruit immediately after picking, but the seeds or beans are dried with the sweet pulp, or fruit flesh, still adhering to them. The Monte Verde estate, run by farmer José Canato, has consistently placed high in the Brazil Cup of Excellence competition. Victrola is a small-batch, hands-on roaster with a passionate commitment to quality and distinctiveness. Visit www.victrolacoffee.com or call 206-624-1725 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Some may find the bittersweet acidity bracing, others mildly distracting, but everyone should enjoy deep, complex aromatics, particularly as they stretch far into a resonant finish.

Name: Brazil Yellow Bourbon Laranjal Farms
Origin: Pocos de Caldas, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.
BlindReview: Sweet, delicately and crisply complex. Distinct rose-like floral notes, roasted cacao nib, caramel, roasted almond in aroma and cup. Gentle acidity; lightly silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but carries persuasively into a quietly dry finish.
Notes: Composed entirely of beans from the yellow-fruited strain of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica and processed by the pulped natural method, in which the skin is removed from the coffee fruit immediately after picking, but the seeds or beans are dried with the sweet pulp, or fruit flesh, still adhering to them. This farm was purchased by the prize-winning Sertãozinho group in 2006. Willoughby's Coffee & Tea is a pioneer specialty coffee roaster established in the early 1980s that has gracefully and successfully moved with the times and now offers a menu of extremely refined small-lot, single-origin coffees. Visit www.willoughbyscoffee.com or call 800-388-8400 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: This refined, delicate version of the classic Brazil dried-in-the-fruit profile may particularly please those who find brighter, higher-grown coffees too assertive but who still crave some aromatic intrigue. The rose-like notes are rich and impressive.

Name: Brazil Grota Funda
Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil
BlindReview: Resonant, gently pungent. Raisin, peach, honey, sweet chocolate, a hint of fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Quiet, lively acidity; light though plush mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a round, richly drying finish.
Notes: From trees of the Catuai and Yellow Bourbon varieties of Arabica processed by the pulped natural method, in which the skin is removed from the coffee fruit immediately after picking, but the seeds or beans are dried with the sweet pulp, or fruit flesh, still adhering to them. Ghost Town is a small-batch roaster, wholesaler, equipment supplier and training resource located in Bozeman, Montana that takes great care in responsibly sourcing top-quality specialty coffees. Visit www.ghosttowncoffee.com call 406-586-0777 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Lovers of subtle dessert-like flavors in coffee.

Name: Brazil Bela Vista Micro-Lot
Origin: Dom Vicoso, Minas Gerais state, east-central Brazil.
BlindReview: Crisp, delicate but deep. Peach, milk chocolate, bergamot-like citrus, honeysuckle in aroma and cup. Gently bright, refined acidity; light, silky mouthfeel. Chocolate in particular carries into a gently rich finish.
Notes: Produced entirely from trees of the respected Yellow Catuai variety of Arabica, and processed by the pulped natural method, in which the skin is removed from the coffee fruit immediately after picking, but the seeds or beans are dried with the sweet pulp, or fruit flesh, still adhering to them. This award-winning farm of seventeen hectares, run by Ana Vilela and her four children, selectively hand-harvests its coffee, an unusual practice in Brazil. Equator is a specialty roaster based in the San Francisco Bay Area driven by “passion for quality and sustainability.” Visit www.equatorcoffees.com or call 800-809-7687 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy balance and subtle, layered complexity. The chocolate note is particularly pure and delicate.

Name: Brazil Leuven Santa Margarida Estate Lot 129
BlindReview: Shifting, layered complexity. Roasted hazelnut, roasted cacao nib, vanilla, hints of Scotch whisky (the smoother Highland style), plumeria-like flowers, orangy citrus carry from aroma through finish. Round, soft acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel.
Notes: This coffee is a fully washed or wet-processed coffee. A special strain of yeast developed by the Belgian laboratory Leuven for wine-making was added to the vat during the fermentation step used to loosen the fruit pulp before it is washed off the beans. Chromatic prides itself in doing everything in-house and meticulously, from printing its attractive bags to modifying equipment to sourcing and roasting its exceptionally fine coffees. Visit www.chromaticcoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: The soft acidity of a classic Brazil combined with authority in structure and engaging aroma and flavor. When it is next available, aficionados will definitely want to sample this coffee to tease out the sensory impact of adding wine yeast to the vat during the fermentation step, as well as to experience what in our records is the lightest roasted coffee ever tested at Coffee Review, certainly the only one close to this light to score so well.

Name: Rwanda Karongi Gitesi
BlindReview: Savory-sweet, distinctive, intense. Dark chocolate, black currant, mulberry, floral vanilla, black sage in aroma and cup. Deeply and sweetly tart acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Sweet sage and berry in particular carry into a long, resonant finish.
Notes: From trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety and processed at prize-winning Gitesi mill. Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: The sweet sage note in particular deepens and adds nuance to this fine, deeply-expressed version of the Bourbon-influenced Central Africa cup.

Name: Gelgelu Adame Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Organic Natural Process
BlindReview: Intense, lush, remarkable. Honey, lilac-like flowers, star fruit, roasted cacao nib, and a deep, grapey, brandy-like note in aroma and cup. Honey and flowers in particular carry into a sweet-toned, resonant finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #3 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2014.  Certified organically grown. Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is less predictable and deeper than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned Yirgacheffe profile. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A dried-in-the-fruit Yirgacheffe for purists: cleanly and grandly opulent.

Name: Taiwan Alishan Washed Sumatra Typica
BlindReview: Richly and softly pungent. Dark honey, wisteria-like flowers, dark chocolate, sandalwood in aroma and cup. Soft but vibrant acidity; plush, lively mouthfeel. The finish consolidates around a deeply nuanced chocolate sensation.
Notes: This coffee was produced in Taiwan from trees of the Sumatra strain of Typica and processed by the conventional “washed” method, meaning the skin and fruit pulp were removed from the beans immediately after picking and before drying. In addition to his retail roasting operation Aroma Roast Coffees, Simon Hsieh also operates Soaring Phoenix Trading, a business focused on purpose-built commercial espresso blends and high quality single-origin coffees. Visit www.facebook.com/4ArtsZeroDefectCoffees or call 886-0983-749876 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A coffee both elegant and exotic from a still rare origin. Taiwan readers in particular may want to buy it to support the home team.

Name: Regular Coffee
BlindReview: Sweetly pungent, deep, big-bodied. Cherry, honey, dark chocolate, cedar in aroma and cup. Quiet, backgrounded acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. The chocolate note moves forward in a richly drying, sweet-toned finish.
Notes: Regular Coffee is a specialty coffee company based in Grand Rapids, Michigan that specializes in bringing consumers a good cup of coffee at a good price without fuss, hyperbole or fancy packaging. The tall 24-ounce can wrapped in a kraft paper label with plain black lettering drives the point home. Regular sells its coffees on a no-commitment subscription basis. The purchase price includes shipping.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy an aromatically straightforward though roundly big-bodied cup at an affordable price.

Name: Cocoa Sweet Espresso Blend
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Deep, chocolate-toned, with a savory edge. Dark chocolate, fresh-cut cedar, plum, hints of tarragon and black pepper in aroma and small cup. Plush, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Some flavor carries into a crisply dry finish. The chocolate comes forward and sweetens in three parts milk, complicated by continued savory, herby hints.
Notes: CofFeeling is a one-location roaster-café situated adjacent to of one of Taiwan’s most elegantly designed metro stations. Visit www.coffeelingcafe.com or call +886-7-285-5300 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a versatile espresso with impressive depth and low-toned, savory-sweet complexity.

Name: Regular Coffee Decaf
BlindReview: Fresh-cut pine, herb and a rounding hint of raisiny dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Muted, herby acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Sweet-toned though simple finish.
Notes: Decaffeinated by the "Swiss Water Process" method, which does not involve use of solvents. Regular Coffee is a specialty coffee company based in Grand Rapids, Michigan that specializes in bringing consumers a good cup of coffee at a good price without fuss, hyperbole, or fancy packaging. The tall 24-ounce can wrapped in a kraft paper label with plain black lettering drives the point home. Regular sells its coffees on a no-commitment subscription basis. The purchase price includes shipping.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: The impact of decaffeination drains aromatics from this solid, good-value coffee, but leaves a pleasingly full, syrupy mouthfeel and a fresh, woody sweetness.

Name: Sulawesi Tana Toraja Peaberry
Origin: Toraja growing region, South Sulawesi, Indonesia
BlindReview: Savory sweet, striking, unusual. Ripe tomato, vanilla, sweet flowers, orangy citrus, roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup. Delicate, sweetly brisk acidity; light, silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a sweet-toned, gently drying finish.
Notes: Sulawesi coffee like this one from the Toarco mill is fully wet-processed, unlike the more earthy and idiosyncratic wet-hulled coffees produced in Sulawesi and elsewhere in Indonesia. This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: An unusual overlap of ripe, slightly savory tomato and sweet, vanilla-like flowers animates this distinctive coffee.

Name: Ecuador Finca La Nube
BlindReview: Delicate but exhilarating. Orangy dark chocolate, sweet, wisteria-like flowers, cherry, a deepening hint of pine in aroma and cup. Buoyant, floral-toned acidity; light but distinctly silky mouthfeel. Flowers and chocolate carry into a surprisingly long, deep finish.
Notes: This coffee was produced from trees of the SL-28 variety of Arabica, a variety famous as the source for many of Kenya’s finest and most distinctive coffees. Produced by farmer Nico Valez, this Ecuador farm is now owned by his neighbors Henry and Verena Gaibor of Finca Maputo. Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria, Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees from the roasting process to the cup.  Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Clean, delicate vivacity should please any coffee drinker, but aficionados may be particularly interested in sampling a coffee produced in Latin America from a distinctive coffee variety closely associated with East Africa.

Name: Colombia Huila
BlindReview: Bright, balanced, quietly complete. Roasted cacao nib, lilac-like flowers, peach, a hint of citrus in aroma and cup. Delicately crisp acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Dry chocolate dominates in a pungently rich finish.
Notes: Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria, Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees from the roasting process to the cup. Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A classic Colombia in the traditional style: bright but sweet and balanced; complete without flourishes or drama. Classic breakfast-cup drinkers should enjoy it.

Name: Guatemala Guaya’B Huehuetenango
BlindReview: Pungent, deep, low-toned. Dark chocolate, grape, fresh-cut oak, a hint of flowers in aroma and cup. Round, backgrounded acidity; full, hefty mouthfeel. Sweet, crisply chocolaty finish.
Notes: Produced by the Guaya'b Cooperative of small-holding Mayan-Quiche farmers in the admired Huehuetenango growing region. This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Produced from trees of a mix of traditional varieties of Arabica. Café Virtuoso is a small-batch coffee roaster that strives to procure, roast and deliver the best quality coffee in San Diego. Visit www.cafevirtuoso.com or call 619-550-1830 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Round, low-toned coffee that rewards patient drinking with an oaky, chocolaty depth.

Name: Ethiopia FTO Worka
Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Balanced in structure but extravagant in flavor and aroma. Complex fruit, crisp roasted cacao nib, agave syrup, bourbon whisky, honeysuckle-like flowers in aroma and cup. Round, resonant acidity; silky mouthfeel. Vibrantly deep, flavor-saturated finish, with cacao-nib, bourbon and agave notes particularly prominent.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #6 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2014. This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. It is an unusually refined example of a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Worka is one of twenty-two primary cooperatives located in the Gedeo Zone of Southern Ethiopia organized as the Yirgacheffe Farmers Union. Topéca Coffee is an artisan roaster with three café locations and a roastery in Tulsa, Oklahoma.Visit www.topecacoffee.com or call 918-398-8022 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those interested in a cleanly expressed yet triumphantly intricate example of the dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” Ethiopia profile. Extraordinary value for the money.

Name: Testa Rossa Classic Espresso Blend
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Rich, chocolaty and hearty. Scorched cedar, deep-toned dark-chocolate, night-blooming flowers, hints of anise and plum in aroma and small cup. Full and buttery, though mildly drying mouthfeel. Bittersweet chocolate and anise carry into a long, dry finish. Flavor rounds and sweetens predictably in three parts milk: buttery chocolate nuanced by continued suggestions of anise, flowers and plum.
Notes: Caffé Luxxe is an Italian-inflected artisan roaster and retailer that emphasizes both its coffee knowledge and precision and its straightforward lack of pretension. Visit www.caffeluxxe.com or call 310-394-2222 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: This bold-charactered espresso makes a hearty straight shot and contributes to a smooth, roundly chocolaty caffè latte.

Name: Aricha Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Natural Process
BlindReview: Distinctive, exotic. Complex fruit-mash sweetness (blueberry, strawberry, kiwi), pungent juniper, roasted cacao nib and jasmine in aroma and cup. Rich, round acidity; silky mouthfeel. Flavor surges in the short finish, fades, then rings on in the long.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is less predictable and deeper than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned Yirgacheffe profile. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy coffees that insist on being noticed.

Name: Kenya Makwa AB
BlindReview: Immensely rich and complex. Blood orange, black currant, dark chocolate, sandalwood, a hint of flowers in aroma and cup. Resonantly balanced, floral-toned acidity. Plush, lively mouthfeel. Deeply flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #4 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2014. Produced from trees of the admired Bourbon-derived SL 28 variety of Arabica as well as the hybrid Ruiru 11 variety. Despite grower discontent, confusing government coffee policy and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Klatch Coffee is an award-winning small-batch roasting company in the Los Angeles area whose resident barista and trainer, Heather Perry, won both the 2003 and 2007 United States Barista Championships brewing a Klatch Coffee espresso blend. Visit www.klatchroasting.com or call 877-455-2824 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Extraordinary coffee with the always astounding Kenya fusion of big, berry-toned sweetness with crisp, dry authority and aromatic depth and complexity.

Name: Kabirizi Rwanda
BlindReview: Softly and opulently pungent. Dark chocolate, Concord grape, fresh-cut cedar, hints of vanilla and cinnamon in aroma and cup. Round, rather lush acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a long, resonant finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica by the COOPAC cooperative (Cooperative pour la Promotion des Activities Café). Certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of the world’s specialty coffee roasters. Founded in 1990, Lexington Coffee is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Virginia. Lexington’s focus on fresh, flavorful and sustainable coffee is reflected in its motto, “Fresh, Flavorful & Fair.” Visit www.lexingtoncoffee.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy syrupy mouthfeel and resonant, low-toned complexity.

Name: Wahana Sumatra
Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra, Indonesia.
BlindReview: Apple cider, roasted pineapple, lush night flowers, a hint of crisp roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup. Tart but muted acidity; smooth, plush mouthfeel. The pineapple and apple cider notes carry into a very sweet finish.
Notes: This is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with the “wet-hulled” coffees more typical of northern Sumatra. Wahana Estate is a relatively new coffee farm in the classic Lintong growing district near Lake Toba. Founded in 1990, Lexington Coffee is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Virginia. Lexington’s focus on fresh, flavorful and sustainable coffee is reflected in its motto, “Fresh, Flavorful & Fair.” Visit www.lexingtoncoffee.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Coffee adventurers looking for quiet excitement. Unusual aroma and flavor, lush but crisp, cidery.

Name: Tolima Colombia
BlindReview: Delicate, lightly rich. Toffee, rose-like flowers, carob, a hint of fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Gently bright acidity; silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists impressively in a long, rather deep finish.
Notes: Founded in 1990, Lexington Coffee is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Virginia. Lexington’s focus on fresh, flavorful and sustainable coffee is reflected in its motto, “Fresh, Flavorful & Fair.” Visit www.lexingtoncoffee.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Try it for the distinct toffee-like character haloed by a rather deep, sweet floral note and pungent fir.

Name: Palanda Ecuador Organic
BlindReview: Pungent, gently lively. Caramel, roasted cacao nib, flowers, raisin, a hint of fresh-cut pine in aroma and cup. Quiet, backgrounded acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The cacao nib and caramel round toward a distinct chocolate in a lightly resonant finish.
Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and produced by small-holding farmers in the Loja growing region. Founded in 1990, Lexington Coffee is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Virginia. Lexington’s focus on fresh, flavorful and sustainable coffee is reflected in its motto, “Fresh, Flavorful & Fair.” Visit www.lexingtoncoffee.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a quietly lively cup from a relatively rare origin.

Name: Kenya Kabare AB
BlindReview: Sweet, pungent, with a deep, shifting complexity. Agave syrup, roasted cacao nib, lavender-like flowers, lemon drop and more in aroma and very sweet-toned cup. Richly tart, floral-toned acidity; light but buoyantly lively mouthfeel. Long, deep, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #17 coffee on Coffee Review’s ranking of the Top 30 Coffees of 2014.  From trees of the much-admired SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica as well as the hybrid Ruiru 11. Despite grower discontent, inconsistent government coffee policy and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Very sweet but superbly balanced structure and deep, engaging aromatics should please nearly everyone.

Name: Sumatra Wahana Natural Process
Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra, Indonesia.
BlindReview: Honey, blueberry, jasmine and a clean, rye-whisky-like note in aroma and cup. Rich, balanced acidity; syrupy but lively mouthfeel. The floral and whisky notes in particular last in a sweet-toned finish.
Notes: This is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with the “wet-hulled” coffees more typical of northern Sumatra. Wahana Estate is a relatively new coffee farm in the classic Lintong growing district near Lake Toba. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy refreshingly clean, whisky-toned fruit in the more balanced style of dried-in-the-fruit cup.

Name: Peaberry Reserve
BlindReview: Quietly balanced, complex. Butter, roasted cacao nib, flowers, tangerine, a deepening hint of musk. Sweetly crisp acidity; satiny mouthfeel. Flavor, flowers in particular, saturate a delicate but richly dry finish.
Notes: This blend combines, with originality and tact, coffees of the peaberry grade from three distinguished origins: a pulped natural from Brazil’s famous Daterra Farms, a Kenya Kabare, and a Tanzania Ruvuma. Peaberries are a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire. Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy white wines that that are both crisply dry and delicately and sweetly floral.

Name: Honduras Santa Barbara Beneficio San Vicente Caracolillo
BlindReview: Sweetly tart, complex. Blood orange, sweet chocolate, vanilla-toned flowers, a hint of almond in aroma and cup. Rich, complexly expressed acidity; light but distinctly syrupy mouthfeel. Orange and flowers carry into a crisp finish.
Notes: This sample, one of Victrola’s Reserve series of rare super-microlot coffees, consists entirely of peaberries (caracolillo or caracol in Latin-American Spanish), a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Honduras, until recently a largely overlooked Central American coffee origin, has been producing increasing volumes of fine coffee over the past few years. Victrola is a small-batch, hands-on roaster with a passionate commitment to quality and distinctiveness. Visit www.victrolacoffee.com or call 206-624-1725 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a classic but distinctive breakfast cup, zesty yet plush.

Name: Ferghana Horse Blend
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Richly sweet and balanced. Honey, roasted cacao-nib, blood orange, lavender and plum-blossom in aroma and small cup.  Lively, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Simplifies but maintains sweetness and depth in the finish. Flavors round but retain definition in three parts milk.
Notes: In addition to his retail roasting operation Aroma Roast Coffees, Simon Hsieh also operates Soaring Phoenix Trading, a business focused on purpose-built commercial espresso blends and high quality single-origin coffees. Visit www.facebook.com/4ArtsZeroDefectCoffees or call 886-0983-749876 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Straight espresso aficionados who enjoy resonant, sweet-toned flavor in their shots will particularly appreciate this versatile blend’s balance and range.

Name: Kenya Makwa AB
BlindReview: Intense and unmistakable Kenya character: dry yet sweet synthesis of pungent black currant, blackberry and fresh-cut cedar; backgrounded hints of lush night-blooming flowers, lemon, black sage. Big, sweetly brisk acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The Kenya flavor complex deeply saturates a long, rich finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #19 coffee on Coffee Review’s ranking of the Top 30 Coffees of 2014.  Produced from trees of the admired Bourbon-derived SL 28 variety of Arabica as well as the hybrid Ruiru 11 variety. Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Classic Kenya. Balanced in structure but with the Kenya aroma/flavor complex on steroids. If you don’t know Kenyas, try this one. If you do know Kenyas and you like them, don’t miss this one. Spectacular.

Name: Monk-Shot Tanzanian Peaberry (K-Cup compatible)
BlindReview: (As brewed in a Keurig B70 Platinum single-serve brewing device using a Keurig-compatible capsule to produce a 6-ounce serving): Briskly rich, balanced. Caramel, walnut, orange, dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Quiet, dry acidity; light but smooth, silky mouthfeel. The short finish is rather drying but in the long the walnut and chocolate and a gentle sweetness prevail.
Notes: This coffee is sold pre-ground in capsules that are compatible with the Keurig brewing system, but which use a different design from Keurig K-Cups. This sample was produced from a coffee consisting entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Mystic Monk Coffee is a small-batch roaster associated with a Carmelite monastery located in the Rocky Mountains of northern Wyoming. Roastmaster Brother Java emphasizes his artisan approach to roasting and his commitment to quality. Visit www.mysticmonkcoffee.com or call 877-751-6377 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A crisp, balanced cup for Keurig owners, nut- and chocolate-toned.

Name: Grade 1 Espresso Blend
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Pungently aromatic. Chocolate, oak, banana, grapefruit, a hint of night-blooming flowers in aroma and small cup. Lightly syrupy mouthfeel; bittersweet chocolate and a zesty grapefruit carry into a dry finish. In three parts milk, sweet and lightly flavor-saturated with distinct cocoa character.
Notes: Bicerin is a small-batch specialty coffee roaster located in Toronto, Canada with café and espresso bar.  Visit www.bicerincoffee.com or call 647-352-8550 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A versatile espresso. Hearty and strong-charactered as a straight shot; rounds and sweetens but remains lively in milk.

Name: El Salvador Santa Elena Honey Pacamara
BlindReview: Sweetly bright, lyric, exhilarating. Honey, peach, tangerine, night-blooming flowers, a hint of roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup. Deeply sweet, resonantly tart acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. The dry chocolate of the cacao nib note moves forward in a flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: This lot is comprised entirely of the much admired, bold-bean Pacamara variety of Arabica, a cross between the giant-beaned Maragogipe variety and Pacas, a selection of the heirloom Bourbon. This coffee was prepared by the honey method, meaning the skin was removed from the coffee fruit immediately after picking but the beans or seeds were dried with at least some of the fruit pulp or “honey” still adhering to them. Santa Elena, owned by Emilio Vasquez Landaverde, consistently delivers coffees that score in the top ten in the prestigious Cup of Excellence competitions held annually for El Salvador green coffees. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A classically bright cup enveloped in sweetness and heady aromatics. A breakfast cup with a major aromatic bonus.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe ECX Auction Lot
BlindReview: Gently bright, sweetly intense. Honey, grapefruit, lilac, cocoa butter in aroma and cup. Juicy, floral-toned acidity; silky mouthfeel. The grapefruit note and a more explicit chocolate dominate in a cleanly sweet finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. The ECX or Ethiopian Commodity Exchange was founded in April 2008 to discipline, regulate and bring transparency to the commodities market in Ethiopia, including the market for green coffee. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world.  Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy the natural sweetness and exhilarating citrus and flowers of a classic Yirgacheffe.

Name: Guatemala El Diamante Patricia Diaz Microlot
Origin: San Pedro Necta, Huehuetenango growing region, Guatemala.
BlindReview: Round, deeply sweet; layered complexity. Brown sugar, roasted nut (macadamia?) fresh-cut cedar, honeysuckle, a savory hint of musk in aroma and cup. Crisp, gentle acidity; very lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The finish is less distinguished by its flavor persistence than by its impressive nutty sweetness and resonant depth.
Notes: Produced entirely from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. El Diamante is a mother-and-daughter-owned farm. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world.  Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer resonance and layered complexity to bright intensity.

Name: Farm Girl
BlindReview: Bracing and dry. Caramel, roasted cacao nib, rose-like flowers, orange zest in aroma and cup. Cleanly tart acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates around the dry chocolate sensation in a simple but pleasing finish.
Notes: A distinguished blend roasted at PT’s Coffee, where the motto is “without the love, it’s just coffee.” Visit www.ptscoffee.com or call 888-678-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Lovers of light, dry white table wines.

Name: Apex Blend
BlindReview: Sweetly bright, gently complex. Honey, rose-like flowers, zesty orange, hints of moist pipe tobacco and walnut in aroma and cup. Buoyantly and sweetly tart acidity; silky, lively mouthfeel. Delicately dry, favor-saturated finish.
Notes: For every bag sold of this blend three dollars is donated to the Nelson Mandela Foundation. Torque Coffee is a small-batch coffee roaster based in Vancouver, Washington started in 2011 in a renovated garage that in years since has distinguished itself through careful sourcing and focused roasting. Visit www.torquecoffeeroasters.com  or call 971-200-5252 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a honey-toned, complexly refreshing morning cup.

Name: Lake Effect
BlindReview: Richly bright and citrusy. Ripe lime and brown-sugar sweetness dominate in aroma and cup, complicated by vanilla-like flowers and a softening suggestion of cocoa butter. Rich, juicy acidity; syrupy but lively mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a simple though gently citrus finish.
Notes: A blend of coffees from Kenya and from two growing regions in Ethiopia that together represent production from three cooperative groups, the Yukro Cooperative in Ethiopia, the Oromia Coffee Farmers Cooperative Union in Ethiopia, and the Barichu Cooperative in Kenya. Madcap Coffee is a small-batch roaster based in Grand Rapids Michigan specializing in sourcing and meticulously roasting distinctive high-quality coffees that help improve life from farm to cup. Visit www.madcapcoffee.com or call 888-866-9091 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a sweetly brisk, citrusy morning cup.

Name: Gingerbread Man Seasonal Espresso (reviewed for drip applications)
Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Ethiopia; Toraja growing region, Sulawesi, Indonesia; Costa Rica.
BlindReview: Sweet-toned, rich; delicately complex. Honey, almond, dark chocolate enlivened by floral top notes in aroma and cup. Deep, resonant acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate and flowers sustain nicely in a gently drying finish.
Notes: This blend is comprised of three distinctive origins. Designed for espresso cuisine, but reviewed here for drip and other brewed coffee applications. Donkey Café is an in store nano-roaster based in southern Taiwan that specializes in high-end coffees and fine baked goods. Email [email protected] or call 886-9-86551309 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer quiet, sweet-toned resonance to bright assertion.

Name: Gamut Espresso (reviewed for drip applications)
BlindReview: Sweet, round, complexly and delicately chocolaty. Milk chocolate, honey, floral-toned vanilla, almond in aroma and cup. Soft, backgrounded acidity; very lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists in a long, resonant finish.
Notes: Gamut is Chromatic Coffee’s flagship espresso. It is reviewed here for brewed or non-espresso applications, however. Chromatic prides itself in doing everything in-house and meticulously, from printing its attractive bags to modifying equipment to sourcing and roasting its fine coffees. Visit www.chromaticcoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those many coffee drinkers who enjoy a round, gently complex, sweetly chocolaty cup.

Name: Dream Blend
BlindReview: Lyric, delicate, yet deep. Apricot, roasted cacao nib, rich flowers (freesia?), almond butter in aroma and cup. Softly brisk acidity; light but very silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a rich, resonant finish.
Notes: This blend combines a washed or wet-processed Kenya coffee with two Ethiopia coffees, one a washed and one a dried-in-the-fruit “natural.” Bacca Café is a Taiwanese family-owned small café that roasts its own coffee and bakes its own pastries with sustained respect for the quality and provenance of green coffees and bakery ingredients. Call +886-6-580-6009 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A tribute to the blender’s art: delicately refined structure supports a quietly distinctive, layered complexity.

Name: Fragrance of Tranquility
Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia; Kenya; Mandheling growing region of Sumatra, Indonesia; other undisclosed origins.
BlindReview: Softly pungent; delicately complex. Honey, roasted cacao nib, vanilla, cherry- and peach-like fruit in aroma and cup. Smooth, poised acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists in a round, deep, gently drying finish.
Notes: This blend is a mélange, a blend in which constituent green coffees are brought to distinctly different roast levels or colors. GreenAlives is a Taiwan small-batch roasting company located in the Taishan District of New Taipei City that pursues quality in every act of coffee production from green coffee selection through storage, roasting and educating customers in optimum brewing practice. Visit www.greenalives.com or call +886-0921-884-579 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A very comprehensive cup: well-structured, crisply sweet, with a wide range of aromatic intrigue.

Name: Rite of Spring
BlindReview: Floral-toned; delicately and sweetly bright. Honeysuckle-like flowers, candied citrus zest, rounding caramel and carob in aroma and cup. Tartly sweet, lively acidity; full, syrupy though buoyant mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a delicately drying finish.
Notes: This blend combines a washed or wet-processed Kenya coffee with two Ethiopia coffees, one a washed and one a dried-in-the-fruit “natural.” Namusairo is a boutique café and artisan roaster founded in Seoul, South Korea in 2002. Visit www.namusairo.com for more information. Visit www.namusairo.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Lovers of bright, aromatic spring mornings.

Name: Ganesha Espresso (reviewed for drip applications)
BlindReview: Deep, complex, big-bodied. Night-blooming flowers, hazelnut, dark chocolate, fresh-cut oak in aroma and cup. Round though rather heavy acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate emerges clearly in a deeply sweet, nuanced finish.
Notes: Ganesha Espresso is Tony’s flagship espresso blend. In 2013 it was named “America’s Best Espresso” at a Seattle competition. It is reviewed here for non-espresso brewing; for a review of the same blend prepared as an espresso see our November 2013 review. Tony’s Coffee has been roasting in Bellingham, Washington since 1971. Visit www.tonyscoffee.com or call 800-448-8804 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer depth and complex chocolaty sweetness to the brighter, brisker, cleaner pleasures of many third-wave drip coffees.

Name: Est Drip Blend
Origin: Ethiopia; Costa Rica; Papua New Guinea.
BlindReview: Very sweet; deeply complex. Cane sugar, blueberry, lily-like flowers, crisp, almondy roasted cacao nib. Round, gently nuanced acidity; lightly syrupy, lively mouthfeel. The cacao nib rounds to distinct chocolate in a long, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: At least one of the coffees in this distinctive blend, probably the Ethiopia, brings a lush, blueberry-toned character to the mix. Café Est is a micro-roaster located in New Taipei City, Taiwan, owned by Ricky Liu who takes coffee quality and roasting very seriously, applying the same passion for them as he lavishes on his second favorite activity, surfing. Call +886-2-2945-1611 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Tribute both to the distinctive quality of the component coffees and the blender’s art: Clearly articulated but intricate structure, broad-ranging aromatics. No single-origin coffee I know of offers quite the same package.

Name: Three Africans
Origin: Yirgacheffe and Sidamo (also Sidama) growing regions, southern Ethiopia; Uganda.
BlindReview: Very complex; big-bodied. Blueberry, ripe lemon, dark chocolate, hints of bourbon whisky and musk in aroma and cup. Round, quietly resonant acidity; syrupy, gently lively mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but lingers in a rich finish.
Notes: Certified organically grown. This popular Blue Bottle blend combines a wet-processed Uganda with a wet-processed Ethiopia Yirgacheffe and a dry-processed or "natural" Ethiopia Sidamo. Blue Bottle Coffee started as the quintessential boutique coffee business: a micro-roasting operation in Oakland housed inside a space about as large as a suburban walk-in closet and a single retail location in San Francisco. Since its founding Blue Bottle has attracted a strong following in the San Francisco Bay Area and beyond, and now operates two roasting locations: one in Oakland, California and another in Brooklyn, New York. Visit www.bluebottlecoffee.com or call 510-653-3394 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Distinctive but versatile blend (pleasing with whitener or without) with a wide stance: simultaneously displays a lemony brightness, blueberry and chocolate sweetness, and a savory musk.

Name: Espresso Blend Spring 14
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Striking flavors. Oak, banana, lavender, dark chocolate, apricot, lime zest in aroma and small cup. Full in texture though a bit sharp in mouthfeel. Dark chocolate and lavender carry into a richly drying finish. Sweet and flavor-saturated in three parts milk.
Notes: GreenAlives is a Taiwan small-batch roasting company located in the Taishan District of New Taipei City that pursues quality in every act of coffee production from green coffee selection through storage, roasting and educating customers in optimum brewing practice.  Visit www.greenalives.com or call +886-0921-884-579 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a drying but very complex and densely textured straight shot; rounds and sweetens pleasingly in short milk.

Name: Peru Cajamarca
BlindReview: Gentle, quietly complete. Plum, honeysuckle, crisp walnut and roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup. Soft, delicately juicy acidity; satiny mouthfeel. Gently flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Produced by small-holding farmers from trees of traditional varieties of Arabica. Beansmith Coffee is a small-batch roasting company serving the Omaha region that believes that coffee drinkers should know as much as they can about the coffee they drink, and that there is a story behind every cup, one worth exploring.  Visit www.beansmith.com or call 866-663-5295 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy balance, delicacy and subtle complexity in a classic American-style breakfast cup.

Name: Organic Bali Kintamani Natural
BlindReview: Intensely sweet and fruit-toned. Brown sugar, dark chocolate, strawberry, hazelnut, a hint of mint in aroma and cup. Roundly rich acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish is impressively sweet and flavor-saturated, though it simplifies and dries out a bit in the long. Two of five cups we sampled were slightly less sweet and more astringent than those upon which this general description was based; owing to this unevenness we deducted two points from the overall rating, dropping it from 92 to 90. Still, an impressively lush, voluptuous coffee.
Notes: Produced in the central highlands of the colorful island of Bali, this is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees.
