Crimson Cup is a micro-roaster based in Columbus dedicated to offering high quality coffee and to helping independent cafes brew and serve it better. Visit www.crimsoncup.com or call 614-262-6212 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Adventurers with a sweet tooth.

Name: Kenya Kalilani
BlindReview: Pungent, deep, complex. Honey, raspberry, roasted cacao nib, fresh-cut pine in aroma and cup. Delicate, sweetly balanced acidity; silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but lasts in a very sweet-toned, slightly drying finish.
Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Big Shoulders Coffee is a Chicago artisan roaster that emphasizes its fresh-roasted, no-nonsense approach to fine coffee. Visit www.bigshoulderscoffee.com or call 312-888-3042 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy depth and resonance in a cup that complicates seductive sweetness with a savory pungency.

Name: Ethiopian Sidamo Kellenso
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Complex and brandy-toned. Minty dark chocolate, papaya-like fruit, hints of musk and sweetly pungent fir in aroma and cup. Brisk but juicy acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Richly sweet though drying in the finish.
Notes: This Ethiopian coffee is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Crimson Cup is a micro-roaster based in Columbus dedicated to offering high quality coffee and to helping independent cafes brew and serve it better. Visit www.crimsoncup.com or call 614-262-6212 for more information. Visit www.crimsoncup.com or call 614-262-6212 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A crisply (and skillfully) light-roasted version of the fruit-and-brandy style of southern Ethiopia natural-processed cup.

Name: Ethiopia Ninety Plus Pheribo N2
Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, Gedeo Zone, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Crisply sweet, exhilaratingly complex. Peach, mint, lily, roasted cacao nib, a hint of rye whisky in aroma and cup. The acidity is breathtakingly sweet and buoyantly light-footed; the mouthfeel full but lively. Flavor consolidates but rings on in a long, gentle finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #18 coffee on Coffee Review’s ranking of the Top 30 Coffees of 2014.  This Yirgacheffe is an extraordinarily refined version of a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Ninety Plus is a very distinguished boutique producer and importer of innovative small-lot coffees from Ethiopia and Panama. Namusairo is a small-batch specialty roaster based in Seoul, South Korea, specializing in very high-end micro-lots with an emphasis on sustainable practices and unique flavors. Visit www.namusairo.com or call + 82-10-3383-5717 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Striking coffee, both in the balance, sweetness and completeness of its structure as well as in its exhilarating range of sensory suggestion.

Name: Kenya Ndaroini Nyeri
BlindReview: Sweetly tart, briskly complex. Honey, lilac, vanilla-toned chocolate, ripe strawberry in aroma and cup. Richly tart acidity; very lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The acidy brightness softens in a long, resonant, floral-toned finish.
Notes: From trees of the much-admired SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica. Despite stresses brought on by social unrest, charges of corruption and a confused transition toward an open market, the famed Kenya coffee auction system and its participating cooperatives continue to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Roasted at PT’s Coffee, where the motto is “without the love, it’s just coffee.” Visit www.ptscoffee.com or call 888-678-5282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy gently bracing, sweet-toned acidity in beverages, as displayed in certain dry white table wines, for example. This sensation is elegantly and complexly expressed here.

Name: Ethiopia Zonegediyo Kochere Yirga Cheffe
BlindReview: Big, sweetly pungent, complex. Brown sugar, dark chocolate, walnut, narcissus-like flowers, savory hints of mango and musk in aroma and cup. Rich, resonant acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Deeply flavor-saturated finish, drying but long and sweet.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on floral notes. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: An unusually deep and resonantly authoritative version of the Yirgacheffe cup; the flowers are still there, but they show an almost carnal richness.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Sidama Shilcho Coop G1
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Sweet-toned and buoyant; delicately pungent. Moist pipe tobacco, guava-like fruit, honey, rose-like flowers in aroma and cup. Gentle, complexly expressed acidity; silky, very lively mouthfeel. The floral notes in particular carry into a sweet, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: From the Shilcho cooperative. G1 refers to Grade 1, the highest grade of Ethiopia coffee. Processed by the orthodox wet or “washed” method, in which the fruit residue is removed or “washed” from the beans immediately after picking and before drying. This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer their coffees gentle but exhilaratingly complex.

Name: Sumatra Lake Tawar Screen 19 Plus TP
Origin: Aceh growing region, northwestern Sumatra, Indonesia.
BlindReview: Sweet-toned, pungent, heavy. Prominent notes of fresh-cut oak, carob and sweet cherry with subtle malt and vanilla suggestions in aroma, and more pungently, in the cup. Brisk but backgrounded acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a rich but drying finish.
Notes: Lake Tawar is situated in a crater valley at the heart of the Aceh growing region near the far northwestern tip of the island of Sumatra. 19 Plus refers to a grade of coffee representing only beans of the very largest size, screen 19 or up. Kakalove Cafe is a nano-roaster located the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the finest quality coffee. Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who appreciate a richly pungent though refined version of the classic Sumatra profile.

Name: Big Papua Espresso
Origin: Western Highlands, Papua New Guinea; Huehuetenango, Guatemala.
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Pungently bright, lively. Ripe citrus, anise, dark chocolate, fresh-cut cedar in aroma and small cup. Lightly syrupy mouthfeel; flavor saturates a crisply dry finish. In three parts milk the chocolate blooms gently with continued hints of citrusy brightness.
Notes: This blend is 75% Papua New Guinea coffee from the Whagi Valley in the Western Highlands, and 25% is Guatemalan coffee from a ‘slow-food’ presidium representing four cooperatives and over 150 farmers in Huehuetenango. Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria, Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees from the roasting process to the cup.  Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a richly bright, lively straight shot or a chocolaty but still gently citrusy cappuccino.

Name: Caffe Primo
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Crisply rich, dense-bodied, slightly smoky. Dark chocolate, cedar, roasted almond, a hint of flowers in aroma and small cup. Very full, dry mouthfeel. Dark chocolate carries into a rich though drying finish. Smoothes out in three parts milk; a sweet chocolate dominates with continued smoky and cedary complications.
Notes: V. Coffee is a Shanghai based roaster established in 2008, they focus on high-quality all Arabica coffee with an Austrian roasting style. Visit www.v-coffee.com or call +86-400-8200-273 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A big-bodied, dry but chocolaty straight shot espresso with enough presence to stand up to tall milk and syrups.

Name: Aramo Grade 1 Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Natural
BlindReview: Sweet, richly complex. Honeysuckle, watermelon, strawberry, hints of pungent sandalwood and roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup. Deep, floral-toned acidity; lightly syrupy, lively mouthfeel. Flowers and a rather chocolaty cacao nib in particular carry into a resonant finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a dry-processed or "natural" Yirgacheffe, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" versions. Blueprint Coffee is a one-location roastery-café in St. Louis, Missouri that aims at producing a small number of flawless and distinctive coffees. Visit www.blueprintcoffee.com or call 888-863-8053 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A sweetly balanced, refreshingly complex dried-in-the-fruit coffee, versatile and agreeable.

Name: Colombia Guadalupe
BlindReview: Richly pungent. Dusk-blooming flowers, peach, hazelnut, moist, freshly-cut wood in aroma and cup. Roundly muted acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Some flavor persists in a clean finish.
Notes: Topéca Coffee is an artisan roaster with three café locations and a roastery in Tulsa, Oklahoma.Visit www.topecacoffee.com or call 918-398-8022 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Quietly unusual cup with its foresty suggestions of dusk flowers and fresh wet wood.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Yirgacheffe “Mini-Me” 2014
BlindReview: Immense, complex aromatics. Floral notes stretch from lush narcissus to crisp lavender; fruit from orange to sweet papaya. Honey, pungent sandalwood, roasted cacao nib. Richly tart, cleanly wine-like acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Richly dry, deeply flower-saturated finish with a slight savory edge.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #8 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2014. Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on fruit and floral notes. In addition to his retail roasting operation Aroma Roast Coffees, Simon Hsieh also operates Soaring Phoenix Trading, a business focused on purposed-built commercial espresso blends and high quality single-origin coffees. Visit www.facebook.com/4ArtsZeroDefectCoffees or call 886-0983-749876 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Big, balanced structure supports an exhilarating range and depth of aroma and flavor. A Yirgacheffe as strong as it is graceful.

Name: Orion Espresso Blend
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly intense. Carob, prune, brown sugar and moist tobacco leaf delicately expressed in aroma and pungently in the small cup with further complications of lime, cherry and cedar. Lightly smooth, creamy mouthfeel; the tobacco and cedar carry with particular clarity into the finish. Three parts milk rounds the carob and brown sugar to a sweet chocolate nuanced by the fruit and tobacco.
Notes: Spyhouse Coffee Roasting emphasizes passion through knowledge and attention to building relationships within and around the coffee community. Visit www.spyhousecoffee.com or call 612-345-4348 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Complex straight shot, but may be at its best in cappuccino and short milk beverages.

Name: Guatemala Finca Santa Isabel
BlindReview: Sweet, gentle, original. Fresh-cut oak, honey, dark chocolate, peach, lily-like flowers in aroma and cup. Softly tart acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate in particular saturates a deep, rich short finish with some fading in the long.
Notes: From the Valdes family farm in the moist, diverse Coban region. Water Avenue Coffee is a tiny roastery nestled next to the railway in the old Industrial Southeast quarter in Portland, Oregon. Visit www.wateravenuecoffee.com or call 503-808-7083 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Fresh, sweet, gently spicy wood notes complicated by lily and peach should please those who prefer to be coddled rather than jolted awake by their morning cup.

Name: Borena Ethiopia
Origin: Borena Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, souther Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Sweetly pungent, richly floral. Roasted cacao nib, spicy rose, peach and blackberry in aroma and cup. Gently bright, vivacious acidity; very silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a quietly rich though drying finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on floral notes. Spyhouse Coffee Roasting emphasizes passion through knowledge and attention to building relationships within and around the coffee community. Visit www.spyhousecoffee.com or call 612-345-4348 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A particularly spicy and rich version of the great Yirgacheffe profile; sounds like the holidays to us.

Name: Bliss of Gayo
Origin: Gayo growing region, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.
BlindReview: Sweetly rich, deep. Dusk-blooming flowers, buttery dark chocolate, fresh pipe tobacco, banana-like fruit in aroma and cup. Roundly tart acidity; lightly syrupy, lively mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but rings on in a sweetly balanced finish.
Notes: In addition to his retail roasting operation Aroma Roast Coffees, Simon Hsieh also operates Soaring Phoenix Trading, a business focused on purposed-built commercial espresso blends and high quality single-origin coffees. Visit www.facebook.com/4ArtsZeroDefectCoffees or call 886-0983-749876 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A deeply sweet version of the great Sumatra profile; the famous earth notes here come across as moist pipe tobacco supporting lavish floral and a soft, banana-like fruit.

Name: San Formosan Estate
BlindReview: Sweet and gently spicy. Brown sugar, roasted walnut, tangerine-like fruit, spearmint, a hint of flowers in aroma and cup. Soft, rounded acidity. Lightly plush mouthfeel. Sweet, clean, simple finish.
Notes: This coffee is the result of a project to develop Taiwanese-grown coffee as a specialty origin. The coffee is grown by small producers who are largely indigenous peoples, and is roasted and retailed in Taiwan.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Taiwanese who want to support the production of their own local specialty coffee, curious aficionados from other countries, and anyone who enjoys a gently spicy, sweet-toned cup.

Name: Kenya Nyeri Tegu
BlindReview: Sweetly pungent, balanced but deep. Dark chocolate, plum-like fruit, hints of lemony citrus and savory baking spice in aroma and cup. Plush, delicately rich acidity; silky, lively mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists in a roundly resonant finish.
Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Tegu is a cooperatively owned and operated wet mill or “washing station” particularly admired for its meticulous fruit harvesting and sorting. Mt. Whitney Coffee Roasters sources, imports and roasts top coffees from around the globe; it is a 501-C3 non-profit that donates all profit after expenses to fund schools and food and well-drilling programs in Africa. Visit www.mtwhitneycoffee.com or call 800-873-1763 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who value both balance and intensity in a quietly distinctive Kenya.

Name: Konga Yirgacheffe Ethiopia
Origin: Konga District, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Intensely and complexly floral – lavender, rose, jasmine – with some citrus complication and rounded by a caramelly chocolate. Richly tart acidity; lightly but distinctly syrupy mouthfeel. Lemon and flowers carry into a deep finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. “Great coffee. Full tilt” is the motto of Whipsaw Coffee, a small-batch roaster newly established in Canada’s southernmost city and dedicated to selecting green beans from all over the world and roasting them in a way that highlights the natural characteristics of each coffee. Visit www.whipsawcoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy the soaring and intense Yirgacheffe aromatic fireworks full on; in fact, full tilt.

Name: Kona Extra Fancy
Origin: Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawaii.
BlindReview: Round, deep, gently roasty, chocolaty. Cedar, dark chocolate, a hint of rich grape-like fruit and fresh pipe tobacco in aroma and cup. Rich, backgrounded acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate carries into a simple but resonant finish.
Notes: Extra Fancy is the highest grade of Kona coffee based on bean size and freedom from physical imperfections. Kona Coffee Purveyors roasts only the finest Kona coffee, and rigorously pursues a program of fresh roasting and prompt shipping so that U.S. consumers can rely on receiving their Kona coffee an optimal two to three days after roasting.  Visit www.konacoffeepurveyors.com or call 877-771-5662 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Slightly darkish medium roast develops the chocolate in a round, deep, plump-bodied version of the Kona cup.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Konga
BlindReview: Intense, elegant. Mint, lilac-like flowers, dark chocolate, pungent juniper berry in aroma and cup. Sweetly brisk, complexly expressed acidity; lightly syrupy, lively mouthfeel. Chocolate in particular carries into a rich though drying finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed Yirgacheffe, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is lower-toned and more pungent than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned profile. The West Bean is a San Diego-based roastery founded by two friends with a passion for coffee and a determination to bring their customers the highest quality hand-crafted coffee possible. Visit www.thewestbean.com or call 619-709-3232 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Exhilarating range of sensation in this moderately dark-roasted Yirgacheffe, ranging from perfumy lilac to juniper-like pungency.

Name: Panama Los Lajones Bambu Geisha
BlindReview: Immense, intricate. Honey, roasted cacao nib, orchid-like flowers, layers of fruit (banana, mango, mandarin), pungent sandalwood in aroma and cup. Crisply juicy, nuanced acidity; lively, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Fruit, flowers and cacao linger far into a richly drying finish.
Notes: Reviewed in December of 2013, this exceptional coffee was selected as the #5 coffee on Coffee Review’s list of the Top 30 Coffees of 2014. Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also spelled Geisha). With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral, fruit and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world's rarest and most unique coffees. This is a dry-processed or "natural" Gesha, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Anyone who can afford this soaringly complex yet perfectly structured cup. Brew this precious coffee carefully.

Name: Kenya Githembe AA
BlindReview: Delicately and sweetly pungent. Night-blooming flowers, caramel, raisin, with a cranberry tartness in aroma and cup. Lively, buoyant acidity; very light but silky mouthfeel. Hints of cranberry and caramel carry into a very sweet though drying finish.
Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. AA is the highest grade of Kenya coffee based on size of bean and freedom from physical imperfections. Gracenote Coffee is a small coffee roaster in Berlin, Massachusetts dedicated to making every roast better through coffee literacy, continuous and vigorous sensory analysis, and by caring a whole lot. Visit www.gracenotecoffee.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Delicately, refreshingly brisk yet sweetly floral version of the great Kenya profile.

Name: Espresso Strata
BlindReview: Reviewed as espresso. Rich, round, big. Dark chocolate, fresh-cut cedar, peach-like fruit, orange zest in aroma and small cup. Full, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate carries into a resonant though drying finish. Retains its rather massive mouthfeel and cedary chocolate in three parts milk, though shows best in taller milk.
Notes: This blend is Red Rock’s “Seattle-style” espresso blend particularly designed for tall milk drinks. Red Rock Roasters was founded in Albuquerque, New Mexico in 1993 in a family barn and remains family-owned and focused on quality and freshness.  Visit www.redrockroasters.com or call 800-873-9793 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy big-bodied straight shots and milk drinks. Should be able to wave the flag for coffee even in tall, syrupy milk drinks.

Name: Arabica Wild Kopi Luwak
BlindReview: Richly pungent. Sandalwood, apricot, dark chocolate, plum blossom, musk and chanterelle-like mushroom in aroma and savory-edged cup. Rich and plump though simple acidity; lightly smooth mouthfeel. Finish rounds in crisp sandalwood and chocolate.
Notes: A version of the famous Kopi Luwak, the world's most notorious coffee. The beans are harvested from the feces of a species of civet cat native to Sumatra that eats ripe coffee fruit. This particular version is represented as having been harvested entirely from the droppings of wild, rather than caged, civets. The Bantuan Coffee Foundation is a Netherlands-based organization dedicated to ending child slavery and trafficking in Indonesia. A minimum of 50% of the purchase price of this coffee supports projects dedicated to stopping that abuse. Visit www.bantuancoffee.org for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: True, Kopi Luwak is a novelty splurge, but if you want to splurge on a sensitively roasted version of this novelty with characteristically rounded acidity and authentically deep, fruity and musky/mushroomy aroma and flavor this version is a good choice, a choice that furthermore supports a good cause.

Name: Love Letter for Winter Holiday
BlindReview: Delicate and brisk. Honey, fresh-cut pine, peach, hints of flowers and oolong tea in aroma and cup. Gently brisk acidity; buoyant, silky mouthfeel. A savory hint in the cup carries into a crisply tart finish.
Notes: The blend name ‘Love Letter’ suggests the gift of coffee. Namusairo is a small-batch specialty roaster based in Seoul, South Korea, specializing in very high-end micro-lots with an emphasis on sustainable practices and unique flavors. Visit www.namusairo.com or call + 82-10-3383-5717 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy delicately brisk beverages with subtle, sweetly pungent aromatics.

Name: Holiday Blend
BlindReview: Delicately pungent and honey-toned. Roasted cacao nib, honey, sandalwood, a hint of lush, night-blooming flowers in aroma and cup. Richly bright, bittersweet acidity; lively, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Cacao nib and flowers in particular carry into a resonant, slightly drying finish.
Notes: A blend of wet-processed and dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” coffees. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those holiday blend buyers who value a lighter roasted coffee that emphasizes with elegance and tact the honey, floral and cocoa side of the holiday culinary myth.

Name: Sumatra Aceh Takengon
BlindReview: Crisply and sweetly pungent. Papaya, mango, orange zest, candied walnut, a hint of moist leaf tobacco in aroma and cup. Round, juicy acidity; plush mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists in a resonant finish.
Notes: Coffees from the northern part of the Indonesian island of Sumatra are admired for their complex fruit, earth and aromatic wood notes that result largely from unorthodox fruit removal and drying practices called “wet hulling.” This coffee is a particularly refined example of the type. Compelling & Rich Coffee is uncompromisingly dedicated to offering only small lots of selectively sourced fine single-origin coffees freshly roasted.  Visit www.compellingrich.com or call 818-835-5135 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy the newer refined style of Sumatra: deep, exotic, but balanced.

Name: Original Christmas, Nicks Holiday Favorite, Organic
BlindReview: Big, sweet and fruity with a savory, spicy edge. Guava- and pineapple-like fruit, brandy, dark chocolate, a hint of flowers and bay leaf or eucalyptus in aroma and cup. Round, vibrant acidity; heavy, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate, brandy and bay leaf in particular carry into a rich though drying finish.
Notes: A blend of two distinguished dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia coffees, a Gedeo Worka from the Worka cooperative in Yirgacheffe and an Amaro Gayo from Asnakech Thomas’s famous mill in the Sidamo/Sidama region. Both are dry-processed or "natural" coffees, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, these striking and unusual coffees were produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Klatch Coffee is an award-winning small-batch roasting company in the Los Angeles area whose resident barista and trainer, Heather Perry, won both the 2003 and 2007 United States Barista Championships brewing a Klatch Coffee espresso blend. Visit www.klatchroasting.com or call 877-455-2824 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Holidays for sure here: fruit, spice, brandy, big body.

Name: Holiday Blend
Origin: Central Valley growing region, Costa Rica; Huila Province, Colombia.
BlindReview: Rich, fruit and brandy. Cherry, blueberry, milk chocolate, brandy, lily-like flowers in aroma and cup. Lively, effervescent acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Rich and sweet in the short finish, slightly drying in the long.
Notes: A blend of a Costa Rica coffee from the distinguished Lomas Al Rio mill and a Colombian coffee produced by the OCCICAFE cooperative in the La Plata region of Huila, Colombia. Olympia Coffee Roasting is a small-batch wholesale and retail roasting company with a youthful, no-nonsense style and a commitment to high-quality organic coffees.  Visit www.olympiacoffeeroasting.com or call 360-753-0066 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: The out-front and expressive fruit, brandy and flowers that dominate cup and aroma should make a nice fit with holiday brunches and desserts.

Name: Panama Finca La Mula Geisha Natural
BlindReview: Softly lush, complex flowers, crisp roasted cacao nib, tangerine-like citrus, apple cider in aroma and cup. Gently bright, juicy acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The apple cider suggestion is particularly distinct in a slightly drying though resonant, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also spelled Geisha). With its elegantly elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world's most unique coffees. This is a dry-processed or "natural" version of the Gesha, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Finca La Mula is a quality-focused micro-farm owned by coffee consultant and educator Willem Boot (co-owner of Equator’s Finca Sofia in Panama) and managed by Kelly Hartmann of the multi-generational Hartmann coffee farming family. Equator is a specialty roaster based in the San Francisco Bay Area driven by “passion for quality and sustainability.” Visit www.equatorcoffees.com or call 800-809-7687 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: The aromatic fireworks are crisp and balanced in this version of the celebrated Gesha profile. The clean dried-in-the-fruit processing contributes a delightfully refreshing apple cider note.

Name: Holiday Blend
Origin: Central Kenya; Toraja growing region, southwestern Sulawesi, Indonesia.
BlindReview: Deeply but vivaciously expressed complexity. Raspberry-like fruit, roasted cacao nib, honey, narcissus-like flowers, a hint of pungent sandalwood in aroma and cup. Round, juicy acidity; syrupy yet lively mouthfeel. Long, rich, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: This fine coffee was selected as the #7 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013.This extraordinary Holiday blend owes its distinctiveness to two very distinguished coffees, a Kenya AA Rumikia Blackberry and the rare Sulawesi AA Toarco Toraja. Sulawesi Toarco is a fully wet-processed coffee, unlike the typical wet-hulled coffees produced in Sulawesi and elsewhere in Indonesia. Located in Everett, Washington, north of Seattle, Velton's Coffee is a quality-focused small-batch wholesale roaster. Visit www.veltonscoffee.com or call 206-250-6130 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Superb balance, complete structure and deeply expressed aroma and flavor should impress aficionados while seducing any casual coffee drinkers around the holiday table.

Name: Organic Ethiopian Yirgacheffe Idido
BlindReview: Explosively bright and juicy. Honey, tangerine, black currant, hints of flowers and spice, mace perhaps, in aroma and cup. Opulently sweet, grandly exhilarating acidity; lightly but distinctly syrupy mouthfeel. Gently dry, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #15 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. This coffee is certified organically grown and processed at the famous Idido cooperative. Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. Wonderstate Coffee, formerly Kickapoo Coffee, is an award-winning roaster based in rural Wisconsin known for their commitment to guaranteeing higher pay for farmers and being the country’s first 100% solar powered roastery. Visit https://wonderstate.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: An aficionado’s essay in the pleasures of big, resonant, lavishly sweet acidity and simple but deeply expressed aroma and flavor.

Name: Panama Gesha Perci Red
BlindReview: Intoxicating, juicy, complete. Dark honey; dark rum; dark chocolate; complex, layered fruit, particularly pineapple and melon; narcissus-like flowers. Intense but juicy acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Sweetly rich finish turns slightly drying but still flavor-saturated in the long.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #3 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also spelled Geisha). With its elegantly elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world's most unique coffees. This is a dry-processed or "natural" version of the Gesha, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. This particular Gesha is produced on the Ninety Plus Gesha Estates. Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast. Visit www.barringtoncoffee.com or call 800-528-0998 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: An amazing coffee, with an immense range and depth of sensation.

Name: Kikai Kenya
BlindReview: Intense, rich, pungent. Blood orange, black currant, fresh-cut fir, plum blossom in aroma and in cup, where a slight savory, truffle-like edge deepens and complicates flavor. Powerful but opulently balanced acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Resonant, gently drying, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #13 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. From the slopes of Mt. Elgon in far western Kenya rather than from the more familiar growing regions of central Kenya. Produced by the nearly 2,000 very small-holding members of the Kikai cooperative. Founded in 1990, Lexington Coffee is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Virginia. Lexington’s focus on fresh, flavorful and sustainable coffee is reflected in its motto, “Fresh, Flavorful & Fair.” Visit www.lexingtoncoffee.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy the deep, richly pungent, fruit-toned but slightly savory side of the Kenya profile. Lovers of big, complexly balanced red table wines may be particularly good candidates for this coffee.

Name: Sumatra Lintong Dolok Sanggul
Origin: Dolok Sanggul, Lintong growing area, northern Sumatra, Indonesia
BlindReview: Molasses, fresh-cut fir, papaya, orange and baking spice, particularly thyme, in aroma and sweet-toned, very slightly savory-edged cup. Roundly bright, juicy acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists richly in a clean, deep finish.
Notes: Coffees from the northern part of the Indonesian island of Sumatra are admired for their complex earth (spice in this case), fruit and aromatic wood notes that result largely from unorthodox fruit removal and drying practices collectively called wet hulling. This is a particularly refined version of the style. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a complex, rather exotic cup dominated by molasses-like sweetness, tropical fruit and a hint of spice.

Name: El Salvador Finca Malacara Lot B
Origin: Volcan de Santa Ana region, El Salvador.
BlindReview: Complex, delicately distinctive. Rose-like flowers, sweet carob, malt, orangy citrus in aroma and cup. Rich, rather opulent acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Hints of citrus and malty carob carry into a sweet-toned though drying finish.
Notes: Finca Malacara, an old and celebrated El Salvador coffee farm, was divided into three farms (A, B, and C) in 1955. This lot, from farm B, is composed entirely of coffee from the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A light roast develops a sweet yet crisply drying cup with delicate, unusual aromatics.

Name: Real Inspiration Blend
BlindReview: Deep, sweetly pungent. Dark chocolate, molasses, fresh-cut oak, hints of orange and spearmint in aroma and cup. Round, quiet acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Rich, chocolate-toned finish.
Notes: The coffees comprising this blend are Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning they were produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee.  Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: This roundly deep, chocolaty blend should provide considerable rich winter inspiration.

Name: S.O. Espresso Mexico Santa Teresa
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Deep, shifting complexity. Dark chocolate, hazelnut, a hint of night-blooming flowers in aroma and small cup. An apricot-like note in the aroma brightens and turns delicately citrusy in the small cup and in a sweetly drying, chocolate-toned finish. Buoyant, creamy mouthfeel. Chocolate dominates in three parts milk, crisply sweet and nut-toned.
Notes: Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Impressive balance and layered complexity in this quiet but authoritative single-origin espresso should please those who take their espresso as straight shot or in short milk.

Name: Lycello Panama Gesha
BlindReview: Delicate but rich; shimmeringly complex. Meyer lemon, jasmine, honey, walnut in aroma and cup. Crisply sweet acidity; silky mouthfeel. Surprisingly deep, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also spelled Geisha). With its elegantly elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, citrusy, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world's most unique coffees. This particular Gesha is produced on the Ninety Plus Gesha Estates. Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast.  Visit www.barringtoncoffee.com or call 800-528-0998 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Precious, delicate, refined, with a quietly layered complexity.

Name: Kenya Gichuka AA
BlindReview: Richly and deeply floral: lavender, narcissus, honey, with contrasting crisp hints of dry fruit: black currant, juniper berry. Big, buoyant acidity; full, velvety mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a quiet, balanced finish.
Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. AA is the highest grade of Kenya coffee based on size of bean and freedom from physical imperfections. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world. Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Richly floral variant on the great Kenya profile offers complex structure, big but balanced acidity, plush mouthfeel.

Name: Kimel Papua New Guinea Peaberry
Origin: Wahgi Valley, central Papua New Guinea.
BlindReview: Quietly but deeply layered complexity. Dark chocolate, black currant, fresh-cut cedar, hints of mint and cumin in aroma and cup. Buoyantly floral-toned acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate and cedar carry into a richly round finish.
Notes: Kimel Plantation is owned and operated by the indigenous Opais people. The high mountain valleys of central Papua New Guinea offer some of the world's most favorable terroirs for production of fine coffee, although the rugged terrain presents daunting transportation and infrastructure challenges. This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Founded in 1990, Lexington Coffee is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Virginia. Lexington’s focus on fresh, flavorful and sustainable coffee is reflected in its motto, “Fresh, Flavorful & Fair.” Visit www.lexingtoncoffee.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those aficionados and others interested in sampling the roundly pungent fruit and rich coherence of a classic Papua New Guinea cup.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffee Konga
Origin: Konga District, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Deeply and richly floral-toned, complicated by crisp roasted cacao nib, orangy citrus and hint of gin-like spirits. Rich, deeply expressed acidity; syrupy but lively mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a rich, slightly drying finish.
Notes: A “natural” or dry-processed coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is lower-toned and more pungent than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned southern Ethiopia profile. Founded in 1990, Lexington Coffee is an award-winning artisan roasting company based in Virginia. Lexington’s focus on fresh, flavorful and sustainable coffee is reflected in its motto, “Fresh, Flavorful & Fair.” Visit www.lexingtoncoffee.com or call 800-322-6505 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Fine and distinctive version of the newer dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia style, with a slight shimmer of ferment enlivening a richly and cleanly floral- and cacao-toned cup.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Yirgacheffe Mini-Me
BlindReview: Perfumy, rose-like floral notes, spicy sandalwood, ripe raspberry, moist pipe tobacco in a deep yet buoyant aroma and flavor. Richly crisp, balanced acidity; silky mouthfeel. Flavor carries deep into a resonant finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on fruit and floral notes. In addition to his retail roasting operation Aroma Roast Coffees, Simon Hsieh also operates Soaring Phoenix Trading, a business focused on purposed-built commercial espresso blends and high quality single-origin coffees. Visit www.facebook.com/4ArtsZeroDefectCoffees or call 886-0983-749876 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Superb variant on the great Yirgacheffe cup: deep, resonant, exotic.

Name: Espresso Blend
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Sweet, delicate, balanced. Vanilla, orange, citrus flowers and roasted cacao nib are lightly expressed in aroma and deeply in the small cup. Smoothly silky, lively mouthfeel; crisply resonant finish. Flavor carries well into three parts milk: almondy orange, cacao nib, flowers.
Notes: With two locations in Southern California's Orange County, Kéan Coffee is an in-house coffee roaster and retailer established by Martin Diedrich of the distinguished Diedrich coffee family. The Kéan slogan, "Martin knows his beans" should be true, considering Martin grew up in Guatemala where his family owned a coffee farm. Visit www.keancoffee.com or call 949-933-9164 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: This gently bright and lively espresso should particularly please high-note purists, though everyone should enjoy its sweetness, balance and understated, graceful complexity.

Name: Kenya French Mission Oreti Estate
BlindReview: Crisp but juicy. Dark chocolate, raspberry, ripe plum, walnut in aroma and cup. Balanced, rich acidity; light but silky mouthfeel. The finish is bittersweet and slightly drying with walnut and chocolate hints.
Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. French Mission is an heirloom, Bourbon-related East Africa tree variety. This is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees through the roasting process all the way to the cup.  Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a crisply dry but complexly juicy, fruit-toned cup.

Name: Ethiopia Kelenso Mokanisa
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Suavely bright, fragrant, deep. Flowers, pear- and peach-like fruit, honey, pistachio-like nut in aroma and cup. Rich acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a resonant finish.
Notes: From the Kelenso Mokanisa cooperative. This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Founded in 1971, Tony's Coffees & Teas is a wholesale specialty coffee roasting company. Although the Tony's roasting facility is in Bellingham, Washington, the company maintains distribution and training centers in Seattle, Washington and San Jose, California. Visit www.tonyscoffee.com or call 800-448-8804 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Unusually deep and syrupy expression of the southern Ethiopian floral cup.

Name: Ganesha Espresso
BlindReview: Crisply sweet, deep. Dark chocolate, hazelnut, cherry, anise, night-blooming flowers in aroma and small cup. Full, velvety mouthfeel; flavor simplifies but carries into a balanced finish. Delicately complex and sweet in three parts milk: chocolate, hints of cherry, nut and flowers.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #17 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. Ganesha Espresso is Tony’s flagship espresso blend. In 2013 it was named “America’s Best Espresso” at a Seattle competition. Founded in 1971, Tony's Coffees & Teas is a wholesale specialty coffee roasting company. Although the Tony's roasting facility is in Bellingham, Washington, the company maintains distribution and training centers in Seattle, Washington and San Jose, California. Visit www.tonyscoffee.com or call 800-448-8804 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A fine, versatile espresso, full and complex as a straight shot and delicately lively in short milk.

Name: Guatemala Finca Bourbon Organic
BlindReview: Sweetly pungent, deep. Honey, night-blooming flowers, sweet chocolate, almond-like nut in aroma and cup, where a slight savory, peppery edge complicates the sweetness and carries into a drying but flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Certified organically grown. Produced entirely from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. Founded in 1971, Tony's Coffees & Teas is a wholesale specialty coffee roasting company. Although the Tony's roasting facility is in Bellingham, Washington, the company maintains distribution and training centers in Seattle, Washington and San Jose, California. Visit www.tonyscoffee.com or call 800-448-8804 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy depth and savory-sweet resonance in a classic Guatemala cup.

Name: Kagomoini Kenya
BlindReview: Richly pungent, cleanly fruit-toned. Ripe orange, apricot, fresh-cut fir, a hint of almond in aroma and cup. Tartly juicy acidity; impressively full, syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a sweet but gently drying finish.
Notes: From trees of the much-admired SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica. Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Blueprint Coffee is a one-location roastery-café in St. Louis, Missouri that aims at producing a small number of flawless and distinctive coffees. Visit www.blueprintcoffee.com or call 888-863-8053 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Briskly juicy, pleasingly syrupy Kenya.

Name: Tanzania Songea Peaberry
BlindReview: Engaging, complex, sweetly tart. Honey, roasted cacao nib, tart kumquat, lavender-like flowers in aroma and cup. Softly rich acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Citrus and cacao in particular carry into a bittersweet, flavor-saturated finish.
Notes: Produced by small-holding growers near Lake Nyasa. This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Kakalove Café is a nano-roaster located the small city of Chia-Yi in Taiwan that strives to procure and roast the best quality coffee. Visit www.kakalovecafe.com.tw or email [email protected] for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a gently bittersweet cup with unusual, engaging aromatics.

Name: Lennette Kenya
BlindReview: Juicy, sweetly bright. Blood orange, lily-like flowers, dark chocolate, minty black currant in aroma and cup. Crisply sweet, perfectly balanced acidity; silky, lively mouthfeel. Hints of mint, orange and flowers carry into a richly drying finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #22 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. Produced entirely from the admired Kenya heirloom variety SL28. Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Based in the San Diego area, Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler focused on organic and socially responsible coffees; it was awarded the “2012 Roaster of the Year” title from Roast Magazine. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: An exotic yet elegantly balanced Kenya, sweetly dry, lush yet restrained. Impressive and original.

Name: Lakeshore Blend Medium Roast
BlindReview: Crisp, gently bright, delicately complex. Flowers, roasted cacao nib, cherry-like fruit, hazelnut in aroma and cup. Softly brisk, lively acidity. Quite light though silky mouthfeel. Sweetness and hints of flavor carry nicely into the short finish, fade in the long, then reassert themselves in the very long.
Notes: Like all Caribou coffees, this blend is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning the coffees composing it were produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee.  Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a gracefully balanced, refreshing cup with quiet aromatic intrigue.

Name: Sumatra Samosir Batak Medium Roast
BlindReview: Deep, sweetly pungent, earthy. Gently scorched cedar, roasted cacao nib, hints of freshly fallen moist leaves and a floral-toned vanilla. Brisk, roundly bittersweet acidity; light but quite silky mouthfeel. Suggestions of earth, cacao and vanilla all carry into the resonant finish.
Notes: Coffees from the northern part of the Indonesian island of Sumatra, like this one, are admired for their complex earth, fruit and aromatic wood notes that result largely from unorthodox fruit removal and drying practices collectively called “wet hulling.” Like all Caribou coffees, this one is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee.  Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A fine traditional-style darker-roasted Sumatra for those who enjoy the hearty but nuanced earth, smoke and chocolate of the style.

Name: Daybreak Morning Blend Light Roast
BlindReview: Soft, nut-toned. Almond, fresh-cut cedar, ripe orange, a hint of roasted cacao nib in aroma and cup. Round, backgrounded acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The finish is rather quiet but a hint of cacao-like chocolate persists.
Notes: Like all Caribou coffees, this blend is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning the coffees composing it were produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee. Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a gentle morning cup, low in acidity, balanced, unassuming and agreeable in character and aromatics.

Name: Mocha Java Medium Roast
BlindReview: Strong in character, roasty, savory-sweet. Dark chocolate, cedar, sweet herb, a hint of tart, cranberry-like fruit in aroma and cup. Backgrounded acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate persists in a sweetly rich though drying finish.
Notes: Mocha-Java is the world’s earliest blend. It originally combined the only two coffees available in the world in the 17th century: “Mocha” from Yemen and Java from the Dutch colony in what is now Indonesia. This version reconstructs the sensory style of the blend using a variety of origins. Like all Caribou coffees, this blend is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning the coffees composing it were produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee.  Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy history and hearty coffee with a deep, savory complexity.

Name: Single Origin Arabica Espresso
BlindReview: Evaluated as espresso. Sweetly pungent. Fresh-cut cedar, roasted cacao nib, orange zest, rich prune in aroma and, more pronounced, in the small cup. Crisp but rather heavy mouthfeel; flavor consolidates though persists in the finish. Quietly but resonantly pungent in three parts milk.
Notes: CoffeeIndy is a coffee roaster and retailer located in Bangkok, Thailand, specializing in flavored, milk-based beverages. Visit www.coffeeindy.com or call +66-891-422-028 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy pungent sweetness with a roasty edge in a darker roasted espresso.

Name: Kenya AA Gakuyuni
BlindReview: Rich, complex, gently tart. Red grape, black currant, dark chocolate and a hint of deeply expressed flowers in aroma and cup. Round, resonant acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists in a crisp finish.
Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. AA is the highest grade of Kenya coffee based on size of bean and freedom from physical imperfections. Atomic Café is a retail and wholesale coffee roaster on the North Shore of Massachusetts with locations in Beverly and Marblehead, Massachusetts. Visit www.atomicafe.com or call 978-910-0489 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy the juxtaposition of berry and chocolate sweetness and tart, dry elegance of a fine Kenya.

Name: Yemen Haraaz-Red Marqaha Grade A
Origin: Haraz (also spelled Haraaz) growing region, north-central Yemen
BlindReview: Pungent, spicy. Cinnamon, sweet spice, roasted cacao nib, a rounding hint of butter in aroma and cup. Rich, balanced acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Some cinnamon and spice notes carry into a drying finish.
Notes: A dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Haraz is a celebrated coffee growing region in north-central Yemen, west of the capital of Sana'a. Although Ethiopia is the botanical home of Coffea arabica, Yemen introduced the beverage to the rest of the world in the 16th and 17th centuries, and Yemeni coffee is still grown from ancient cultivars and sun-dried, usually on the roofs of stone houses. This particular Yemen is the result of a program aimed at improving the quality of this legendary coffee by drying on raised tables and processing only ripe fruit. CaféTaster is an aficionado nano-roaster of the style increasingly characteristic of East Asia countries like Taiwan and Korea, roasting very high-end coffees in very small volumes for a tiny clientele of passionate coffee enthusiasts, in the process selling coffee education as much as coffee itself. For more information, visit www.facebook.com/cafetaster or email roaster Jerry Huang at [email protected]
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those interested in the taste of history; I suspect this is about how the best of the “Mocha” coffees of Yemen tasted when they first arrived in Europe to establish coffee as a luxury beverage, though they were probably brought to a darker roast. Those who enjoy the more spicy-sweet, savory side of coffee may enjoy this selection regardless of history.

Name: Sidamo Natural Micro-Lot Reserve
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Lightly tart, juicy, citrusy. Tangerine, green grape, honeysuckle, sweet chocolate in aroma and cup. Richly bright but balanced acidity; light, velvety mouthfeel. Some citrus, flowers and chocolate carry into a balanced finish.
Notes: This coffee is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Dragonfly Coffee is a Boulder, Colorado based micro-roaster aiming to produce high-quality coffee and support worthy causes. Visit www.dragonflycoffeeroasters.com or call 303-579-2154 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Unusually bright and citrusy version of the dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia cup should please classicists.

Name: Organic Ethiopian Natural Process
Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Complex, gently pungent, lively. Floral honey, roasted cacao nib, hints of bourbon whisky and blueberry in aroma and cup. Deep, rounded acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The cacao nib and a hint of honeyish flowers carry into a quietly resonant finish.
Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. It is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Banko, established in 2012, is one of twenty-three primary cooperatives located in the Gedeo Zone of Southern Ethiopia that are organized as the Yirgacheffe Farmers Union. Wonderstate Coffee, formerly Kickapoo Coffee, is an award-winning roaster based in rural Wisconsin known for their commitment to guaranteeing higher pay for farmers and being the country’s first 100% solar powered roastery. Visit https://wonderstate.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a quiet, cleanly understated version of the gently fermenty, dried-in-the-fruit cup.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Yirgacheffe
BlindReview: Crisply rich, honey-toned. Honey, roasted cacao nib, wisteria-like flowers, ripe apple, a hint of cumin-like spice in aroma and cup. Roundly tart, juicy acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The apple-like fruit in particular carries into a simple but rich finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. A “natural” or dry-processed coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is lower-toned and more pungent than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned Yirgacheffe profile. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Based in the San Diego area, Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler focused on organic and socially responsible coffees; it was awarded the “2012 Roaster of the Year” title from Roast Magazine. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A light roast develops the natural sweetness and crisp richness of this cleanly balanced dried-in-the-fruit coffee.

Name: FTO Ethiopia Worka 3 Special Reserve
Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Rich, sweet, intense. Brandy, mint, cherry, dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Round, balanced acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate in particular persists in a sweet-toned finish.
Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. It is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Worka is one of twenty-three primary cooperatives located in the Gedeo Zone of Southern Ethiopia that are organized as the Yirgacheffe Farmers Union. Yo el Rey Roasting is a retail coffee shop with an in-house roaster located in California's Napa Valley. Yo el Rey ("I the King"?) roasts only organic and Fair Trade certified coffees. Visit www.yoelrey.com or call 707-942-1180 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: An outstanding version of the more brandy-like style of dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia coffees. The fermented notes are sweet, graceful and cleanly expressed.

Name: Ethiopia Kochere Natural
BlindReview: Chocolaty and spicy. Roasted cacao nib, fresh-cut cedar, flowers, a hint of paprika-like spice in aroma and cup. Richly balanced acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The chocolate-related notes carry deeply into a sweet, gently drying finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. A “natural” or dry-processed coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is lower-toned and more pungent than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned Yirgacheffe profile. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Barista HK is comprehensive specialty coffee business in Hong Kong that operates cafés, provides training, and produces a wide variety of products including coffees like this one. Email Terry Tse, [email protected], for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Clean but unusual profile for coffee adventurers.

Name: Ethiopia Aramo Natural
BlindReview: Crisply sweet, refreshing, gently complex. Ripe tangerine, cherry, honey, fresh-cut cedar, hints of port wine and dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Lightly rich acidity; lightly syrupy, lively mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but still saturates a gently drying finish.
Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is rounder and richer than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned Yirgacheffe profile. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Old Soul is a roastery, bakery and crafter of artisan goods dedicated to quality. Visit www.oldsoulco.com or call 916-443-7685 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A lighter-roasted dried-in-the-fruit coffee that balances great purity and clarity of structure with delicately lush aromatics. Perhaps may satisfy those clean-cup fanatics willing to at least experiment with dried-in-the-fruit profiles.

Name: Nekisse Ethiopia Sidama
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Delicate, complex, lively. Distinct honey and crisply sweet cacao-nib with lavender-like flowers and an herby hint, cilantro perhaps, in aroma and cup. Lively, floral-toned acidity; very light but silky mouthfeel. Lavender in particular carries into a quietly rich finish.
Notes: Ninety Plus is a distinguished boutique exporter and importer of innovative small-lot coffees from Ethiopia and Panama. Grown near Neji in the Sidama/Sidamo growing region, this Ethiopian coffee is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast.  Visit www.barringtoncoffee.com or call 800-528-0998 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A nicely conducted extreme light roast develops the lyric sweetness and delicate complexity of this very pure dried-in-the-fruit coffee. Those who enjoy sophisticated lagers with floral-toned hops might be particular candidates for this one.

Name: Ethiopia Banko Natural
Origin: Gedeo Zone, Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Richly pungent; deep, complex. Strawberry, cedar, night-blooming flowers, dark chocolate, a hint of brandy. Balanced, vibrant acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor, particularly chocolate, saturates a sweet, very slightly drying, finish.
Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. It is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Banko, established in 2012, is one of twenty-three primary cooperatives located in the Gedeo Zone of Southern Ethiopia that are organized as the Yirgacheffe Farmers Union. Olympia Coffee Roasting is a small-batch wholesale and retail roasting company with a youthful, no-nonsense style and a commitment to high-quality organic coffees.  Visit www.olympiacoffeeroasting.com or call 360-753-0066 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Environmentally and socially conscious hedonists. A lush, voluptuous, but cleanly structured dried-in-the-fruit coffee with the chocolate, flowers and brandy appeal of the type plus Fair Trade and organic certifications.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere Aricha
BlindReview: Delicate yet intense; distinctive aromatics. Minty floral notes, sweet chocolate, hints of blueberry and rye whisky in aroma and cup. Gentle but buoyantly vivacious acidity; lively, silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists in a slightly drying, whisky-toned finish.
Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #24 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. This is a “natural” or dry-processed version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is rounder and lower-toned than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned Yirgacheffe profile. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Mr. Espresso is a San Francisco Bay Area wholesale roaster and espresso parts distributer that slow-roasts its coffees using traditional wood-fired roasting machines. Visit www.mrespresso.com or call 510-287-5200 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A hint of blueberry- and whisky-toned ferment complicates floral and chocolate aromatics, all supported by almost perfect structure. A striking value; one seldom sees a coffee this distinctive and distinguished at such a reasonable price.

Name: Ethiopia Ninety Plus Nekisse Red
Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.
BlindReview: Deep, complex, balanced yet extravagant. Ripe plum, honey, crisp roasted cacao nib, orchid-like flowers, a hint of sandalwood in aroma and cup. Delicate, quietly lively acidity; very silky mouthfeel. Flavor saturates a sweet, resonant finish.
Notes: Ninety Plus is a distinguished boutique exporter and importer of innovative small-lot coffees from Ethiopia and Panama. Grown near Neji in the Sidama/Sidamo growing region, this Ethiopian coffee is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Papa Lin's Coffee Roasting is a small, “nano” roaster located in Yorktown Heights, New York, focusing on carefully sourced, extremely high quality specialty coffees, which are custom roasted to the preference of every customer. Visit www.papalins.com for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: For those who can afford it, a coffee flawlessly balanced and deeply exotic in its resonance and complexity.

Name: Guatemala El Tambor
BlindReview: Sweetly crisp, cleanly layered complexity. Dark chocolate, peach-like fruit, hazelnut, a hint of flowers in aroma and cup. Gently lively, flavor-nuanced acidity; silky mouthfeel. Dark chocolate in particular carries into a long, deep finish.
Notes: Finca El Tambor is a distinguished, award-winning Guatemala farm. Caffe Luxxe is an Italian-inflected artisan roaster and retailer that emphasizes both its coffee knowledge and precision and its straightforward lack of pretension. Visit www.caffeluxxe.com or call 310-394-2222 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Classic Guatemala: soft without simplicity, perfectly balanced, enveloping chocolate and low-acid fruit.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Harfusa FTO
BlindReview: Sweet, silky, subtle. Intriguing halvah-like honey and almond notes in aroma and cup, with delicate floral and apple top notes. Gentle, floral-toned acidity; light but buoyantly lively mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a richly sweet-toned though mildly drying finish.
Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed.   Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: Honey and almonds and silky, lyric mouthfeel in this fine certified variant on the great Yirgacheffe cup.

Name: 100% Kona
Origin: Kona growing region, "Big Island" of Hawaii.
BlindReview: Balanced, quietly rich. Buttery caramel, hints of dark chocolate, fresh-cut cedar, apricot in aroma and cup. Round but lively acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor saturates a sweet-toned, resonant finish.
Notes: This fine Kona is produced at Greenwell Farms, one of Kona’s oldest and most respected coffee farms. It is one of Green Mountain’s Special Reserve line of specially sourced, limited edition coffees. Keurig/Green Mountain, formerly Green Mountain Coffee Roasters, pioneered single-serve capsule brewing in the United States with its Keurig brewing system, and remains one of the country’s leading large specialty roasters, offering a particularly wide-ranging variety of origins and roast styles. Visit www.GreenMountainCoffee.com or call 888-879-4627 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A classic Kona, quietly complete, gently seductive.

Name: 100% Kona (K-Cup)
Origin: Kona growing region, "Big Island" of Hawaii.
BlindReview: (As brewed in a Keurig B70 Platinum single-serve brewing device using a "K-Cup" capsule to produce a 6-ounce serving). Sweet-toned and balanced. Caramelly dark chocolate, apricot-like fruit, a hint of fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Crisp acidity; very lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The chocolate and apricot notes carry into a very sweet though slightly drying finish.
Notes: This fine Kona is produced at Greenwell Farms, one of Kona’s oldest and most respected coffee farms. It is one of Green Mountain’s Special Reserve line of specially sourced, limited edition coffees. Keurig brewing devices were among the first single-serve brewers on the market, starting in the mid 1990's with office models and now available in five home models with a variety of features and price points. Keurig/Green Mountain, formerly Green Mountain Coffee Roasters, pioneered single-serve capsule brewing in the United States with its Keurig brewing system, and remains one of the country’s leading large specialty roasters, offering a particularly wide-ranging variety of origins and roast styles. Visit www.GreenMountainCoffee.com or call 888-879-4627 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A fine, classic Kona for Keurig owners.

Name: Jamaica Blue Mountain
BlindReview: Crisply sweet. Apricot- and orange-toned fruit, melon, sweet chocolate, a hint of fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Delicately brisk acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The fruit notes carry into a round, resonant finish.
Notes: This Blue Mountain is produced by Mavis Bank, one of Jamaica’s oldest, most traditional and most respected coffee mills. Mavis Bank coffees grow at some of the highest growing elevations in the Blue Mountains. This is one of Green Mountain’s Special Reserve line of specially sourced, limited edition coffees. Keurig/Green Mountain, formerly Green Mountain Coffee Roasters, pioneered single-serve capsule brewing in the United States with its Keurig brewing system, and remains one of the country’s leading large specialty roasters, offering a particularly wide-ranging variety of origins and roast styles. Visit www.GreenMountainCoffee.com or call 888-879-4627 for more information.
Summary: Who Should Drink It: A solid version of the celebrated Jamaica Blue Mountain profile, with good low-toned fruit and chocolate.

Name: Jamaica Blue Mountain (K-Cup)
BlindReview: (As brewed in a Keurig B70 Platinum single-serve brewing device using a "K-Cup" capsule to produce a 6-ounce serving). Crisp, sweet-toned, delicate. Caramel, apricot, sweet chocolate, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Round, gentle acidity; plush mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists in a rich though slightly drying finish.
Notes: This Blue Mountain is produced by Mavis Bank, one of Jamaica’s oldest, most traditional and most respected coffee mills. Mavis Bank coffees grow at some of the highest growing elevations in the Blue Mountains. This is one of Green Mountain’s Special Reserve line of specially sourced, limited edition coffees. Keurig brewing devices were among the first single-serve brewers on the market, starting in the mid 1990's with office models and now available in five home models with a variety of features and price points.
